TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-All Australians heard with deep shock and concern this morning the news of an attempt on the life of President Reagan. President Reagan has undergone surgery and his condition, as I am advised, is reported to be good. His Press Secretary, Mr James Brady, who was also shot is reported as being in a critical condition. One security guard and one policeman were also shot. A young assailant has been charged with these shootings.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the latest tragic example of the vulnerability of public figures in the United States of America to the threat of attempted assassination and is part of an increasing pattern of political violence around the world which continues to shock all decent people. The news we have of the President's condition gives us some relief. We have all heard the reports of his bravery and good spirits in the aftermath of this attempt on his life. We salute him and admire him. We all hope and pray for his speedy and complete recovery. At this time of trial, the United States Government and people are demonstrating yet again their great strength and resilience as a nation. The United States people should know that we in Australia respond to this shocking event in a spirit of complete sympathy, support, and concern for all those personally involved and for their families. I inform the House that I have this morning sent personal messages to Mrs Reagan, to the President, and to Secretary of State Haig, expressing our sincere concern for and our hopes for a speedy recovery of all those who were involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Like the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), I was appalled to hear the news this morning of the attempt to assassinate President Reagan. We have been pleased to hear that his condition is improving, and on behalf of the Opposition I shall be sending a message to the President and Vice-President expressing our deep concern that this should have happened and our hope for the early recovery of the President. We shall also be conveying to Mrs Reagan our sympathy at a time of great tension and anguish for her and her family, and indeed of great anxiety for the American people.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall also ask that the sympathies of the Opposition be made known to the families of those who were struck down around the President. The condition of Press Secretary, James Brady, is reported to be critical. In our justified concern for the well-being of the President, we should also take care to keep in mind the sacrifice of Mr Brady, of the secret service agent and the policeman who were shot and the equal anguish of their families.

Mr Speaker, this deadly attack is unfortunately not without precedent in the United States. As well as the assassination of John Kennedy in 1963, and that of President McKinley in 1901, there have been several other attempts on United States Presidents this century, including President Ford. This sort of violence is becoming more prevalent; the lives of national leaders throughout the world seem now to be much more at risk. In Australia, it is true, there has been no tradition of political violence against national leaders-the attack against the then Leader of the Opposition, Arthur Calwell, in 1966 stood out because of its rarity. But I say in all seriousness that Australian Prime Ministers must take account of the increasing dangers to their safety and take adequate security precautions.

In the Australian and British context, a low-key approach in which security precautions have been as inconspicuous as possible has proved effective so far. To my mind there is always a danger that highly visible security might encourage the unbalanced seeker after macabre celebrity, against whom it is almost impossible to defend, however massive the security measures taken. I reiterate our deep shock at these events, and our hope that in the text few days we shall hear good news about the condition of the President and all others involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister a question. I refer to the rather sensational-perhaps sensationalised-reports, which are very disturbing, of Soviet penetration of the British security service, including the allegation that a founding father of the Australian Security Intelligence Service may have been a Soviet agent and that the penetration of British agencies may be current. Is it a fact that there is a regular exchange of top classified security material between the British and Australian security services? Is it a fact that Mr Justice Hope did not investigate matters related to these claims, reasonably enough, because they were not known at the time? Further, has the Prime Minister noted the very disturbing allegation of Mr Brian Toohey, a senior journalist who has just returned from several years' assignment in Washington, that the Central Intelligence Agency believes that there has been a high level penetration of the Public Service, perhaps even the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, by the Soviets for more than a decade, resulting in a volume and quantity of security material flowing to the Soviets exceeding anything coming from any other part of the world? Therefore, will he arrange for a full and urgent inquiry into these matters and for a report to be tabled in Parliament on them as promptly as possible? Finally, will the Prime Minister reaffirm the normal practice of arranging full briefings on request for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and me from all heads of security agencies in this country in relation to these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman knows a full briefing is available to him at any time. I hope that he will take up the matter if he has any concerns about some of the current allegations. I hope also that no members of this House will wilfully try to enlarge allegations which significantly concern events of some decades ago, in many instances, and try to suggest that they are relevant to the various services today. Let me give as an example the allegations in relation to Colonel Ellis. He was involved in intelligence matters in Australia some 25 to 30 years ago. Certain allegations have been made about Colonel Ellis in the recent book by Mr Chapman Pincher in the United Kingdom, but these allegations are not new. It became known to various people in Australia that this book was to be published before it was published. I was told of the allegations that would be made in the book and I was told at that time that the allegations were not new. A senior officer of my Department confirmed on 31 March with Mr Justice Hope that he was fully aware of the allegations about Colonel Ellis when framing his recommendations as royal commissioner on intelligence and security. Allegations against Colonel Ellis have no present significance for Australia, as I am advised.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth noting that we have had a royal commission into the security services and that the royal commissioner, as I am advised, was aware of the circumstances of the bulk of these allegations, certainly the ones coming out of the United Kingdom involving particular officials or persons from the United Kingdom, including Colonel Ellis, as I have just mentioned. He made his reports. The Government has considered those reports and has acted upon them in a very significant way, and statements have been made in the Parliament about that. Again, I think we need to keep these matters in perspective so far as Australia is concerned.

The honourable gentleman has raised allegations involving a mole in senior echelons of the Government's advisers, making the suggestion that the United States is aware of that but has not done anything about it, has not advised us. The original allegation is an incredible one. I am only disappointed that the Leader of the Opposition has given any credence or support to it because he has been given briefings by the Director-General of the Australian Security and Intelligence Organisation and by the Department of Defence, amongst others, and he has visited the joint facilities in which the United States and Australia are full partners and has seen the extent of our co-operation. I ask him, and I ask the House, whether it is conceivable that the United States Government would continue co-operation of this kind if it believed for one moment that there was a KGB mole in the senior ranks of the Public Service. If the United States had suspicions it would tell us. The relationship is of that kind; there is not the slightest doubt about that. We would certainly act to see whether those suspicions were unfounded or founded. If the Leader of the Opposition wishes to have a further specific briefing by Mr Justice Woodward, that will be available to him as a matter of course.
Allegations of this kind are the stock in trade in certain areas, prompted sometimes by shadowy figures in the world of intelligence. I note also that Brian Toohey recently wrote:
In the double agent, triple agent business, the KGB has managed to create a debilitating atmosphere within the CIA in which no one is safe from the indiscriminate finger of suspicion.

If the Leader of the Opposition or anyone else has any evidence-not indiscriminate allegations-of KGB penetration, I invite him to provide it to me. But the suggestion that the United States knows of penetration and does not tell us about it is so utterly absurd that it should be given no credence by anyone in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Prime Minister, refers to recent events in Poland between the union Solidarity and the Polish Government, and this Government's expression of concern about those events. I ask the Prime Minister: What is the current position in Poland and the Government's response to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is clearly following developments in Poland closely and with a very great deal of concern. Over recent weeks we have been in very close touch with a number of other countries in relation to Poland. It would now seem that the general situation is being aggravated by increased external pressure, notably from some of Poland's so-called allies in the Warsaw Pact. We are concerned that the Soviet media has recently reported Polish developments in tendentious terms. We are concerned with the pressure that has apparently been placed upon Poland by the Soviet Union or Warsaw Pact countries. We view this as an unhelpful intrusion in Polish internal affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent months the Polish Government and people have shown a commendable capacity for restraint and moderation in their attempts to solve the country's very serious difficulties. It would seem also that events within the recent 12 or 18 hours demonstrate again their capacity to resolve their own problems if only they are left alone to do so. Any departure from that course is likely to have serious repercussions not only in Poland but also abroad. The Government has said many times before that the Polish people must be left to resolve their difficulties in their own way without a threat of external interference or coercion. We can only be disturbed by the knowledge of the extent of preparations of Warsaw Pact countries, and Soviet Union forces, and their capacity to act with great speed and with very little warning in terms of additional military preparations. The state of readiness of Soviet Union forces on the boundaries of Poland has been very high for months. That carries its own implications of which, I have no doubt, the Government of Poland would be well aware. We have joined with others in publicly expressing our anxiety about the grave consequences of intervention by the Soviet Union for international order, peace, and East-West relations. If the Soviet Union moved to an invasion of Poland the world would not be the same again. These views have been made abundantly clear to the Soviet Government. It would know very plainly where Australia stands.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, relates to a matter raised today by my leader. I also submit that it comes within the special case consideration identified by Mr Justice Hope in paragraph 460 of his report. Is the Prime Minister in a position to advise the House whether the Australian Government was informed of British doubts about, and the interrogation of, British agents Hollis and Ellis? If the Government was informed, what action was taken to vet Australian officials?

—These matters occurred very many years ago. I have already made it plain that since that time we have had our own royal commission. Mr Ellis was involved some 25 to 30 years ago. Obviously I would have no personal knowledge of the details of what occurred 25 or 30 years ago. I have knowledge of the fact that Mr Justice Hope was aware of these allegations at the time he made his report and anything he needed to say or wanted to say he was able to say.
—The interrogation period was before Hope.
—If it was even earlier I would suggest that it is of even less relevance to the Australian scene today.
—You were in government at the time.

—I was not in parliament at the time. I have been advised that Mr Justice Hope was aware of these matters. He was able to report on any matters that he wished. The report of the royal commission postdates any of these matters, whether they relate to Hollis or Ellis. Let me only say that I was advised, before these reports in relation to both gentlemen became public, that they would be made public. I was also advised of the official attitude in relation to both of them. Therefore, our authorities were aware of the circumstances in relation to Hollis and Ellis. I think that honourable gentlemen opposite are really going on a far-fetched fishing operation, especially since our own royal commission examined all Australia's security agencies much more recently than when these events occurred. The royal commission has reported and we have acted upon that report. As the honourable gentleman knows, there is full consultation with the Leader of the Opposition.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of concern being expressed in Western Australia regarding possible future changes to Commonwealth-State tax sharing arrangements? TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the honourable gentleman thinks the Leader of the Opposition asks me Dorothy Dixers. Some time ago, because the States recognised that the relativities between the States in respect of the moneys that we make available in tax reimbursement grants may well have altered, or that the needs of the States may have altered, all the Premiers agreed that a report ought to be provided by a special division of the Commonwealth Grants Commission on relativities between the States. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer to the current Senate inquiry into Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd when the Minister for Communications made the unsworn statement that when he was Minister for Primary Industry he did not know of the breaking of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangements by Asia Dairy Industries. As the former manager of ADI, Mr Tony Webster, has now said in a sworn statement that the Minister did know, who does the Prime Minister believe?
—If there is any information that I can give the honourable gentleman, I will give it.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of claims by the New South Wales Chairman of the Cattlemen's Union that Australia is not realising potential beef sales to Asian countries, such as Korea, because Australia's tariff policies are preventing these countries from earning sufficient foreign exchange to fund desired levels of beef imports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no evidence to suggest that there is any significant relationship between the purchases of beef by various Asian countries and the tariff policies of this country. Indeed, the purchases of beef by the various Asian countries vary quite considerably and for different reasons. If we take Korea, the fact is that the Korean Government reduced the importation of beef for a couple of reasons. It had pressure from its own beef producers and at the same time it had a doubling of its oil bill and was concerned about expenditure on foreign exchange. Indeed, on the Korean market we hope that, following the announcement of a tender being called by the Korean Government for some 12,000 tonnes, that country might be back on the market.

ANSWER.PARA: Asian countries, apart from Japan, since the 1970s have increased their levels of imports from some 10,000 tonnes to some 55,000 tonnes. Again, for a variety of reasons they have not been in the market so strongly as previously. One of those reasons was that at the height of their purchases beef prices in this country were very low. They were taking advantage of the low beef prices in the country. Since the increase in price on export markets the Australian marketers have taken advantage of improved market opportunities in other countries to the cost of sales in Japan. There has not been an availability of beef to service all markets.

As to the other part of the honourable member's question in relation to tariffs, I point out that the Government recognises the importance of improved access for developing countries into developed country markets such as Australia. I believe that we have a good record in this regard, particularly in comparison with other advanced industrialised countries. For example, the Australian system of tariff preferences for developing countries is designed to assist them in competing for access to our market. A reflection of this preferential treatment is seen in the fact that our percapita imports from developing countries are significantly greater than those of the United States, the European Economic Community and Japan. Similarly, even in regard to protected areas such as textiles and clothing imports, the Australian market reflects a much higher proportion of such imports than is the case in most major Western developed countries. Summing up, I would say that there is not a great deal of substance in the claim made by the New South Wales Chairman of the Cattlemen's Union.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industry inform the House of the latest position regarding efforts by United States dairying interests to have restrictions placed on Australian casein exports to that country, which, in 1979-80, took 9,657 tonnes, or 70 per cent, of our total casein exports?

—The Government is concerned about reports that advances are again being made in the United States Congress for the imposition of restrictions on casein and milk protein imports. The value of this trade to Australia is some $17.5m and represents some 70 per cent of our total exports of casein. We have made representations to the United States pointing to the adverse impact of any such action on the Australian dairying industry and urging the Administration to resist pressures to introduce quantitative import restrictions. I am pleased to note that the United States Senate decided not to amend the 1981 Farm Bill to provide for restrictions on casein imports, but I understand that the Department of Agriculture is doing some work on this for the United States Administration. We will be making representations to the United States Government pointing out the Australian Government's position on the matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. The Minister will be aware of the concern expressed by representatives of the tuna fishing industry about the reported Government decision to lift the freeze on licences in that industry. Is the Minister aware of recent Press statements that fishermen in the industry were opposed to the lifting of the freeze, and of claims 'that the tuna industry was in a mess, and that now is not the time to lift the freeze, apparently only that foreign interests can be served'? I understand that the Minister was to meet the Australian Fishing Industry Council in Adelaide recently. Can he inform the House of the result of those discussions and whether there has been any change in the attitude of the Government to the lifting of the freeze on such licences?

—Today being 31 March, I believe that it is 12 months to the day since this Government announced that the freeze would be continued until 31 March 1981 and would then be lifted. In the interim 12-month period an economic survey of the industry was to be made and soundings taken as to the future of the freeze. The decision to lift the freeze was taken 12 months ago or more at a meeting I had with State Ministers with fishing interests. The present situation is somewhat mixed. Differing views are being taken by people interested in the tuna industry from the various States. For example, the New South Wales Government and, as I understand it, the majority of members of the tuna industry of that State, want the freeze on licences in the industry lifted. The same thing applies in Victoria and Western Australia. The same thing does not apply in South Australia, that Government having changed its view about the situation which was considered last year. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I have looked also at the level of foreign ownership in the various projects which are operating or in the process of being built. These levels are as follows: Collinsville-Newlands mine 53.9 per cent; Oaky Creek 64 per cent; Goonyella, Peak Downs, Daunea and Norwich Park 80 per cent; Blackwater 89.2 per cent; Curragh 49.6 per cent; Sirius Creek 100 per cent; Blair Athol 76.8 per cent; Capella 76.8 per cent; Hail Creek 46.3 per cent; German Creek 85.8 per cent; Tarong 61 per cent and Dalby-Milmerran 100 per cent. It is disastrous for a nation like Australia to find this very high level of foreign ownership in Queensland, one of the areas which will be burgeoning, in terms of the development of our resources industry. It is disastrous to find these figures so high particularly in the steaming and coking coal industries. Last week the position was exacerbated when we saw the Queensland Government grant an authority to prospect to a consortium of companies which included British Petroleum Ltd, Drayton Mining Development Co. Pty Ltd and Westfield Ltd. The position is that foreign ownership in Queensland is being exacerbated rather than diminished. The behaviour of the Queensland Government last week will not help to change the position one iota.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week the Opposition raised in the House the relationship between these companies and the Queensland Government and the way in which the Queensland Government awarded the tender to BP, Drayton and Westfield. In that speech I invited BP, amongst others-BP is the foreign company of that tender consortium-to answer publicly a number of questions. The first one was to make public its dealings with Mr Camm, the former Queensland Mines Minister. British Petroleum has done so in a statement released under the name of Mr Alex Gorrie, its chief executive. I also invited BP to say how and why it came to be involved with Drayton which is a company owned by Sir Leslie Thiess, or Thiess interests, and Westfield. The questions I asked related to the mechanics of this marriage between these companies for the process of the tender application.

British Petroleum failed to address itself to this issue in its reply released late last week. I invited BP and the other companies involved, that is Drayton and Westfield, to say whether money had been paid to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. Mr Gorrie replied that BP had not contributed anything to political parties. At this point we have heard nothing from either Drayton or Westfield. They have remained silent throughout and have made no response whatsoever about any financial relations they may have had with the National Country Party, the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation or anything else. I invited BP to make public its tender submissions so that we could have an opportunity to examine them but BP failed to respond to his request. All it has said is that it does not contribute to political parties. Whilst I accept that assurance-BP also referred to Mr Camm's visit to the company's headquarters in May 1978-no mention was made of the arrangements with Drayton and Westfield and there was no publishing of the tender. British Petroleum has referred basically to what it suits it to refer to-the issues where it felt it could give a definitive reply. It has not referred to the arrangements entered into with Drayton and Westfield or to the other issues which I have just raised. The situation became clear over the weekend in an article by Mr Allen which appeared in the Sunday Mail. The article stated in part:
Mr Gibbs alleged in a press statement on March 24 that Dr Edwards was a party to the tender assessment.
'I took with me a supplementary 31-page document to Cabinet. It had a summary of each applicant's offer', Mr Gibbs said.
The Mines Minister said this document was examined in detail by a Cabinet committee which included Dr Edwards.
'Officers from the Treasury were included in the final assessment of the documents before Cabinet announced its decision to award the authority to prospect to a consortium led by BP', Mr Gibbs said.
Yet twice in the state House, Dr Edwards has denied that he was party to the evaluation of the 32 tenders.
On March 12, the Treasurer and Deputy Premier said: 'Neither I nor my officers were involved in the discussions in regard to the assessment of the tender'.
Then in reply to the Acting Opposition Leader, Mr D'Arcy, in the House on March 25, Dr Edwards said:
'I am unaware of the details of the proposals by other tenderers'.

If it is all above board, why does not the Queensland Government release all the tender documents? If the Queensland Government says that this matter was decided competitively in a Cabinet situation, with a complete understanding of all the details, why not make all the tender proposals public so that the public is in a position to judge the comparative merits of each tender? Apparently, the Queensland Government does not want to do this. If the Government says it has nothing to hide, what is the point of not making the tenders public? I find it very strange that the British National Coal Board was given a 16 per cent share of the German Creek major coking coal deposit in Queensland when the same British National Coal Board is opposing the Utah company's coal exports to Great Britain to the conglomerate steel maker there, the British Steel Corporation.

It seems to me a curious way of expressing the British National Coal Board's gratitude for being allowed to participate in a substantial and important coking coal venture, to find that it, a state instrumentality of the British Government, opposes coal exports from Australia to Britain. Other British companies have been awarded large and important areas of coal in Queensland, even though the British National Coal Board persists in this behaviour. The BP company is 46 per cent owned by the British Government. It is in part a creature of the British Government. We are awarding it a major coal lease. No one would object to this if we could establish that it was done in a competitive tender situation. That is not clear. It appears that Drayton and Westfield either jointly or severally have made arrangements with the Queensland Government, or have come to agreements with the National Party leadership of the Queensland Government, which are outside the terms of the competitive situation of the tenders submitted by these companies.

Drayton is owned by Sir Leslie Thiess and his family. Westfield is owned by a property developer. It is no news to anybody that the mining interests of Thiess were hived off and taken over by CSR Ltd not so long ago. It is no longer a burgeoning mining company. No doubt Sir Leslie Thiess has experience, but he is now an elderly man, and one wonders what the management status of that company is when its previous coal interests were so poorly managed that a takeover was imminent and had been for some time before CSR finally took it over. Fortunately for Australia, the company remained in Australian hands. One wonders what the intelligence is now of saying to Sir Leslie Thiess and his company, Drayton, particularly at the twilight stage of his active commercial life: 'Here is a major coal area in Queensland'. I have no doubt that Westfield is a substantial company but, again, what is the basis on which it has become involved? Those companies seem to be a most unlikely combination.

If BP knew of any arrangements which Drayton or Westfield had made with any member or members of the Queensland Cabinet outside the tendering processes it would be as guilty as the other parties if the tendering processes had been subverted, whether BP was involved directly or indirectly. That is the issue. Drayton, Westfield and BP have been very silent on it. If we are to hear more from them, I would like to hear how they got together. I would like to hear some expressions from the three companies, particularly Drayton and Westfield, as to their dealings with the Queensland Government and members of its Cabinet outside the normal tendering processes. I invite them all once again to clear up this matter and not be reticent about telling the public of the situation.

I repeat my assertion that the Queensland Government should table all the tenders and let a public judgment be made. This was the first major competitive situation for the awarding of a major coal lease in a state of Australia. It was a competitive situation which was essentially squandered in the eyes of most of the other participants, public commentators and people in the industry. That is a very bad precedent to have been established. I regard it most seriously, particularly when we are in this position of having British companies favoured in Queensland, where the companies have been generously awarded areas. We then find that their creatures in Great Britain-the British National Coal Board amongst others-are vehemently opposed to British steel importing Australian coal. That seems a funny way of rewarding that kind of behaviour.

Overall we are seeing a general problem with foreign investment. The repatriated dividends which are flowing from investments in Australia made in the 1960s are now a substantial drain on the balance of payments. Because we have been a balance of trade deficit country for most of our history since the war we have been keeping some equilibrium in the balance of payments by bringing in capital inflow. The more inflow we have, the more we are committed. Equity is a drain upon dividends forever while debt capital is a drain upon dividends for a while. While we augment out balance of payments with slabs of equity, we commit our country irrevocably to a continuing payout of dividends. In other words, foreign investment is addictive. The more of it we have; the more dividends we have: The more dividends we have; the more capital we need to maintain the balance of payments. So we find ourselves travelling down this road. The only obvious benefits which must accrue to this country can come through a continuing and growing level of Australian ownership.

The Government talks about the 50 per cent policy. The unfortunate thing about the 50 per cent policy is that it now becomes a 50 per cent maximum, not a 50 per cent minimum. For years the Opposition has been encouraging the Government to adopt the 50 per cent policy as a minimum. In some areas I believe that the Government is now trying to reach that objective. The figure of 50 per cent has now in the Government's terms become a maximum. Organisations of Australian companies or Australian companies with 100 per cent Australian equity are virtually invited to bring their foreign partners along to be considered in these major projects. I think this is a great shame for Australia. Certainly, a lot of benefits from the resources industry will simply dissipate if we do not lift the level of Australian ownership.

Handing out authorities to prospect at that basic stage to foreign companies is absolutely stupid because Australian companies are then admitted later, in some cases by paying a huge premium on the value of the shares, simply because a foreign company has been given the right to prospect to quantity a reserve and to come up with some preliminary engineering plans. It is not fair to Australians. It does not reap the benefit for Australians from foreign investment. It squanders opportunities which the Australian people should have. The Government will have to be ever more vigilant about this authority to prospect issue to ensure that the States are just not handing away to companies some of the best and most important coal areas in the world. In this squalid situation one finds that tender processes for competitive bids are upset by political preferences. I ask BP, Drayton and Westfield-not one of them but all-to say what arrangements thay have had together, to say what arrangements they have made with the Queensland Cabinet and any members of that Cabinet either individually or corporately, and to make this matter clear. I call upon the Queensland Government once again to table all the tender documents and let a public evaluation be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case the House has forgotten the topic of the matter of public importance raised by the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating)-which he hardly touched on-it is:

SPEECH.PARA: The unsatisfactory nature of the granting of mineral leases in Australia resulting in a continuing concentration of Australian mineral wealth in the hands of foreign corporations, particularly in Queensland.

The honourable member spent 90 per cent of his time complaining about alleged deals in Queensland, whereas this is a very serious matter which affects the whole of Australia and should be examined on that basis. After all, State governments grant these licences. It is not a federal matter at all. It is a farce for the honourable member to beat his breast in this Parliament about matters that, constitutionally, are specifically under the control of the State parliaments. I wonder whether the allegation of stupidity which the honourable member, at the conclusion of his remarks, directed at State governments relates, for example, to the former Dunstan Government of South Australia. Mr Dunstan clearly took the view, and stated it repeatedly, that he was quite in favour of allowing foreigners to explore for minerals to their heart's content in South Australia provided the actual mining was carried out on a basis of 50 per cent Australian ownership. Apparently, according to the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr Dunstan is stupid, although perhaps that might be an unkind comment to make about him. A similar comment might apply to New South Wales. The fact is that as long as under the present Federal Government guidelines, the ultimate ownership is at least 50 per cent Australian, it seems that this Government's role, which is what we should be discussing here, is proper and reasonable.

Some of the grants of mining licences in Australia certainly fall far short of what is totally desirable. I refer especially, of course, to what has happened in New South Wales, a subject which was avoided by the honourable member, who is the President of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party. Obviously, he would be terribly embarrassed to acknowledge the reality of the granting of mining and exploration licences in that State. I refer him especially to a company called Energy Recycling of Australia. It is not a multinational. It is one which was given by the New South Wales Government, in the course of a deal, the reasons for which I hope will be made public sooner or later, a mining licence in the Ulan area, a very rich coal area, simply because it had managed to convince the Premier that it had a magic formula for converting coal into some super fuel. I do not know what special arguments or inducements of an intellectual kind enabled the Premier to come to the curious conclusion that this straw company had the capacity, the knowledge, the skill, and the licences to justify the granting to it of such an enormous benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The authority has now been withdrawn.

—The honourable member has awakened from his sloth and states that it has been withdrawn. Certainly it has, after for some time blocking other corporations from developing the area and only because the corporation was exposed by the honourable Ted Pickering, a colleague of mine in the Upper House of the Parliament of New South Wales, as one which had no capacity to undertake this work. The granting of the licence was a farce in the first place and is a typical example of the way in which a State government can be seduced. I do not know what the seduction was, or its terms. I cannot understand why a man who presents such a reasonable face as does the Premier of New South Wales should be seduced into providing a company of straw, comprising nothing but hot air, with such a licence. Certainly, it demonstrates that there may be some accuracy in the point raised by the honourable member for Blaxland. Perhaps some States, such as New South Wales, do not indeed follow the proper course; that the way in which mining licences are granted in some States is of an unsatisfactory nature. I have particularly dramatised the position in the State of New South Wales in that example.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to listen to the usual diatribe against foreign investment in Australia from the honourable member, who would notice, I suppose, that in New South Wales a lot of exploration is being undertaken by foreign multi- nationals. Although it might offend and upset the honourable member, I draw to his attention an area in the Riverina district where the Mitsubishi organisation is undertaking the actual work of exploration. Surely, a consortium is involved but it seems to me that the very principle espoused by the honourable member for Blaxland, that it is stupid to allow foreign multinationals to perform exploration, is in conflict with the approach taken in New South Wales, where Mitsubishi Development Pty Ltd, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Corporation of Tokyo, is carrying out the drilling being performed by the Corporation. Frankly, I believe that such activity is a great thing for Australia. My view is that it is wonderful for the development of this country that international corporations are prepared to invest their money, in partnership with Australians, in such activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

Following consideration of recommendations by the IAC in its report on cheese, the Government has decided that existing levels of assistance should be maintained except for Canada, where rates of duty on certain cheeses will rise from $80 per tonne to the general tariff rate of $96 per tonne. In its report the IAC recommended a duty of $200 per tonne on imports from all sources which would have required that cheese be removed from Schedule A of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. Failing agreement with New Zealand on this action, the IAC recommended an equivalent bounty. Following consultations between the New Zealand Dairy Board and the Australian industry, agreement was reached on the export of New Zealand cheese to Australia. The New Zealand Dairy Board has given assurances that it has no intention of disrupting the Australian market and will follow a policy of reasonable restraint towards cheese exports to Australia. The Government also noted that a multilateral trade negotiation agreement with the European Economic Community has secured guaranteed access for Australian cheese to the market in return for which Australia agreed to allow specified quantities of EEC cheese entry into Australia.

In respect of the IAC's report on crushing or grinding machines, the Government considered that the reduction in assistance for jaw and vertical rotary crushing machines, having a working weight of less than 50 tonnes, to the level of 15 per cent as recommended by the Commission, could lead to significant disruption to activity and employment in the industry and has decided that a duty rate of 20 per cent would be more appropriate. The remainder of the goods under reference will continue to be dutiable at 15 per cent as recommended by the Commission.

In its report on fluorescent and filament lamps the IAC, in a majority recommendation, suggested that no short term assistance be provided. The Government considered that the mechanism put forward by the IAC-that is, a full rebate of the protective portion of the tariff-would have resulted in an unduly generous rebate for imported manufactured cut tobacco.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating a paper entitled 'Review of Australia's Demographic Trends' presented to the House last Wednesday by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). The Minister at the end of his statement to the House said:

SPEECH.PARA: We should not be misled into believing that issues arising from future population developments can be left to the future.

I believe that it is in that spirit that the Minister presented the paper. He has given the House an opportunity to debate some of the implications of future population growth for policy development in various areas of Australia. With that in mind, I compliment the spokesman for the Opposition, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), for the way in which he responded to the Minister's statement and for the very constructive comments he made about the paper.

The paper reviews Australia's demographic trends in the light of recent data and it comments on some implications for the next 20 years. Naturally one of the major facts commented on in the paper is the aging population in Australia. The situation is summarised at page 3 of the paper. The following comment is made:

Persons in the older age groups are also of particular interest to policy makers. The number of people 65 and over is expected to increase by about two-thirds by the end of the century, while the number of persons over 75 is expected to roughly double. The absolute size of these groups affects social welfare planning, including the provision of pensions and special medical care and accommodation.

Those large increases will take place without there being a commensurate increase in the working age groups in the population. Obviously that has implications for the sheer rate of expenditure on social security payments and on a number of other benefits.

I link that aspect of the aging of the population to another aspect which is commented upon on page 6 of the paper where reference is made to the number of divorces taking place in Australia. The paper points out that, in 1975, 24,000 divorces were registered but that in 1976, the year after the commencement of the Family Law Act, there was a substantial upturn to 63,000 divorces. The number fell back to 38,000 in 1979. I do not want to get into a protracted argument about the meaning of the figure of 63,000 in 1976 because to a very substantial extent there would have been an element of pent-up demand-if that is an appropriate phrase to use with respect to divorce-in that a number of people were waiting for the Family Law Act to come into operation before they pursued their applications for divorce. However, in the last 10 years or so there has been indisputably an increase in the rate of divorce. I link this with the aging of the population because it may have implications of the degree to which government agencies will have to become involved in the care of the aged.

It appears to me that one of the implications of an increasing divorce rate may well be that children of divorced parents who have perhaps gone into a second or third family-a reconstructed family-as a result of a second or third marriage, may not have the same degree of emotional commitment to their parents; they may not have the same sense of obligation to look after their elderly parents as has been the case in the past. I think that is a matter that we ought to explore in greater detail. It is not touched on in this paper. Perhaps the authors of the paper did not feel it was their responsibility to comment on this matter. But, as well as looking at the sheer numbers of elderly people in the population-the sheer percentage of elderly people-I think we need to look at the extent to which there will be that sense of obligation between the age groups that has in fact enabled large numbers of aged persons to be cared for in the past in the homes of their children and families. So, I think that is a matter of some significance for the future.

The Minister in his statement commented that the net reproduction rate of the Australian population in 1979 was 0.92 per cent, that is, a figure below the long term level of replacement of the population, the replacement figure being one per cent. The Minister commented that there had been a decrease in the reproduction or the replacement rate of previous years. The honourable member for Port Adelaide in commenting on the Minister's statement said that he did not think that, economic demands being what they are in the home, there was likely to be an uptake in the fertility rate in Australia which would markedly alter the figures given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

There is some evidence in the paper tabled by the Minister that there may in fact be some upsurge as a result of revised attitudes to child bearing. I refer to a comment on page 6 of the paper that there was an 'upturn in birth rates of women aged 30 years and over (suggesting that births postponed at earlier ages were being made up)'. Some commentators have pointed out that there are some indications, which perhaps are very early at this stage and one cannot draw firm conclusions from them, that young couples who had decided they would both work to establish themselves first are now getting to the stage where they want to have families. They have made this decision after having developed the economic security they were looking for in the early years of their marriage.

There are also some indications that people who had perhaps decided that two children were enough, have decided after a few years that perhaps they would after all like another child. They have decided that, having done a number of things they wanted to do without the ties of a large family and after thinking about it again, it would be nice to have more children. I am certainly not going to suggest that we will get to the stage of having the very large families that were common many years ago. But I am going to suggest that there is some evidence that in the coming few years we are likely to see an increase in the number of families who have three or four children when perhaps their original intention was to have only two children. So I think that that is a possible change in community attitudes that we will want to watch. The Minister also pointed to the fact that on present assumptions it would appear that over the next few years the average annual gain to the population through migration would be at a rate of about 0.5 or 0.6 of one per cent of the population.

I refer now to some aspects of our migration selection program and point to some of the problems that have arisen. One of the major initiatives of our immigration program in recent years has been the implementation of the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System, the point score system whereby applicants for migration to Australia, outside refugee categories and outside trans-Tasman migration-that is, New Zealanders-are assessed. That system has been the subject of many criticisms, particularly from people who have friends and relatives whom they want to bring into the country and who have not been approved under NUMAS. The Minister has announced that NUMAS is presently the subject of a major review. He has invited migrant and ethnic community organisations-indeed, a wide range of interested groups-to comment on NUMAS and have some input into the review, if they wish to do so.

I think that many of the criticisms of NUMAS arise from those who understandably are disappointed at being rejected. This will happen under any system of selection. As a member of parliament who deals with many migration inquiries, I can report that NUMAS has produced more consistency in migration approvals than was previously the case. After all, the factors that NUMAS encompasses have always been part of Australia's selection process. I refer to factors such as job skills, ability in English, accommodation guarantees by sponsors, and formal qualifications that might be recognised in Australia. Before NUMAS was introduced, I always had the feeling that some of our selection officers overseas gave greater weight to one factor than to others. For example, one officer may have given undue emphasis to current knowledge of English and ignored excellent qualifications and an intellect which would enable the applicant to learn English quickly. Another selection officer may have been mesmerised by formal academic qualifications without properly assessing personal settlement factors.

NUMAS has the effect of forcing all selection officers to go through each of the factors and give them an appropriate numerical weighting according to a set scale. Obviously there is room for dispute about what is an appropriate weighting but there is, it seems to me, a basic integrity about the system itself which minimises the exercise of personal preferences on the part of departmental staff. It has also given members of parliament a better basis for describing to constituents the criteria that their friends and relatives will have to meet when they apply to come to Australia.

One personal criticism that I have of the present application of NUMAS is that insufficient credit is given to non-formal job qualifications. It is easier to allocate points for a trade certificate or a diploma than it is to allocate points for what might best be described as entrepreneurial flair. I think that all honourable members would agree that many of the migrants who have made the most significant contributions to the developments of the Australian economy and to our cultural fabric are people who have lacked formal qualifications but who have had the initiative, enterprise and personal robustness which has enabled them to succeed very well in Australia. I think that there are potential migrants still with little formal education who have the energy and enterprise to create their own employment in some form of small business. I hope that the review of NUMAS will enable greater credit to be given for such attributes.

On the broader debate about immigration policy, it is difficult to obtain a comprehensive objective assessment of the economic and employment effects of a migrant intake. One gets the impression that most of such assessments are made to support a predetermined attitude; that is, proponents of more immigration point to the employment-creating effects of the increased demand for goods and services by new migrants and opponents of immigration enlist arguments about competition for scarce jobs and pressure on already overtaxed community facilities. Whatever the economic benefits, and they are probably mixed in the short term, I think it is fair to say that immigration is not solely about economic advantages to Australia.

I should state, just to make sure that my own view is clear, that I believe that the net economic effect of migration is of particular benefit to Australia; but the benefits are not just economic. Our refugee resettlement policy, for example, must be based on some concept of Australia's regional role and our humanitarian responsibilities. In the short term, this part of our intake cannot be justified on economic grounds, although I suspect that in the longer term we will owe as much to the Indo-Chinese refugees as we now recognise we owe to the refugees of post-World War II Europe.

Many family reunion cases have no economic justification, but become the cause of the strongest emotional and political pressure. Migrants already here want their relatives to join them, and often they are supported strongly by neighbours and workmates in approaching parliamentarians for special consideration. In other words, stronger political pressure often tends to be applied to cases with less economic justification and this is understandable. In practical terms, any Australian migration policy must maintain some balance of these elements, whatever the total intake. Certain skilled people from overseas are required on immediate employment grounds. Some family reunion cases must be permitted if the immigration policy is to have the necessary electoral support, and Australia's place in the world requires it to respond positively to the humanitarian needs of our region. Taking all these factors together, I believe that most Australians will continue to support an active immigration policy.
