TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make my main contribution to this debate, I shall deal with one of the points raised by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer); that is, the question of whether the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System makes it easier for immigration officials to judge the appropriateness of a particular person to come to Australia. In theory, it does; in fact, it does not necessarily do so. May I give one example of how it was clearly badly applied. I had representations in Sydney from a young woman from Ireland who was working here on a special permit. She worked as a specialist type of secretary in the accountancy field in a very large Australian organisation. Her one-year or two-year work permit had expired and, rather than apply for permanent residency, she was advised that if she went back to the United Kingdom or, for that matter, New Zealand and applied under NUMAS she would immediately become eligible because of her qualifications. She had a job, she had accommodation, she had money, she had a ticket to come back here, and she could speak English. Obviously she would have been selected. She was quite prepared to visit her relatives in Northern Ireland.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to be able to say that I told her that if she had any trouble she should contact me by a reverse charge call. I said that because one never knows what will happen with our Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. She went back to Northern Ireland and applied under NUMAS. Within two weeks she was rejected as unsuitable to be a migrant to Australia. This person was in the appropriate age group being aged 26. I understand the maximum points are awarded to applicants between 26 and 30 years of age. She had money, she had a flat, she had a job, she had worked here before, and she obviously fitted into the local scene. I then contacted the appropriate person in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and within a very short time this lady was admitted under NUMAS. The point I am making is that if she had not been here before and if she did not have a contact such as myself in Australia she would have been rejected and that would have been the end of the story. She would have been told, as she was told, that she was unsuitable to come to Australia.

I am pleased that we are debating this matter today. It is an important topic. I have always taken a great interest in immigration. At the same time, we have to realise that the reason we are debating this matter and the reason later today we will be debating the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's speech, a debate which commenced last November, is that this Government has no legislation available to introduce into the House. I do not consider that to be a bad thing, but the Government certainly considers it to be a bad thing. I consider it to be a good thing because I believe that most legislation falls into two categories: Either it is bad or it is unnecessary. The first category is important as far as this Government is concerned. Most of the problems with which we are dealing are caused by so-called solutions to previously perceived problems. The most obvious example is found in the health field. We must establish whether the alleged proposed changes are necessary. Previously solutions which were applied obviously did not turn out to be the correct ones. Therefore I believe that government in Australia may be better after July when this Government will face a hostile Senate and when it will no longer be necessary--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is digressing somewhat. I would like him to come back to the question before the House.
—That is the reason for this debate.
—That is not the question before the House.

—I will deal now with the demographic changes which affect us in many ways. I do not know whether I will have time to get down to specifics, but I wish to make a general statement. I believe Australia should accept immigrants to increase its population, both for selfish reasons and to help those who want to come here. I am sure this world does not believe that 14 million people in this country are entitled to occupy one of the richest continents on this earth. As population pressures and all kinds of political pressures increase in other areas people will look to this continent and say: 'We do not believe that relatively few people are entitled to occupy the whole of this continent and make decisions as to who will come to it'. At present we have the ability to make that decision. It is important that we should use that ability responsibly to allow other people to come to this country and to increase the population. The most obvious example is the United States, a country which started with a very small population and, over the last 200 to 300 years, increased its population to 220 million.

SPEECH.PARA: People who advocate zero population growth, and zero economic growth which often goes with it, are active opponents of immigration and, for that matter, active opponents of a higher birth rate. It is remarkable how often these two matters coincide. If honourable members were to look at many of the people associated with organisations such as the government funded Australian Conservation Foundation-an obvious one, although it surprises me that it is Government funded-they will find people who hate people. Basically those people oppose immigration. One gets the impression that they would like to award orders of the heroin of Australia to women who have had more than three abortions. They consider that to be a terribly impressive performance. I am one of those people who objects to such awards or titles to highly fertile mothers as was done in nazi Germany and is now done in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; mother of the order of Lenin, or whatever it may be called. As it happens I do not object to abortion as a last resort. It is the woman's own decision. I object to people who feel strongly that women should be embarrassed into feeling, when they have conceived, that they have done something wrong and, therefore, should have a termination of that pregnancy. It always surprises me that people who get terribly excited about saving the whales, seals, chickens, kangaroos, parks, or individual trees and buildings are never prepared to allow a larger population in Australia so that more human beings can have a good life. I remember the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), who was not at the time a member of this House, pointing out during an election campaign how it surprised him when driving behind cars to see on one side of the bumper a sticker which read, 'Save the whales', and on the other side a sticker which read, 'Abortion on demand'. There seems to me to be a contradiction there. Both he and I can see that contradiction but it is obvious that a large number of people cannot. It is my view that leaders of the movement opposing immigration in Australia in many cases are dishonest in their arguments. Some years ago when Australia was experiencing overemployment Paul Sharp, one of their leaders, said:
Immigration reduces our rate of economic growth per head of population, while increasing industrial unrest and social problems.
It has also tended to move us away from being a capital-intensive economy to a labour-intensive one.
He claimed:
. . . the cost of adding one extra person to the population of Sydney or Melbourne is in the vicinity of $20,000.
This was back in the early 1970s. He said further:
. . . immigration lowers the material standard of living by lowering the ratio of production capital to labour.
It does this in two ways:
It diverts our limited capital resources away from production and into areas such as housing and roads and;
It increases the number of people over which this reduced amount of capital has to be spread.

Immigration, therefore, moves us toward being a labour-intensive country with low standards of living and low rates of growth instead of toward being a capital-intensive country with high standards of living.

It is a reasonable argument. But exactly the same people-I am not suggesting Mr Sharp but the people associated with him-are now arguing exactly the opposite. They are arguing that by allowing immigrants into this country we are causing unemployment. Yet they want labour-intensive industries and want to get rid of capital-intensive industries. These people cannot see the obvious contradiction that is there. When I was preparing my contribution to this debate I could not think of a better source of reference than my submission to a national population inquiry held by Professor Borrie in about 1971. I will quote from some of the statements I made then. I said:

Whilst most thinking people must obviously support zero population growth or even minus population growth for the globe's population, this does not necessarily mean the same for Australia. Many of the ZPG arguments in Australia rest much more on value judgments about what makes for a tolerable life style than on what I would call pseudo-scientific predictions. To my mind growth-economic and population-tends to threaten traditional middle class values. It is felt to be disruptive and unpleasant precisely because it turns minority privileges into majority ones, because it means crowded roads, crowded beaches and fishing spots. It has overtones of a strong historical anxiety about being overwhelmed by Asia's population. The local ZPG movement collects the Asian-horde worriers. Recruitment in the schools is spreading, with ecological politics receiving an uncritical embrace--
I object to that very strongly-

not given to any other political movement-probably because of the combination of scientific jargon and doomsday religion. There is the theme of apocalyptic catastrophe-the threat of doom to come-and the theme of milennial hope with the promise of human perfectability, zero population growth plus a repudiation of worldly goods.
These are the sorts of people who move up to the North Coast of New South Wales. I said further:

We have the combination of complete pessimism that scientific technology could not be the saviour, with a completely unjustified optimistic faith in social technology. There is the assumption that mankind would carry out the social revolution demanded, that underdeveloped nations would not aim to reach our levels and that those in our society who already consider themselves close to subsistence level would join with the affluent in reducing their consumption.

Basically they-the ZPG and zero economic growth advocates-make one of two alternative sets of assumptions: Firstly that, broadly speaking, the global distribution of income will remain in the future as it is now or secondly, that there will be a voluntary massive redistribution of income from the rich nations to the poor. Both seem very unrealistic. The advocates of global equilibrium throw up their hands in horror at the assumption that what they consider such minor political problems as the redistribution of income among countries or within individual societies cannot be overcome under the threat of catastrophe. Suddenly it appears that although the technologists and scientists cannot solve the problems of increasing food yields, recycling raw materials or stopping pollution, politicians can square the circle by reconciling everyone to the social and economic consequences of global equilibrium. This, of course, is a nonsense assumption.

Just as growth was once seen as the magic formula, so now non-growth replaces it; one over-simplification takes over from another in a depressing dialectic of slogans. The emphasis on repudiating wordly goods is, of course, drawing on a very deep well of Western tradition. And the final irony is perhaps that what is basically a religious impulse now feels obliged to reinforce itself with scientific predictions from a computer, the 20th century version of the apocalyptic vision. But in the past the choice was seen as a personal one. It was the individual who chose to join a mendicant order of friars or give part of his income to the poor. Now, however, the choice is presented as a communal one. It is society as a whole which is expected to take a pledge of voluntary poverty, or more accurately, to abstain from enriching itself still further. And the sanction is not the traditional one of retribution in the next life but ecological catastrophe in this one; present affluence and future squalor, the contemporary version of visiting the sins of the fathers on the sons.

I would like to conclude by appealing to my fellow members of the Labor movement not to forget that worthwhile socialism is an international movement and wherever it has become highly nationalistic it has become authoritarian and, therefore, to me the very antithesis of socialism. Similarly, if socialism is about anything it is about people as individuals. We must always consider them more important than trees or private profit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in my view, should be congratulated on the provision of this excellent report entitled 'Review of Australia's Demographic Trends'. It is a very fine compilation of statistics and analyses of things that have happened and which are likely to occur in the future. In the short time that I can speak, because many members of the Opposition would like to share the time which is available, I wish to emphasise that the Opposition regards this report, previous reports and future reports, which we can reliably anticipate, as providing a basis for policy and planning. We have considerable enthusiasm about the need to plan for Australia's future in respect of employment, the needs of industry, education, social welfare and urban services. These matters have been spelt out in the report. These statistics obviously have that application, as has been conceded by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). We are on common ground in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very unlikely that if we let all the free forces go to work, fortuitously everything will fall in its place. Things just cannot be expected to happen that way. We do have a laissez-faire approach to political and economic matters in Australia. The casualties which result therefrom are very evident in the Australian community today. It is absurd to think that industries can be created in various locations around this country as a result of capital being received from overseas, that they can commence without any pre-planning and that subsequently everything will fall into place so that people can have the sewerage services, water reticulation, roads, houses and schools that they need. I think that this is one of the most important kinds of debate that can come before this Parliament.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you come from Queensland, you remind me of the dilemmas confronting us in respect of the dramatic and spasmodic development patterns that are occurring in Australia. I read only the other day that in Gladstone-a city with which you are very well acquainted, Mr Deputy Speaker-whatever the cost private enterprise might represent, infrastructure costs of some $120m are being called for by public instrumentalities following in the wake of the development of industry. The call is being directed to this Parliament-in other words, to the taxpayers of the nation. That kind of problem will be increasingly evident as time goes on.

Australia's population growth fell during the 1970s from around 2 per cent to a little above 1 per cent in 1975-76, before recovering to 1.35 per cent in 1979-80. Yet we have still had a dramatic increase. I can well remember the population around the War years and in the immediate post-war period sitting at between 7 million and 8 million. It has almost doubled in the interim period. In 1980 it reached 14.6 million. As a result of the analyses before us, we are able to anticipate a population of some 17.6 million by the year 2001. It is interesting to note that the net reproduction rate, which is referred to as the NRR, has continued to fall from 1.39 per cent to 0.92 per cent by 1979. I note a comment made in the report beside these figures that:
This is below the long-term level of replacement, 1.00.

I regard this is as alarming. It cannot be a heartening fact for any culture, any group of people, any nation, to observe its incapacity to reproduce itself. In Australia we can observe a trend of the traditional Australian families jettisoning the old values and standards. They are not thinking in terms of extended families. They are not even bothering to get married. They are not bothering to have children to the same extent. While that trend is in evidence among the traditional Australian families, I think the pattern is being disturbed by the fact that other ethnic groups are coming to Australia and maintaining standards which contributed to the greatness of our country in previous years-that is to say, those ethnic groups are having influences brought to bear by peers in the family and generally are upholding the things that they regard to be worth while. They are not throwing out the baby with the bath water, as it were. I think that traditional Australian families might have to take some stock of themselves in this regard.

We are told that the reason we are not doing so well in reproducing ourselves is due to the participation by women in the work force. That has happened. Heaven knows the extent to which it has happened and the extent to which it was sensibly planned and thought about. If women are to be employed in the work force, obviously there will be social consequences if we do not ensure that backup services for the family, such as pre-school, kindergartens, child minding and so on, exist. I think we were lackadaisical in that respect. We are told that one of the reasons is the general decline in the marriage rates. I do not know whether that is a good thing. Whether we are a little indifferent about the influences which we bring to bear on our own children is something which we should perhaps contemplate. We are told the reason is that couples are delaying having children. Undoubtedly, that is a result of the use of contraceptives. There may be beneficial and possibly some deleterious consequences also. We are told that the reason is the state of our general economic conditions-undoubtedly that has a bearing on the situation-and that there is now, among our younger people, a greater emphasis on individual freedom. I put it to the House, without having time to discuss these matters fully, that so many of these things are occurring. There are obvious trends. Too little time is given to this Parliament and to the people of the nation generally to determine the extent to which licence, encouragement and support should be given.

In the limited time that is available to me, I wish to make one or two points. I noticed that the forecast is that a much higher life expectancy rate in Australia will apply in the future. Whereas in 1947 on average males could be expected to live to 66.1 years, I am happy to say that in 1979 they were expected to live to 70.8 years. In 1947 females could be expected to survive, on average, to an age of 70.6 years. In 1979 the expectancy was 77.8 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought they wanted equality.

—Regrettably I do not have time to reply to these very stimulating interjections. We are going to see this aging of the population. There are some very interesting figures in that regard which I will not have time to cite. Some nine out of 10 Australian women will probably become widows. We must take on board here the obvious indicator that far more planning and provision of resources should occur in respect of the need to care for aging people who will be a much larger proportion of our population in the future than they have been in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to note the statistics about marriages and divorces and the fact that marriages peaked in 1971 at some 118,000 and fell steadily to 104,000 in 1979. In 1976, there was a sudden upturn in marriages. We could have all been heartened by this development to think that there was a trend in the community to revert to the traditional processes. But, if we study the figures, we learn that the 1976 upsurge is attributed to the remarriages that occurred following the very high divorce rate after the introduction of divorce reform in Australia in the early 1970s.

I think it is important to note that there is a significant shift in migration patterns in Australia and that there is a declining proportion of intake from Europe. Back in 1971-72, European-born people were 70 per cent of the intake and, by 1979-80, that proportion had dropped to 39 per cent. The main reason, of course, was the significant falls in intake from the United Kingdom, Eire and also Yugoslavia whence in an eight year period the intake had dropped from 10,700 to 1,700. There was a drop in respect of the intake of migrants from North America and Canada. There was a much higher proportion of intake from the Middle East and Oceania and especially from Asia. The increase was represented by the figures of 12 per cent of our migrant intake which came from Asia in 1971-72 and 39 per cent of our intake which came from Asia in 1976-77 reflecting, of course, the refugee problem and the like. We are told that, compared with 2.1 per cent in 1978, by the year 2008 6.8 per cent of Australians will have Asian or Middle Eastern origins. This, of course, can only have very good consequences for Australia in that we are relating in this practical and effective way to our Asian neighbours and regarding them as people with the ability to integrate effectively into the Australian community.

Let me conclude by saying that we hope these figures are available. I hope that they do not go the same way as the products of very searching inquiries such as the 1965 Vernon Committee of Economic Inquiry, the Crawford Commission to Advise on Assistance to Industry, the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry and so many others which came in their large numbers only to be pigeon-holed and to be enveloped by cobwebs and governmental indifference. What is needed in respect of this demographic forecast and the others that will follow is a continuing and ongoing process of study and analysis to determine the effects that the changes in our population will have and the way the Australian Government will need to moderate its programs to ensure the well-being of the Australian people.

There can be little doubt that there is a lot of merit in indicative planning processes. I had the privilege of introducing one of the first indicative planning processes that the Australian Government has ever been involved with and that was an indicative planning council about the housing needs of Australia. In so many parts of the world, indicative planning is now the order of the day-certainly in the East European countries and certainly in a number of West European countries, particularly in France but also in the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Belgium and many other parts of the world. People are not just wallowing in the mistakes that occur through accidental developments. They are really planning and setting out with objectives and making things happen because they can be made to happen for the benefit of the people. I hope that this report will be the subject of that continuing examination. The Government might even constitute a new authority made up of representatives of industry, government, the trade union movement, academics and the like so that we can really work out the directions which we consider will be beneficial to future Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of what the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Les Johnson) said made a lot of common sense. I remember when a year ago I attended a conference on population and development in Colombo. After listening to all the problems of the developing world as compared with the problems associated in the developed world, I started to realise that population and development will be one of the most difficult problems to be overcome to the satisfaction of all people living on this earth. At that time I thought that Australia was becoming a very selfish country when I considered that by the year 2000 we could have zero population growth. It is well known that we abort about 90,000 babies each year; yet, when we think of the number of migrants that we allow into this country and people we allow in for humanitarian reasons, we are going backwards rather than ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this Review of Australian Demographic Trends and the trends that have developed in Australia are something that we all should have a very good look at. Politicians particularly should be aware of the shift in population because we will be confronted in years to come with some mammoth problems. My friend the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), who is at the table, should realise that Tasmania, for example, is having hardly any increase in population. In fact, we are going backwards fast. We have all known that, quite apart from the few people who have stayed in Tasmania to fight for the good of Tasmania, many of our good brains have left Tasmania to develop this great Australia as we know it. Unfortunately, the shift in population has placed a very heavy responsibility on the people in Tasmania to look after the aged. We should start to realise that the problems of the aged are starting to multiply. People, particularly the ladies, are living a lot longer. They need special assistance, special help. When we have a State like Tasmania that is dependent on only a few industries, this raises some real problems. Sometimes I, the Minister and the other good colleagues from Tasmania are criticised because we start to say that they need special assistance. I think when we look at these trends and start to realise the problems in Tasmania we realise that they are a bit unique and a bit different.

At that conference in Colombo I remembered some of the facts. I stopped and thought about this great country that we have. What should we do? We have high unemployment today. We have many people from the United Kingdom who would love to come to Australia. One starts to wonder whether if they come here, it will make it even more difficult to employ the young people that we have. I remember listening to a radio program. Two people were interviewed who wanted to come to Australia, the land of milk and honey.

TALK.START.PARA: —And apples.

—And apples. They wanted to come here because they thought that jobs were readily available. They thought that they could get the best of two worlds. On listening to that program, I started to think to myself that we have unemployment running at a fairly high level, a lot of young people cannot get jobs. What should we do? Should we stop them coming into this country? We know that they are leaving a country that is depressed economically. If they come here, they will add to the problems that we have. I talk about the developed world when I talk about the United Kingdom. We have the grave problem of trying to reconcile whether we are going to look after our own with the problems that we have now with whether we should open the door up and allow other people to come to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: At the conference in Colombo, a declaration was considered. A few of the points in that declaration were interesting. One should consider them very carefully. As to the need, in the 25 years to 1975 the total world population increased from just under 2,500 million to more than 4,000 million. By the year 2000 it is expected to reach 6,200 million, of which-this is important-four-fifths will be in the developing countries with a substantial majority living in desperate poverty. So, of course, the shift has been to the developing countries and we, in a developed country such as Australia, have seen our population decrease. The implications of such increases in the developing countries are staggering. Between now and the end of the century 800 million additional jobs will have to be created. This is more than are now actively employed in the entire developed world.

Problems of similar magnitude will be posed in regard to the provision of food, water and shelter. In the developed countries the per capita consumption of resources which is so much higher than that in the developing world, has been the cause of much pollution, waste and environmental degradation. It has also contributed to world-wide shortages of key resources.

Other questions, such as the aging of the population and internal and international migration, are becoming important. At the global level, continually expanding human demands have created intolerable pressures on resources, particularly energy. The pressures on biological resources, such as fisheries, forests, grasslands and croplands, are mounting steadily and will continue to do so. Human needs have also begun to outstrip the productive capacity of many local biological systems, as currently managed. Peace itself, which is the precondition of development, will be put in jeopardy but one of the principal threats to peace is the social unrest caused by the accumulation of human fear and hopelessness.

It is also noted that forced migration and the deliberate encouragement of citizens of countries to become refugees are disruptive to the economic development and political stability of countries ill-equipped to receive them. Moreover, it is clear that we can no longer afford to limit our viewpoint just to the year 2000, which seems to be the year to which everybody looks. Unless effective action is taken now in regard to population and development, world population could continue to rise to 8,000 million or even 10,000 million. A delay of just one generation in bringing world population to a stable level implies its increasing by approximately 3,000 million.

The point that I would like to make very clearly is that in Australia we do not have the problems of the developing world. We should have a good look at what is happening in Australia. We should begin to precondition ourselves for the problems ahead. If, by the year 2000-I shall use that magical year-we are to have zero population growth, what are we going to do about it? Are we to continue to allow young babies to be aborted, to have our population diminish and the elderly increase in numbers to such a degree that the young ones coming on will not be able to assist them to the extent that we would like? These are national problems and I would like to see formed a committee to look not only at population but also at development. Population and development are inextricably bound together. We should look at them both in the context of the problems that they will pose in years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the presentation to Parliament of a periodic report on demographic trends is to be applauded. These trends are highly important in our approach to planning for governmental intervention in a variety of fields. Comparative studies and discussions in this Parliament over the last decade or so indicate just how rapidly the base on which such projections are made can change. My colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) suggested that Parliament should consider appointing a standing committee to monitor the demographic trends and their implications. Honourable members are probably aware that I believe that too many permanent standing committees of the House are a waste of manpower and facilities; that subject matter committees of short duration, dealing with specific questions and reporting on them, paying due regard to our limitations and resources, represent the most efficient approach. However, I believe these particular reviews leave unanswered so many questions having important implications that the appointment of such a standing committee would be worth while. Its main task could be to categorise the questions which arise from the reports. Parliament itself could determine those which required in-depth examination by honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: In this discussion, I can raise only a few questions. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) has commented on the projected effect of population aging on consumer demand and similar matters. I would like to go to the top end of the scale and to his comment that in the next 20 years the number of people aged 65 years and over will increase by about 70 per cent. This represents a very substantial increase indeed. Interest in the subject by honourable members would no doubt have been stimulated by today having received the paper 'Sixty-Five Not Out: Consequences of the Aging of the Australian Population' by D. T. Rowland, issued by the Institute of Public Affairs of New South Wales in February 1981. In that paper, after a deal of discussion, a number of questions are posed. However, the principal question is posed in the introduction. It is: What is the division between collective and individual responsibility? I do not believe that any honourable member so far during this debate has failed to acknowledge this question of collective and individual responsibility, which varies with the type of family structure which prevails in the community from time to time. A family structure which involves zero population growth may well produce a situation in which the elderly cannot expect support from the large family group. As a father of four, and so far grandfather of four, I could hope that under this individual responsibility concept I might be well looked after but the 65 years and over age group does have special need for continuing care in the welfare field, and in many other fields also. The Institute of Public Affairs quotation on the subject from the report of the National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry of 1976 is still pertinent. In part, it states:

We regard the distinction between subsistence and belonging as a useful characterisation of alternative sets of attitudes to social welfare policy. Support for the present austere and means-tested age pension seems to us to accord more nearly with the goal of subsistence than with the goal of belonging, whereas the emphasis of the recommended National Superannuation Scheme is the reverse.

This is not the time or place to discuss a national superannuation scheme. It does concern us that most comment on the 65 years and over age group consigns them, as if undeniably they were no longer productive, to the scrap-heap. Of course, this is arrant nonsense. One has seen, in the calling of politician, for example, many after the age of 65 years who have made substantial contributions to government. The same can be said of many other fields, such as those of science, education, arts and medicine, but we are structuring a society where there is no place for the person over 65 years to be productive. This can only result in a great loss to society. As their numbers increase the loss will be even greater-unless we break out of our present attitude and devise means to harness the accumulated wisdom and skills of years of experience for the benefit of society.

The statement provides also an opportunity to discuss the austere provision of funds for accommodation to meet the needs of this increase in the number of aged people. In the 1960s I was a member of the Victorian Parliament and had occasion to examine this problem faced by the aged. The fact is that nearly 20 years later in that State the number of names on waiting lists for geriatric institutions is just as great and the waiting time is just as long. No public institution for the aged as such has ever been built in the Melbourne metropolitan area; all the institutions have taken over buildings that were used for other purposes. The Bundoora geriatric complex was started, but building stalled through lack of finance and there is only a big hole in the ground. We have a rash of private nursing homes, but they are expensive and cannot supply the wide range of rehabilitatory and other services necessary if this increasing number of aged persons is still to have a sense of belonging in this society.

One of the major recommendations of the report was to adopt a team approach which envisaged teams for assessment and rehabilitation, in conjunction with placing emphasis on domiciliary care. Some of the comment on domiciliary care in the community is too glib and optimistic. However, the fact remains that this recommendation has not been acted upon. It provides some hope of alleviating the social effects of increases in the number of persons aged over 65 years. We are deeply conscious of the contribution made to Australia's population growth by overseas migration. This in itself adds a further dimension to the problem of belonging to society which is experienced by those over 65 years of age. Many of the immigrants who arrived in the immediate post-war years are already aged over 65 years. The number will rise. Various migrant groups have examined the problem of the aged. For example, the director of the Villagio G. Vaccari at South Morang in my electorate provided me with a copy of a report on aging in the Victorian Italian population. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) had a report of a similar nature on Yugoslavs in the Geelong area.

There are added problems for such Australians who migrated to Australia. A number of studies of their problems have been carried out. Some honourable members will recall that a number of those problems were outlined in publications such as 'The Migrant Worker', edited by Brennan and produced by the Good Neighbour Council of Victoria,and 'Towards an understanding of the Greek Immigrant' by Cox. In our society we have neither complete integration of the migrant nor the mosaic type of integration which seems to be more fashionable nowadays. The fact that the great majority of migrants, particularly those from southern Europe, were unskilled workers means that the family group has no high financial means to care for the elderly. So the true dimensions of even just welfare services is not readily known and that requires urgent present and forward planning by the Government. If the Government is to be inactive, let it say so in order that a judgment can be made.

I undertook to round off my remarks now and cut them short, but the report refers to other problems in a section which describes internal migration within Australia. People are moving from New South Wales and Victoria to Western Australia and Queensland. As all honourable members would know, the migrant intake of New South Wales and Victoria was largely urban. In the 1960s that caused many problems by placing a strain on urban services. That raises the question of whether in these other States we will face the same urban pressures, the need for an injection of Federal funds to provide health services and education services, and to meet simple needs such as providing sewerage facilities. Unless we take note of this now we may well build up a debt in years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to comment on the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), especially in view of my migrant background. The Minister's statement was intended to be general in nature in that it sought to predict Australia's population by the year 2001. Naturally, anyone attempting such excursions into futurology is likely to bring to the exercise certain presuppositions and values. I want to subject to scrutiny some of the assumptions in the Minister's statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the Minister told us that the net reproduction rate in Australia is currently 8 per cent below the replacement rate. In other words, taking into account birth and death figures and excluding immigration for the moment, Australia's population is actually shrinking. The Minister did not seem to express any concern about this trend; he stated it as a matter of fact and went on to the next item. The reason is that the Minister assumes that the problem can be dealt with through immigration policy.

It is this subject that I want to say something about. It leads me to the second assumption in the Minister's speech which needs to be more thoroughly examined. The Minister admitted that in the last 10 years immigration levels have fluctuated widely, yet at the same time he based his projections on the total level of population by the year 2000-he predicted 19.5 million people-and on the likelihood that the net gain in people through immigration will be 73,000 to 88,000 per annum. Given that the report on Australia's demographic trends recognises that over the next few years there will be an increase in the number of people leaving Australia, the Department's figures on the total population which will be achieved by the year 2000 seem to be over-optimistic. I argue that a greater increase in immigration than the Government is presently admitting will be necessary for the projected figure to be realised. I will return to this point later.

What is the philosophy which led the Government to accept the 19.5 million figure in the first place, a figure which represents an increase of five million in 20 years, including increases due to a birth rate which may, on the Minister's admissions, not be realised. I argue that the acceptance of this figure indicates an acceptance of a lower rate of growth in population than that to which we are accustomed, especially the acceptance rate of the 1950s and 1960s. The questions that arise are: What kind of a philosophy are we advocating when we seek to reduce the rate of population increase, including the increase through immigration; and what are the long term implications for the future of this nation?

Of course there are no simple answers to these questions, but I raise some of the issues involved. I begin with this question: What are the implications in social and human terms of the restrictive policies on family reunion which the Government is engaged in at present? I will cite some statistics on the present direction of family reunion policies, which I am sure will surprise at least some honourable members. In 1977-78 under the family reunion program there were 20,372 arrivals-26.9 per cent of the total arrivals. In 1978-79 there were 17,225 arrivals, 25.1 per cent of the total arrivals. In 1979-80 the figure was 18,359, or 22.6 per cent of the total arrivals, and in the period July to December 1980 there were 10,239, which was 19.5 per cent of the total arrivals. In other words, the proportion of arrivals under the family reunion program is rapidly decreasing. We have to ask ourselves what is the reason for this substantial reduction in family reunions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an increase in real terms; a decrease in proportion.

—There may be a marginal increase in real terms, but in relation to the overall proportion it is still very inadequate. There has been a reduction in the proportion of people coming to Australia in family reunion programs yet, as every member of Parliament knows, there is strong pressure from many immigrants to have their brothers, sisters, cousins and other close relatives brought to Australia. The enormous social and emotional costs of separation of families must surely have been brought to the notice of every honourable member and of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs many times. We have a moral obligation to respond to the heartbreak created for these families. The Australian Labor Party advocates an immediate extension to the family reunion program and an immediate relaxation of criteria for families to come and live together in this country. This extension would be at little cost and often of great benefit to the Australian community, for when people arrive on family reunion programs they have support groups around them to help them become established and to take their place in our society. The Government should act with foresight and vision on this matter and help rather than hinder the process of reuniting families. I add as a footnote to that point that I have been informed that no statistics are kept which show what proportion of immigration applications are made in the family reunion category and are rejected. It is time we found that out.
—It is a great proportion, I can tell you. I get them in my office.

—The honourable member for Hotham said that it is a great proportion. I agree with him. Another question we need to ask when giving overall consideration to population policy is whether we have a moral obligation towards the hundreds of thousands of refugees in many countries. I believe that, as a young and growing country, we have a very substantial obligation to help as many of these people as we can to come and live here. This does not mean that I agree with the current Government policy on refugees, which has been very discriminatory. There has been much action in favour of Vietnamese and Kampuchean refugees, to the virtual exclusion of those from many other countries.
—There are no Lebanese, either.

—In particular, refugees from Middle Eastern countries-especially Lebanon-and from Latin America and Africa seem to be discriminated against. We need to move towards a more responsive, fairer and more humane refugee policy which does not discriminate on the basis of political beliefs. Certainly that seems to be the basis of the present policy. Probably many honourable members will object to increased immigration on the ground that the current economic situation in this nation, especially the unemployment crisis, does not permit it. I have sympathy with this argument; of course we must take account of economic factors in any judgment on immigration and population. However, we must not, as unfortunately some do, seek to blame immigration and immigrants for our economic problems. Nor should we see these economic problems as inevitable, with the attitude that we can do nothing about them. Rather, we should see them as a consequence of the policies of governments, especially the policies of the present Federal Government. There is nothing sadder than the fact that the policies of the current Government on unemployment, which have resulted in the present level of unemployment, have severely restricted our room to manoeuvre on immigration and population policies. Indeed, if the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) is as concerned as he maintains about population trends, then he should pressure his Government more for a change in economic policy so that we can afford to be more generous to those people who are keen to come to this land and make their contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not let the temporary economic trends created by this Government cloud our vision on this matter. When the Labor Party returns to government in 1983, it will restore normal economic circumstances and it will increase dramatically employment in the economy and provide the circumstances for genuine growth, especially in the public and manufacturing sectors. This will open up opportunities for us to take a bold and imaginative view towards immigration policy. A point often made on the relationship of economic factors with immigration policy is that during the period of highest immigration to this country we had the greatest growth in the economy. That is because immigration helps to contribute to the overall health of the economy. That factor has to be taken into account when we make an overall estimation of the relationship between our immigration and economic policies. As the Minister has acknowledged, without further immigration our population will shrink. We need to adopt as a matter of principle a renewal of an immigration program similar to that which we had in earlier times. We need to ensure that we create economic circumstances which will allow us to implement that program and to help increase the population growth of this nation from below the zero level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to confine my comments on the Review of Australia's Demographic Trends to two aspects. The first deals with the aging of the Australian population. Of course, this is relevant to all areas of Australia but page 10 of the report highlights the particular problem of the Australian Capital Territory. It says that in the Australian Capital Territory there has been a greater rate of increase in the proportion of the population aged over 65 years than elsewhere in Australia. Demographic trends towards an aging population will have enormous implications for the provision of care for the aged. We can now expect that at least 55 per cent of males and 73 per cent of females will attain the age of 70 years.

SPEECH.PARA: This means that a higher proportion of Australian families will have aged relatives to care for, and Government policies towards the aged do not encourage their independence because the age pension is a miserly amount, representing only about 20 per cent of average weekly earnings. Therefore, most pensioners are forced to rely on their families for assistance with accommodation, transport and social activities and to spend a great deal of their time trapped in their homes because they do not have sufficient facilities. This appalling state of affairs was demonstrated in the Australian Capital Territory recently when there was an increase of 66 per cent in bus fares for pensioners. That may not seem a great deal to people on normal incomes but it makes substantial inroads into the weekly allowance of pensioners, many of whom are living below the poverty line. The current pension levels are insufficient to provide age pensioners with comfortable and relaxed lifestyles, which is their right after a lifetime of contributions to Australia's development. They are forced into a dependent situation which leads to loss of dignity for them and for their relatives. It is time for this Government to give elderly citizens a fair go and to stop treating them as second class citizens.

At present, insufficient policies and funds are directed towards the aged and, as the Australian population ages further during this century, the needs of our aging population will increase. Demographic factors alone will necessitate a much greater expenditure for the aged, but if we are also to include the need for humane and compassionate policies, we will have to re-think seriously the rationale for current policies towards the aged. There is no doubt that the costs of providing for the aged in Australia must escalate in the future. We must ensure than any increases in pensions represent real advances in relation to prevailing living standards and that the position of our pensioners does not fall further and further below the poverty line. Providing subsistence funding for our pensioners is not good enough. Our goal should be to enhance and extend the lives of our elderly citizens, to allow them to belong more fully to our society without being dependent on their relatives for support. For the remainder of this century there will be a relatively small elderly population compared with the number of people working, but it is clear from this paper that the economic dependency ratio will deteriorate next century, causing severe problems in the financing of welfare benefits for the aged. The next two decades will give us a brief respite when I hope that we can accumulate funds and develop strategies for dealing with this issue. This demographic paper illustrates quite clearly the grave problems facing governments in the provision of and funding for the care of elderly citizens in a climate where the population is aging and where there are fewer working people to support them. This matter deserves our serious consideration if Australia is to continue to provide adequately for its citizens.

I wish to refer very briefly to another aspect of the report. Table 2 on page 11 of this report highlights the sudden decline in the rate of population growth in the Australian Capital Territory. By looking at that chart, it can be seen that the decline was from an increase of 6.51 per cent in the population in 1975 to a sudden drop of 2.41 per cent in 1976. This proved to be too much, too soon. Obviously the drop was caused by direct government policy. As we all know that had a dramatic effect on industry in Canberra leading to a very high unemployment, a massive increase in bankruptcies, empty schools and a loss of faith in the future of Canberra. No other State or Territory, with the exception of the Northern Territory, whose sharp decline in population growth can be attributed to Cyclone Tracy, had anything like such a decline. Their greatest decline was about 0.4 per cent. We have already seen the dramatic effect caused by such a decline. I think that this should be a clear warning to the Government and to Opposition parties to ensure that this does not happen again in 1988 when the Federal Government completes the new and permanent parliament house project. Every other State and Territory has steady population fluctuations and it is only fair and reasonable to expect that the Australian Capital Territory should have a long term plan based on steady population variations rather than on the massive variations since 1976. That is the only environment in which Canberra can prosper and in which its citizens can have a secure future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper on Australia's demographic trends has a number of major themes which I want to refer to briefly. Firstly, I think that essentially it suggests that the doubling or the rate of increase in the population which we have seen in the post-War period is likely to continue to the turn of the century. So we have the revision of the Borrie estimates upwards and the estimate that, given increased levels of migration from those levels which persisted in the 1970s, the overall population is likely to reach about 20 million by the turn of the century. Secondly, there will be further and significant changes in the compositon of the population, with the most dramatic changes being to the age structure of the population as well as changes in relation to the ethnic composition of the population, particularly as a result of the vastly increased rate of migration from South East Asia. This movement of population from South East Asia will result in a situation in which a very significant proportion of the Australian population will either be of Middle Eastern or Asian origin by the turn of the century. Thirdly, the sharp decline in net reproduction rates, which occurred during the 1970s, is likely to be a continuing characteristic; that is, we are not likely to achieve very much over one per cent net reproduction rates through to the turn of the century.

SPEECH.PARA: The historic distribution of Australia's population, particularly in terms of urbanisation, is likely to be a continuing characteristic of the distribution of the Australian population through to the turn of the century. Eighty per cent of the population lives in coastal areas. The report reminds us that 65 per cent live in major urban areas of over 100,000 people; and 60 per cent live in the great conurbations associated with Sydney, Newcastle and Port Kembla in New South Wales and Melbourne and Geelong in Victoria. No other country has as high a degree of urbanisation as Australia. The changing distribution of the population between the States is not likely to alter this fact. People will still live on the coast. Generally they will still live in large cities. The vast majority of the population will live not only in large cities but also in the metropolitan areas such as Sydney and Melbourne.

This report raises a number of issues. I have just received a message which indicates that I have very little time to canvass any of them. I would like to make one more point, which I think is fundamental, and perhaps conclude my remarks. This report suggests that any increase in the Australian population over the next 20 years is going to occur very largely as a result of migration. If we look at the migration policy which we have historically adopted in the post-War period, we will see that the reasons for that policy were national security, independence and economic development. The reason for that policy has not been due particularly to social goals and it has not been relevant particularly to any assessment of the kind of society that we have wanted to create. It has not had a kind of value base. Whilst we adopted very recently the idea of multiculturalism, we did not set out in the 1940s to create a multicultural society. Rather, we set out to build up the population because we thought that it would give this country a much more secure society. I believe that as a result of that process, our society has become a very complex one and that built into it there are very serious strains and tensions.

Given the levels of growth that this report suggests and given the new complexity which will be introduced by having a very much higher proportion of the population drawn from Asia-a fact which I welcome-another dimension will be added to make what is already a very complicated population structure even more so. Whilst in the post-War period we have not had violence associated with our migration program and the signs of tension have been very much under the surface, I believe that we can expect that those tensions will grow in the future unless we learn from our experience of that period. I think that experience would suggest that migration brings with it very great costs which need to be addressed. I believe that, as a society, we have not really faced up to these costs and been prepared to commit that expenditure. It is very easy to talk about Australian society as if it is united as one. If one looks at the reality, we are in fact a society which is very divided, particularly along class lines. If one looks at the working class areas of this country, one finds that migration has not been addressed socially in the way it might have been.

I believe that, if we are genuinely to move towards a multicultural society, there is no more important question than the question of language; there is no more important issue in this country than that of bilingual education. In the past we have not taken seriously in terms of education the languages of the people who have come to this country and there is no sign that we intend to take Asian languages seriously in the future. I believe that this issue of language, given the complexity of our society, is more important perhaps than any other single issue. I regret that, as a Parliament, we have not devoted ourselves to the question of bilingual education. I would hope that, if we are to continue to develop as a multicultural society, the question of the teaching of community languages will be taken much more seriously in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure this afternoon in entering the Address-in-Reply debate and supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). Five months ago today, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) delivered his policy speech at the opening of the 1980 Federal election campaign. The Prime Minister said on that date in the introduction to his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: Today, a new spirit, a new enthusiasm, a new dynamism, is at work in Australia.

It is amazing to see how hollow those words ring five months after the date of delivery. Since this Government came to office, we have seen an assault on the Australian people the like of which we have not seen for many, many years. Since the delivery of the Prime Minister's high sounding words, the living standards of Australian families have declined markedly.

The ideal of home ownership, which is something dear to the hearts of all Australians, has been virtually put out of the mind of any young person living in the city of Sydney and in most of the capital cities of our country. Interest rates have increased rapidly under this Government. In fact, at present they are more than two per cent higher than the level pledged in the Prime Minister's policy speech only five months ago. One wonders at what level interest rates will be when this Government goes out of office in 1983. Will Australians be able to afford the Fraser Government for much longer? We have seen health costs spiral. The report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, which was set up by this Government, recommends a significant curtailment of health programs which are provided to Australians at present. We are watching the Government take the last hatchet to what is left of Medibank which was probably one of the greatest social reforms ever instituted by a government in this country. I am very proud to say that this reform was instituted by an Australian Labor Party government. Many people in my electorate would face incred- ible financial hardships if there were any further changes to Medibank.

Whilst the Prime Minister has done all those things-whilst he has destroyed Medibank, whilst he has destroyed the chance of Australians to purchase their own home and whilst he has taken away any of the benefits that people can gain through hard work-he has the hide to say that while achieving all this we have enchanced the dignity and self-esteem of those in need. My goodness, if that is the way a government tries to enhance the dignity and self-esteem of those in need, I would hate to see what would happen if this Government took the stick to them. We are approaching the same sort of rationale under this Government that we see in America at present. This morning's edition of the Sydney Morning Herald contains an interview with the Director of the White House Office of Management and the Budget in the Reagan Administration. When asked by a reporter from the Sydney Morning Herald what rights people had for services from government he said that they had absolutely no rights. He said that the idea of people having a right to some sort of service from government was absolutely absurd. That is the sort of attitude that the Fraser Government is approaching in Australia. How long will it be before all the programs that governments have provided as a safety net for the needy of this country are dismantled by the government that is in power in our country today?

Between 1972 and 1975, some real changes were achieved in the attitudes of Australians, as well as the attitude of government, towards those who were not as well off as others were. Australians have been made to go back into their shells and that to my mind is the most insidious effect that this Government has had on Australians. This Government has made the middle class take a certain approach to people who are less able to fend for themselves and say: 'If they are not doing as well as I am, bad luck for them'. I think that is a deplorable state of affairs; I think that attitude which is abroad in our country today is deplorable.

Earlier this afternoon, a number of honourable members debated a paper on a Review of Australias Demographic Trends and a statement made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). One of the most significant features to come out of that review is the rapidly aging factor in the Australian population. We are the most rapidly aging population in the world. This Government does not have any proposals or policies to deal with that development. It now has the facts and the figures before it and it cannot shirk its responsibility. It must come up with a co-ordinated policy for the aged. Rather than having a co-ordinated policy, the present Government unfortunately has found ways to tax the meagre earnings of pensioners who the Department of Social Security says can earn $20 a week without affecting their pension fringe benefits. The Government has found ways to tax pensioners who wish to put some money away to pay for their funerals. I wish that some Ministers would take some cognisance of the absolute fear that many old people have of not being able to afford the high cost of burying themselves. At present the minimum cost in Australia of a burial is $2,000. However, the Government taxes the interest earned if a pensioner has that much money to put in a bank.

In recent weeks, one of the most humane members of the Government backbench put forward a plan which may help some pensioners who have some money. Unfortunately the plan does nothing for the poor. The honourable member for Barton (Mr Bradfield) has put forward a plan which he says the Government is seriously considering. His plan would allow pensioners to invest in government savings bonds and the interest earned would not be subject to taxation or affect the level of pension benefits. That might be a reasonable plan for those who have money. I suppose most of the pensioners in the honourable member for Barton's electorate do have a fair amount of money. Unfortunately, the people in my electorate do not have much money and they can try to supplement their income by small earnings only. The Government has said that it has nothing of any interest to offer to those people at all. In fact when recently I put to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the Parliament that the Government should review the taxation situation with respect to pensioners prior to the Budget and introduce retrospective legislation, the Treasurer said: 'Well, that does not matter; we will look at this matter when the Budget is brought down'. What will happen is that in June of this year any pensioner in Australia who earns the $20 a week that the Department of Social Security says he may earn and not affect his pension fringe benefits will get a bill for $100 from the Commissioner of Taxation. Most of those people will not be able to find that money and it will cause them much grief and pain. Of course, the Government has nothing to say for those people. The Government has no policy on nursing homes or the provision of domiciliary care for aged people. All it says is that it will provide more nursing homes for private entrepreneurs to get rich. I have pointed out in this Parliament on a number of occasions the great rip-offs that are occurring in private nursing homes. The Government is willing to provide about $200 a week to keep a person in a private nursing home, but if one wants to keep one's aged relations at home, all the Government allows is less than $30 a week as domiciliary nursing care benefit. Where are the Government's priorities? As was said in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, this Government's policies are very much the same as those of the Reagan Administration in America; its policies are to soak the poor and feed the rich.
In his rather amazing policy statement aired five months ago, the Prime Minister also had something to say about Australia's international affairs. He said:
And, under the Fraser-Anthony Government, Australia has won a respected place in world affairs.

Let us look at the record of this Government in international affairs. We have seen the fiasco of the Prime Minister's stance over Afghanistan; we have seen his bullying of and attempts to stand over Australian athletes who wanted to go to the Olympic Games in Moscow. He has seen that his policy on Afghanistan was absolutely incorrect. The line he took had absolutely no relevance to modern international affairs, and the Prime Minister was shown to be one of the few people stepping down the lane with the Americans on that proposal. Once again we see the Prime Minister posturing on the international stage. We are to go all the way with the United States in relation to El Salvador.

I believe that Australians should have defence ties with the Americans and that our ties with the Western allies are important to our survival in the world. However, I do not believe that an ally is a good ally only if he is critical when there is need for criticism. To my mind the present perceived policies of the American Administration regarding El Salvador are absolutely ridiculous. When a government goes to the extent of propping up a dictatorship that it says is anti-communist just because it alleges it is anti-communist it is a ridiculous situation, particularly when the same government shoots to death, in the cathedral of San Salvador, the Catholic Archbishop of that country. I do not know how anti-communist one has to be to shoot Catholic Archbishops, only to find the American Government saying that that gives one some sort of seal of approval.

I should think that the solution in El Salvador would be to provide for great land reform in that country. I commend to any member of this Parliament who wants to see a somewhat unbiased view of the situation in that country the recent 60 Minutes television program by George Negus. I think that that is incontrovertible evidence that there are great inequities in El Salvador and that a government cannot be propped up by military force alone, that there must be some sort of social justice in El Salvador. It would be much better for the Australian Government if it took the view that it would support a social justice line in that country rather than just being willing to give mealy-mouth support to a rather corrupt extreme right wing dictatorship which does not have the support of anyone in the country with the exception of the 14 or 15 families that own most of the assets of the country.

Finally, the Prime Minister said in his policy speech that business expectations are high. The Prime Minister may have thought that they were high five months ago, but since the campaign he has waged against the unions over the last five months, I think even the business community in Australia is willing to give away these industrial hatchet men. We had the ridiculous situation in this Parliament some weeks ago of the Government bringing in a motion to disallow a determination of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which was a rather hypocritical approach from a government which has always said that people should obey the decision of the umpire. As a sideline, it was very interesting to note that, while that debate was in progress, the industrial relations spokesman for my party was wearing a Victorian Umpires Federation tie. It was interesting to see the shoe on the other foot. The Opposition is willing to support the decision of the umpire, but the Government will support the decision of the umpire only when it suits it.

In the few minutes remaining to me, I should like to say a few things about my electorate, in particular about Sydney airport. I am pleased that the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), who represents the seat of Farrer, is the Minister at the table. I know that on a number of occasions the Minister for Education has acted as Minister for Transport. It would seem that his expertise in transport has not washed off to a gentleman by the name of Schipp, who masquerades from time to time as the Opposition's spokesman on Transport in the New South Wales Parliament.

In the Sydney Daily Mirror of 30 March 1981-yesterday-Mr Schipp had a rather amazing article headed 'Airport delay causing jams'. I think the Minister for Education should take Mr Schipp aside and either write his speeches and articles for him or tell him a little about Commonwealth responsibility. In his article, Mr Schipp says:
After all, it is principally a State decision . . .
That is, to decide on the site of a second airport-
and that responsibility cannot be ducked.

Mr Schipp ought to know-if he does not know, the Minister for Education, who has acted as Minister for Transport on a number of occasions, should point out to him-that the Commonweath Government has responsibility for civil aviation in this country, and that the decision about when and where anything will be done to the Sydney Airport is a matter for the Commonwealth Government. It is not a matter for the New South Wales Government. In my view the Commonwealth Government should accept its responsibility. It may be that what Mr Schipp was saying really relates to the Commonwealth Government. It should accept its responsibility and make a decision about Sydney Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Commonwealth Parliament, what do you think we should do about it?

—I have made my position quite clear. The Minister, I think, is a little more intelligent than Mr Schipp. He can read some of my speeches and find out what I have said, but obviously Mr Schipp does not know what he is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned about a number of proposals which have been floated by supporters of the Government about what will or will not happen to Sydney Airport. An inspired editorial in the Daily Telegraph of Tuesday, 24 March had a lot to say about the curfew at Sydney Airport. As the Minister is concerned to know what other people know and think about it, I should like to know what is this Government's attitude to the removal of the curfew at Sydney Airport. I am concerned that there are far too many supporters of the Government who are saying at present that we ought to get more traffic into Sydney Airport and the only way in which to do that is by removing the curfew. To my mind, the worst thing that could happen at Sydney Airport would be the removal of the curfew. The people who live around the airport probably bought their houses long before the airport was anything like it is at present. Many of them bought their houses there before the international airport was extended to where it is presently. They have a terrible noise problem with that airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us how to overcome the problem.

—What is the Government going to do about the curfew? Will it take it off? It will try. It has been caught out on this matter. The Government should make an unequivocal statement that there will be no attempt to remove the curfew at Sydney airport and that there will be no attempt to cause more hardship to the people who live under the flight path and who in the main live in my electorate and the surrounding electorates. I would like to hear the opinion of the right honourable member for Lowe (Sir William McMahon), who never makes a statement about Sydney airport. The flight path runs right over his electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I should like to make two comments on matters relating to the portfolio of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). I am concerned, and I have written to the Minister about this recently, that the Government's proposals for quotas for immigration into this country in 1980-81 provide for a quota of only 2,500 people to come to Australia from the Middle East. My electorate has an extremely large number of people who have come to Australia from the Middle East in the last 10 years. In the main these people have made excellent migrants to this country. They have involved themselves in the life of my electorate and have brought up families which fit in extremely well with Australian society. I think the proposal to allow only 2,500 migrants of a total quota of about 80,000 to come to Australia from the Middle East needs to be reconsidered. There are many people who would like to sponsor relations to come here from the Middle East. There are many people in my electorate who have good and cogent reasons for needing to have members of their families in the Middle East join them.

The Government has a commendable program for refugee resettlement in this country. However, I think it should seriously consider the position of refugees from the Middle East. If those people living in the camps in Cambodia are in great strife-as I believe they are-then those people living in the civil war situation in the Lebanon are in even worse straits. The Government should take a more humane attitude to those people. It should allow the same immigration and refugee status to migrants from the Middle East as was allowed in the latter 1970s. Those people should be allowed to seek a haven in this great country of ours. Their compatriots have shown that they make excellent citizens of this country. A higher percentage of Middle Eastern people takes out Australian citizenship than do many other migrant groups in Australia. They should be encouraged. The paltry figure of 2,500 migrants for this year should be reviewed. I hope the Minister will sympathetically review that situation. Finally, I thank the House for its courtesy. I believe the Government should have a look at the Prime Minister's policy speech once again to see how badly he has failed to live up to any of the points he put forward to the Australian electorate. If any of the High Court challenges on unfair electoral advertising had been upheld it would have been interesting to see whether that document would have got into court. In my view it is one of the greatest shams we have seen in this country for many years.
Sitting suspended from 6.2 to 8 p.m.
