SPEECH.PARA: The results of the by-election were somewhat gratifying to the Liberal Party. Those results were unexpected by some commentators and some Liberal Party members in the local electorate. They showed a reversal of the normal trend against a government and, in fact, a reversal against the Labor Party. It was gratifying to find that support for the Labor Party declined by about 3 per cent. It was a most unusual result. It needs a great deal of conjecture to arrive at its cause. I remember travelling through the electorate one day during the election campaign with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peacock). We went into the front bar of one of the local hotels. We found that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) had been there the previous day. The person telling us of his visit said that he had been on the wagon and was drinking Claytons tonic. The Minister for Industrial Relations looked at him and quickly said: 'Claytons, that is the drink you are having when you are not having a drink. The Leader of the Opposition, that is the leader you are having when you don't want a leader'. Perhaps that summed up the voters' views in the electorate of Boothby.

After the election we tended to believe that perhaps the result was due to the lack of leadership qualities displayed by the Leader of the Opposition until, of course, we looked more deeply at the Labor Party and understood the divisions within it and the confusion which is now recognised by the general public. I will refer to several documents which show quite clearly that there are deep divisions within the Labor Party. Recently the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, Mr Bannon, put his toe in the water again with a pro-uranium stance. He started to elucidate a program in South Australia for the Labor Party by saying that uranium was now safe to mine. He was soon brought back to earth. An article in the Advertiser stated:

However, the criticisms have resurfaced following Mr Bannon's statements to a meeting of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Society that the ALP should make an objective examination of its uranium policy and that it was now possible that mining of uranium could be placed in the 'safe category'.

Supporters of the ALP's anti-uranium policy have been alarmed further by the views expressed by the Opposition spokesman on the environment, Dr Cornwall, that the stage has been reached where it is relatively safe to mine, process and enrich uranium.
It was soon pointed out by the incoming President of the United Trades and Labor Council that all sub-branches and unions would consider similar motions. He said:
We believe that the policy of the party is clear and the only place this policy could be changed is the party convention.

The contrast in those attitudes resembles the confusion at the federal level when last October the Leader of the Opposition tended to take the same pro-uranium stance. The honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) soon brought him back to earth. He said:
Only the whole of the Labor party at all levels can make that decision through the decision-making processes of the party.
That is where it will be judged whether the nuclear industry is guilty or innocent.
Individuals cannot decide whether the problems are resolved. A Labor Cabinet cannot make that decision. The Labor caucus cannot make that decision.

Those types of divisions, running deeply within the Labor Party, on one of the most important issues in the community are the basis for its loss of support. I am alarmed, however, that the new honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) made some accusations against the South Australian Government in relation to the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories, known as AMDEL, at Thebarton. He accused the Government of covering up reports on the uranium industry. He said in this House that the South Australian Government had endeavoured to cover up and bury a report on the health hazards associated with AMDEL. He said:
Fortunately, there were public servants who had enough conscience to make sure that the report got out.

I was able to get a copy of the reply given by the State Minister of Mines and Energy in the South Australian House of Assembly. After repeating the statement made by the honourable member for Hindmarsh he said:
That is patently untrue. The report was made available, as is the policy of the Health Commission, to the unions involved as a matter of course.
There was no way in which that report could be secret. It was made available to the PSA and another union was concerned although I forget its name . . .
There was no attempt to cover it up and Mr Scott's suggestion that it had been leaked by public servants and commending them for it is a reflection on their integrity.
The claims and charges of the honourable member for Hindmarsh are utterly baseless. They reflect on him, not the South Australian Government.

This evening I want to mention a subject which is of great importance to South Australia. I hope the House will excuse me if I am somewhat parochial in my remarks. It concerns an area in which South Australia has been treated unjustly for many years. It ought not to have been treated in this way. I refer to the allocation of the Federal road grants and their distribution among the various States. South Australia has received a very poor allocation in the last decade. In 1969, in another capacity, I attended a roads conference in Canberra. It was held in this chamber. Allocations were made to the various States. Mr Gorton was then Prime Minister. South Australia received a very bad allocation. It was an allocation which the local Dunstan Government and all subsequent Federal governments have been pleased to continue. The allocation is the basis of unjust treatment of my State and I will deal with it in some detail.

Firstly, I refer to the cut-up of funds in 1969 by Mr Gorton when he was Prime Minister. One might have thought that with the divisions between the political parties being what they are the new federal Labor Government would have rectified the position, particularly as South Australia had a Labor Government. That was not so. When the new Labor Government was forming its policies on roads the expert advice was again presented by the Bureau of Roads to the Commonwealth Government on the allocation among the various States. I draw comparisons with Western Australia, in particular, and sometimes with Queensland. In 1973 the recommendation of the Federal Government's expert body, the Bureau of Roads, was that South Australia should receive 77 per cent in money terms of the amount that Western Australia received. In a speech introducing the Bill on 18 July 1974 the then Minister for Transport, Mr Jones, announced that the allocation for South Australia would be $100m and for Western Australia $150m. South Australia received the same proportion, two-thirds, which it had received under the previous Gorton arrangement. When the Labor Government came into office, for comparative purposes, it did nothing but continue and, in fact, increase the disparity between South Australia and the other States. The tables and graph show that in 1968-69 South Australia received 11.1 per cent of the total road funds granted to all the States in Australia. In 1980-81, it received 8.5 per cent of the Funds. The progression downwards since 1969 has almost been a straight-line graph of reduction. It is no wonder that Western Australia with its road construction teams, was able to reach the Western Australian/South Australian border before South Australia could complete its share of the Eyre Highway. This disability by South Australia was brought about by the disastrous Gorton decision and the meek acceptance, as I have said, by the South Australian Government of that false base in later years. We now suffer one of the most inequitable and unfair cut-ups of Commonwealth funds that have existed since Federation. It has been, and exists today as deliberate discrimination as a matter of government policy against the South Australian people and the States economy. We resent that for these comparative reasons. I make these comparisons without any ire or without wishing to reduce the funds allocated to other States. I use these comparisons with Western Australia and Queensland because they are the other two mainland States which are in our type of road situation, as distinct from Victoria and New South Wales.

If we refer to the funds which are allocated, for example in 1974-75, we find that South Australia received 53.2 per cent of Western Australia's Commonwealth road grants. Yet on a self-help basis-the amount spent by our State and local government authorities, compared with the amount spent by State and local government in Western Australia-we accomplished 93 per cent of what Western Australia accomplished. Yet we received 53.2 per cent of what Western Australia received in Commonwealth grants. In 1978-79-another four years on-we received 65.3 per cent of what Western Australia received in road grants, yet our self-help position was 78.8 per cent of the self-help that Western Australia was able to provide. That is the position on a per vehicle basis. If we turn to a per capita basis we find that for that same two-year comparative period, we received 57.4 per cent in 1974-75 of Western Australian funds, yet we exactly equalled that State when it came to self-help in State and local government expenditures. On a per capita basis, in 1978-79 we received 60.7 per cent of Western Australian funds and our self-help relationship was 74.7 per cent.

If we compare South Australia with Queensland for those same years, we find that on a per vehicle basis for 1974-75 we received 58 per cent of what Queensland received, yet our self-help amounted to 73.7 per cent. In 1978-79 we received 59.6 per cent of what Queensland received in the form of Commonwealth road grants and our self-help component was 73.5 per cent. On a per capita basis for 1974-75, in comparison with Queensland we received 64.2 per cent. Our self-help amounted to 81.1 per cent. In 1978-79 we received 64.1 per cent and our self-help was 79 per cent. The figures may be boring but they are incontestable. There are plenty more of them.

If we look at the estimates for vehicle kilometres of travel on a State by State comparison basis, we find that in 1975, 8,734,000 vehicle kilometres were travelled in South Australia and in Western Australia the figure was 8,743,000. The estimates for 1980 show South Australia as having 11,355,000 vehicle kilometres travelled and Western Australia as having 11,775,000. The estimate for 1985 is 13,753,000 and 15,251,000 respectively. Comparing those figures on a percentage basis, the figures are 99.8 per cent, 96 per cent and 90 per cent. If one turns to the comparison of motor vehicles per thousand of population, one will see that in 1974, South Australia had a total of 464 vehicles per thousand of population and Western Australia had 466. In 1979 the figures were 504 and 542. The estimate for 1984 shows South Australia as having 535 and Western Australia 615. It is estimated that in 1989 South Australia, will have 691 vehicles per thousand of population compared with 680 vehicles per thousand of population in Western Australia. Forecasts of average annual kilometres per vehicle show the same position. The forecast indicates that by 1990 we should be almost equal with Western Australia. Forecasts of motor vehicles on the register show that for the year 1979 South Australia had 651,000 and Western Australia had 650,000. The forecast for 1984 indicates the figures to be 727,000 and 799,000 respectively. For the year 1989 the figure is estimated at 864,000 in South Australia and 969,000 in Western Australia.

I have a table which indicates the amount of money that the South Australian Government, through its Highways Department, has spent on national highways. How do we eventually meet up with Western Australia's Eyre Highway which is bitumenised to the West Australian border? We meet up with it by spending State funds, not by spending the money which we ought to have received from the Commonwealth Government in the discriminatory grants which are being made to my State. Over the years from 1974-75 to 1980-81 we spent $29.1m on those national highways. In 1976-77 $9.1m was spent on finishing the Eyre Highway. It is disgraceful for the Commonwealth to sustain that low figure which we now obtain. The situation is worse than that. I invite honourable members to look at the amounts that are repaid to the States in comparison with the fuel taxes which are collected. In 1977-78, Queensland supplied $139m in fuel tax. It received 71.9 per cent of that back in grants. South Australia supplied $82m and received 48.8 per cent back in grants. Western Australia supplied $102m and received 59.8 per cent back in grants.

The only consideration that emerges from those figures is that South Australian motorists are subsidising Western Australian and Queensland motorists by the fuel tax that they pay. This is a disgraceful situation. In addition to that, the States of South Australia, Victoria, and Western Australia have now brought in, under the business franchise legislation, taxes on fuel which will yield $20m to South Australia in 1980-81. Whilst Western Australia is also involved in that, Queensland is not. Therefore, the per capita and per vehicle comparisons with Queensland will be much worse than I indicated a short while ago. The warranted or justified road program for the years 1979-80 to 1983-84, as presented to the Minister by the Bureau of Transport Economics, has recommended that South Australia should complete in that period of five years 94.8 per cent of Western Australia's program. Yet if we are to proceed with these inequitable votes, we will receive 66 per cent of Western Australia's vote. I want to know why. What discriminatory measures, attitudes and activities have acted against my State over the last 10 years-as carried on by the Labor Government when in office; meekly complied with by the Dunstan Government-to allow the situation to continue in this way?

We are facing a new decision in the next few weeks. The remaining four years of the current five-year program will be allocated between the States. I want the Minister to stop what amounts to a rip-off of the South Australian motorist. As I have said, South Australian motorists are subsidising motorists in other States. We want to be treated as Australian citizens and not as citizens of a colonial outpost which is not yet admitted to the federation. The Minister is a clean skin in this matter. He has had nothing to do with these past events, this discrimination and this attitude against South Australia. I put it to him: He can be the first Minister in a decade to put right what is one of the greatest wrongs in administration federally of funds disbursed under this or any other government in that decade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to that conglomeration of thoughts by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) in which he slandered Australian Labor Party and Liberal ex-Prime Ministers, it is not difficult to understand why he lost his seat easily and also lost government in South Australian to the Australian Labor Party. If he continues in that fashion, I think he will even lose his seat for the Liberal Party. All the honourable member did was slander the Liberal Party and tell us how good Don Dunstan was in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on being elected to your high office. I ask you to pass on my congratulations to the Speaker and to all the other Deputy Speakers. I congratulate all honourable members on being returned or elected to this Parliament and all those honourable members who have made maiden speeches. I have enjoyed their speeches.

In his opening address to the assembly of the thirty-second Parliament, the Governor-General referred to the theme on which I am about to expand-the International Year of Disabled Persons. We were told on that occasion:

These policies are designed to work for the well-being of all Australians and to develop a society which maximises the rewards of individual effort and initiative, and which also respects the right of individuals to shape their own lives.
Under the heading 'Caring for People', the Governor-General went on:

In what I have said about unemployment, youth and the economy, I have stressed my Government's concern with the human dimensions of the issues involved. It believes that the only legitimate yardstick for assessing any policy is not conformity to an ideology, not the strengthening of the state, but the effectiveness of that policy in enhancing the lives of people. This is the fundamental concern of my Government.
He continued:

It is evident in the programs developed in the context of the International Year of Disabled Persons 1981 to assist the education of severely handicapped children and to increase employment opportunities for the disabled.

The International Year of Disabled Persons seems destined to enjoy short-lived prominence in our day to day affairs. With almost one-quarter of this year behind us, we find that this present Government has yet to initiate fundamental or far-reaching legislative changes in order to break down the barriers between the disabled and the non-disabled in our community. It will be extremely regrettable-indeed it will be to this Government's everlasting discredit-if the words spoken at the opening of the thirty-second session of Parliament were mere gloss to enhance the ceremoniousness of the occasion.

Yet there seems fairly clear evidence at this stage that the Government's attitude to legislative change with regard to disabled persons is 'hasten slowly'. Between now and June, this Government will no doubt unleash all manner of undemocratic tactics on both Houses of Parliament in order to ram through some unwanted and unsalubrious legislation. I am predicting with utmost confidence, however, that none will concern the disabled. Of course, this Government has never been known to act assiduously in the area of welfare reform, and there is already ample evidence that this year will be no exception. I am told that a working paper on the subject of anti-discrimination legislation in respect of the rights of the disabled is presently buried somewhere in the Attorney-General's Department. If this is the blighted path on which the Government has chosen to launch the International Year of Disabled Persons-the year specially designated by the United Nations-I ask: What will happen in years to come?

The United Nations proclaimed 'Full Participation and Equality' as the theme for the International Year of Disabled Persons 1981. I ask again: Where is the participation and where is the equality? Participation suggests to me that disabled persons themselves should have a say in what legislative changes are to be contemplated. Yet what do we find? We find no participation but more paternalism, government and institutions deciding what is best for the people involved. The Handicapped Persons Assistance Act is a prime example. The past paternalism displayed by this Government has meant that only organisations that provide services on their premises are eligible for Government financial assistance, while self-help groups pooling their resources are ineligible. The thoughtlessness and the heartlessness of this Government are demonstrated once more in the overlapping provisions of the National Health Act, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. With characteristic insensitivity, the Government has ignored the conflict that arises in attempting to strike a balance between encouraging the integration of the disabled within the community and providing much needed regular therapy in institutions.

I have been advised by multiple sclerosis sufferers who must undergo intensive therapy once or twice a year as occasional in-patients in nursing homes that they are lucky to find their fare out of the home on completion of the treatment. After paying the nursing home fee of $60.20 a week, they are left with the grand sum of $8 a week in pocket money. Frequently these unfortunate souls have commitments outside the nursing homes which must be kept going when they are in the homes. What account has the Government taken of their predicament? In its generosity, it has provided a further bureaucratic hurdle however, not one that is available to all disabled persons so afflicted. But-and here's the rub-there is provision for the patient's contribution to be waived, if the patient is suffering financial hardship. Under the circumstances I have previously described, that is when $8.00 is all a nursing home patient is left after paying nursing home fees, surely all disabled persons in such circumstances are suffering financial hardships. It is typical of the Government to treat all the under-privileged in our society as an aberration. What I have described is a perfect example of this policy slant. Clearly the Government has two options, if it is to rectify this situation: Either it must increase the nursing home subsidy or it must lift invalid pensions.

With no opportunity to participate in decisions taken to influence their welfare, what chance have the disabled to receive equality of opportunity? At present, their chances are very slim indeed, due to the disjointed and fragmented patchwork quilt of Federal and State laws which directly or indirectly impinge on the lives of the disabled. The International Year of Disabled Persons presents us with an opportunity-no, more than an opportunity-an obligation, to bring some rationality and uniformity into the set of existing Federal and State laws dealing with the disabled person. It is imperative that the Federal and State legislators join together in immediate consultation to ensure that the laws affecting the disabled are comparable right across Australia. Legislation relating to human rights and citizenship rights for the disabled should be the point of departure in which all other reforms find their reference. It makes sense to locate this legislation in the Federal sphere. At the very least the Government should already be observing the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled. These rights include the promotion of higher standards of living and full employment for those disabled persons able to work, while assuring their welfare and rehabilitation. When it comes to equality for the disabled, it is self-evident that we must start from a basic threshold, such as a guarantee of access to welfare and rehabilitation.

One has to look no further than the Social Services Act for evidence that this Government has little regard for the disabled. The Social Services Act can only be described as grossly discriminatory and ill-conceived, especially with regard to the payment of invalid pensions. It is ill-conceived because only the blind are allowed means test free invalid pensions. Countless disabled persons are thereby forced to live squalid and second rate lives, trying to eke out a desperate existence at near poverty level. Frequently those disabled persons who are able to work discover that full employment extends only as far as the nearest sheltered workshop. With the average wage of sheltered workers frozen at $20 for a 40-hour week-that is, the maximum permissible weekly earnings without the loss of pension-the possibility of higher standards of living is forever out of reach. At a recent national conference to discuss employment of the disabled, it was asserted that Australia is the only English speaking country which has not legislated for conditions in sheltered workshops; further, that sheltered workers did not get the benefit of national wage increases. This in itself is a tragedy. However, even more regrettable is the fact that national wage increases would not profit a disabled pension recipient, given the application of the means test I mentioned above. Every dollar earned in excess of $20 per week is reduced by half. If this were a humane and caring government, it would index the sheltered workers incentive allowance, which is not means-tested but which presently stands at a pathetic $5 per week. This would ensure that disabled persons would get the benefit of consumer price indexs increases.

With some 28 areas of legislation under which disabled persons receive direct or indirect assistance from the Government, there is plenty of scope for reform and I do not intend to give an exhaustive account of all areas. However, there is one matter on which I think this Government should act swiftly if it is not to attract censure from this side of the House. I refer to providing the disabled with legislation to prevent their being discriminated against in their employment on the basis of their disability. There is still no legislative backing for the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation. Disabled persons, who may also be Commonwealth public servants, or those employed in the States where there is no protective legislation, are being kicked about and down-trodden because of the Government's failure to act in this sphere. The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation each year receives many complaints from employees who believe that they have been discriminated against because of a disability. However, it can do no more than wag its finger at guilty employers. In these difficult times, made even more difficult by the Government's economic policies, what prospect does a disabled person having once been retrenched, have of finding another job? One has only to consider the extent of the number of what is now cruelly termed 'hard-core unemployables' who are not disabled to know the answer to this question.

There are other facets of anti-discrimination legislation which should be enacted for the disabled, among them measures dealing with aspects brought to our attention by the National Women's Advisory Council. These include the abolition of the need for the disabled to qualify for superannuation schemes as a means of becoming eligible for employment; the protection of the disabled in relation to the imposition of compulsory abortion and sterilisation procedures; the provision of a promotional appeals avenue for Commonwealth public servants, one which is sensitive to the rights of the disabled; and the provision of legal support and advocacy services to give the disabled representation in legal matters in their role as private citizens.

The Government would do well to look at handicap legislation in the United States where, to quote Mr Justice Kirby, Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, 'handicap law is being hailed as the new era of law'. Mr Justice Kirby has praised the United States Vocational Rehabilitation Act of 1973 under which nobody in the United States may receive supportive federal funds if it is shown that the body discriminates against an otherwise handicapped individual . . . solely by reason of his or her handicap. The Act has been used in precisely the areas where handicapped people are at a particular disadvantage, such as those of housing, employment, education and access to public facilities. There will be no shortage of inspiration and example available to the Government when it is finally moved to exert itself.

Yet another area where the Government is dragging its feet is in regard to the hearing impaired. It seems it has now become commonplace for persons suffering hearing impairment to wait three months or even longer for the supply of hearing aids through the National Acoustic Laboratories. There seems to me to be an awful irony in this state of affairs. To say the least, it is symbolic of the Government's callous attitude, its downright inability to hear the pleas for assistance coming from the less fortunate in our community. In turning a blind eye and a deaf ear, the Government is revealing the deficiency in its policy toward the supply of welfare services to the seven out of 100 Australians who suffer from serious hearing defects.

The IYDP deserves a co-ordinated approach at the national level, not only in regard to legislative reform but also in regard to funding. To date, the Government's efforts with regard to the supply of television services to the hearing impaired has been characterised by demarcation disputes over departmental jurisdiction, by ministerial buck-passing and by intervention from media monopolies. At least four government departments, those of the Prime Minister, the Minister for Social Security, the Minister for Communications and the Minister for Health, are involved-strewing red-tape, pigeon-holing and procrastinating as only they know how. Their ineptitude has caused much concern among many wonderful people who assist the disabled persons in these areas. Either the Minister for Communications or the Minister for Social Security should decide which of their two departments will accept responsibility for a national captioning centre. The Australian Deafness Council met with representatives of each of the above-mentioned departments to decide Australia's options with regard to such a captioning centre in October last year. The proposed national captioning centre requires special funding initially but the Australian Deafness Council believes that it can be self-sufficient thereafter. Although the Minister for Social Security currently has responsibility for the IYDP at the national level, the responsibility for this particular issue is clearly causing some impairment, not only to Government hearing but also to its vision. Since it also involved the Minister for Communications, who was asked to take a decision as regards policy for standardisation of a video-text technique, it is anybody's guess where the buck will finally stop. The United Kingdom, the United States and Canada are already well established in the provision of closed captioning for the deaf and the hearing impaired. If the delays in Australia hinge on who is prepared to accept ministerial responsibility, I suggest it is time the Ministers involved introduced themselves to one another and began to work together.

Furthermore, the policy on the standardisation of a video-text technique is too important a decision for market forces or, more to the point, for media monopolies to decide. I understand also that at the meeting held last October, at which the four government departments were represented, it was pointed out that 10 out of 17 metropolitan television stations have Teletext. However, it is also true that research is needed into what programs people want captioned. To date the necessary research, like the decision as to the type of video text to be used, is still in limbo.

The fragmented and disjointed approach which has characterised legislation relating to the disabled is also evident in the Government's funding program. In the 1980-81 Budget Speech, the Government stated it would spend $11m in the first year of a three-year program for the establishment of new services for handicapped children and adults. To date, only $3.8m of this allocation has been made available and $1m of that has been spent on publicity. If such a lag in the disbursement of funds occurs at the beginning of the funding program, what will be the fate of the program overall? As at this date, if we disregard the $1m which has been made available to the Department of Social Security for publicity purposes, it appears that only $2.8m has thus far been channelled through four government departments. Honourable members are bound to agree with me that this sum is a mere trifle and substantially beneath the level of funding that we have been anticipating given the great fanfare of publicity associated with the Government's intentions toward the IYDP. The time and effort spent in trumpeting the Government's achievements, or lack of them, would be better spent providing concrete benefit to the disabled. As it stands, it is arguable how much of the $2.8m mentioned will filter through to the disabled themselves.

If the IYDP is not to go down in the annals of welfare reform as a gigantic public relations and self-congratulatory exercise by and for, the Fraser Government, let us see more funds, more co-ordination and more communication from the Ministers responsible for administering it. Let us hear clear and regular reports as to the overall progress of the IYDP.

I would be grateful if you would convey to Mr Speaker my congratulations to him and my wishes for a successful forthcoming term for him also. May I also congratulate those honourable members who made maiden speeches during the course of the Address-in-Reply debate and other debates. I note in particular that there were two women maiden speakers and also one who was returning to the House. Much as I regret the loss of my former party colleagues from those seats, I nonetheless believe that it is a useful balance within this chamber to have three women members-if only three.

SPEECH.PARA: His Excellency the Governor-General in his Speech to the Parliament on 25 November last, made particular reference to the problem of unemployment and the importance attached by the Government to a solution to this problem. His Excellency said:

My Government believes that the long-term solution to it undoubtedly lies in the creation of new jobs by restoring healthy economic growth, and in this respect Australia is much better placed than many other industrial countries.
He went on to say:
But the matter cannot be left there, has not been left there, and will not be left there.

I agree with that and I would like to say something tonight about the kinds of things we have to do. First, I will dispose of some excess baggage that the ideological Left is trying to load on to us as we tackle the problem of unemployment. It has become fashionable, indeed it seems to be a political imperative of the Left, to try to frighten the wits out of people over the job-reducing effects of technological change. The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) joined the bandwagon in his book I Want to Work, published a couple of years ago, and the present opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), has skated dangerously around this subject over the last two or three years. On the far Left we have Messrs. Wheelwright and Windschuttle purveying highly questionable material that suggests that a complete collapse of employment is imminent. According to these gentlemen it should have occurred already, but the statistics of the last eighteen months or so have been rather inconvenient for them.

For a balanced view of the effects of technological change on employment I refer the House to a paper given by Professor F. H. Gruen of the Australian National University to the forty-seventh Summer School of the Australian Institute of Political Science earlier this year. Professor Gruen is an economist respected by both sides of politics, and he acted as an adviser on some matters to the Whitlam Labor Government. He gives three substantial reasons why we should be sceptical of the suggestion that technological change will destroy employment. Firstly, in Australia the growth of unemployment was too great and too sudden to have been caused by new technology. In 1974-75 unemployment grew by 150 per cent in less than twelve months, and it most certainly did not result from an inrush of microprocessors during that period. Secondly, if unemployment is to result from rapid technological change, then one would expect it to be accompanied by a rapid increase in productivity; that is, higher output per worker through the use of machines. However, on the contrary, the rate of growth in productivity has actually declined in most Western economies, including Australia, over the last decade. Thirdly, unemployment in Australia after 1974 moved from one of the lowest in the developed economies to one of the highest, yet Australia introduced fewer microprocessors or industrial robots over these years than these other countries. How, then, could our increased rate of unemployment be explained by the use of high technology?

Of course, no one argues that jobs are not lost in particular firms or particular industries because of technological change. What seems clear, however, is that there is no evidence to show that on balance there is a net loss of jobs through technological change. On the contrary, there is more evidence to show that unless we do have technological change we will become internationally uncompetitive, will not sell our goods abroad and as a result will lose more jobs in the end. The real reason we have lost so many jobs in Australia since 1974 is that we halved our rate of economic growth. Some of this was caused by overseas factors, such as the rise in oil prices, but we would have done a lot better if we had not had such bad economic management under the Labor Government. I know it has become boring to say this, but it is true nonetheless. It is even more boring to follow a responsible policy of economic recovery, but over the last 12 months that policy at last has borne fruit. We are getting economic growth again and more jobs are becoming available, but there is a real danger that the least able, the least skilled or the most disadvantaged, could be passed by when the new jobs are handed out.

It is clear from Professor Gruen's paper that the two essential components of full employment in the pre-1974 sense are, firstly, economic growth and, secondly, labour market flexibility. The two are intertwined, for although we now have the ingredients of better economic growth in Australia, labour market inflexibility will in various ways reduce the size of that growth, and thereby also reduce the availability of jobs. Honourable members should understand that we cannot blame the economists for our high rates of unemployment. Their job is to point out why unemployment is high and what is stopping it from going down. This the better economists-Professor Gruen is one-have done. What economists cannot do is prescribe simple economic solutions to the essentially political problem of shaking out entrenched interest groups. It is only by doing just that that we can reach a solution. One may well say that the problem is political and passes on to governments. In a way that is true, but the Federal Government gets little help from the business sector, the unions, State Governments or the constitution of the Commonwealth in its efforts to deal with the situation. It is certainly not blameless itself, as it has bowed too often to sectional interests on certain issues and has not admitted publicly in unmistakeable terms that it has no control whatsoever over one of the main determinants of employment, that is the setting of industrial awards.

Nonetheless, the Government deserves credit for reintroducing sound fiscal monetary and energy policies compared with those of the early 1970s, and creating a receptive climate for the kind of investment that is giving us the improved growth rate that we now see. Given the size and nature of the pressures exerted on the Government by sectional groups and the comparative absence of counter-pressures from those waiting in the queue for their own slice of assistance, it is not really surprising that some important structural decisions have been ducked. The most obvious is protection. It is true that protection can slow down, but not halt, the decline of employment in inefficient industries, such as textiles and motor manufacturing. However, there is hardly an economist in the country of any school who claims that protection improves overall employment. Yet the trade unions, the Labor Party and I regret many in my own party, link arms with protected manufacturers to preserve the privilege of the few at the expense of the many. The textiles battle was lost, and we now shape up to the bigger issue of the motor industry and the general survey recommended by the Crawford report, but shelved 18 months ago. Will those prepared to speak out on behalf of consumers and the unemployed please gird their loins, for the motor chiefs are already at work and they carry big sticks.

The political issues relating to the question of labour market flexibility are more complicated because the Government has no direct power. If we could shake the devil out of the labour market tomorrow we could employ most people who want to work. I am informed that one of the growth industries, a so-called leisure industry-that of take-away foods-does 85 per cent of its business outside the traditional five-day working week. Under our crazy labour system one pays a severe economic penalty if people are employed outside these traditional hours. It is all right for the few who get the higher rates, but the hamburgers and the fried chooks cost a lot more. Ordinary people eat out less than they would like, fewer people go into the business and probably only half the number of people who could be employed are employed.

I refer now to my old friends the banks. Most industries in Australia are forced to squeeze their work into a set of rules set out in the 1920s and 1930s but the banks contrive to maintain practices set in the nineteenth century, when it was necessary to close at 3 o'clock to handwrite the ledgers. It seems to have escaped the attention of the banks and the banking unions who support all the protective privileges enjoyed by the banks, that the leisured gentry comprise only a minority of their customers today and that a machine gobbles up the tedium of the ledgers at dead of night. What possible justification is there for determinedly keeping those expensive retail outlets closed at the very times the customers want to use them? Last year on television I saw an advertisement for a bank. It showed all the clocks chiming in the village square at 10 o'clock and a happy young couple rushing through the totally empty village square. They were greeted by the bank manager with not another soul in sight because everybody else was at work, which is where they should have been at 10 o'clock in the morning. As soon as the people come out of their offices, the bank shuts its doors and no one can do business.

How many more people would be employed if banks opened at times convenient to their customers rather than to themselves or their unions? Indeed, retailing overall in Australia is a transparent nonsense. The only shops that actually serve their customers are those operated as family businesses, that can afford, or are allowed to stay open when people are not at work. Consumers, you should rise up in rage when you are forced to cram your shopping into one evening or a Saturday morning under unbelievably unpleasant conditions! If you are able to sneak some time off work you can observe acres of expensive space in store after store all ready to be snapped shut and lights turned off as soon as the main rush of potential customers emerges from offices and factories. Every time I think of this I feel the fury that must have gripped the early reformers; a fury directed then against the owners of the satanic mills and now directed against the mock arguments and skirmishing that form the ritual dance of the employer organisations and unions before the high priests of the conciliation and arbitration system as they proceed to deliver consumers and the unemployed for further sacrifice. Clearly, labour market flexibility would not only share out existing work equitably but also it would create new work, particularly in labour intensive service industries. All those imaginative goods and services that people think of offering to people for extension of their knowledge or their leisure at times when they are not at paid work, could proceed without the crippling burden imposed on them by having to follow work rules considered appropriate for manufacturing industry in the first half of this century. In moving towards a solution, I suggest that there should be no minimum award working week. There should be a premium for night work but none for weekend work. There should be overtime paid for working over, say, 7 hours at a stretch, but not otherwise. There should be no fixed retiring age. There should be no fixed shopping hours, banking hours, baking hours, or any other restraints against serving a market. That will do for a start. Let us try it and see then if anyone is still left on the scrap heap.

The second major area of labour market rigidity is, of course, price. In his paper Professor Gruen raised the question of the price of labour in relation to unemployment amongst low achievers. The Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone, also rattled this skeleton in his address to the National Agricultural Outlook Conference in Canberra recently. Let me be a little more dogmatic. The unskilled or less presentable will not be employed in any numbers until the minimum rates of pay prescribed by law are roughly in line with what prospective employers think such applicants are worth. If the rates are silly, then expanding work opportunities will continue to be taken up by increased participation rates; that is, those not presently seeking work will take the new jobs available before the young or the unskilled. Also, unemployment in places like South Australia and Tasmania will remain high while laws prescribe the same rates of pay for those locations as for more profitable locations for enterprise such as Sydney or the Gold Coast.

The convolutions indulged in by social scientists, social workers, bishops, editorialists, and governments of all persuasions to avoid these facts of life fill volumes of learned texts, lobbying submissions, pastoral letters, newspapers and regrettably, legislation. All the bureaucratic solutions to unemployment, such as job creation schemes, wage subsidies and the like will never approach the effectiveness of market solutions. Employers in a free society, like consumers, continue to exhibit that surprising tendency to avoid paying more for goods or services than they think they are worth. Come to think of it, that might also be a reason for sluggish sales and falling employment in the motor industry.

I will touch only briefly on the third area of labour market rigidity, that is, in the availability of skills. Forgive me, Mr Deputy Speaker, if I remain profoundly sceptical of national manpower planning forecasts. Manpower planning or manpower forecasts in any individual area such as a business, a corporation, a government department or education system are absolutely essential. However, I am sceptical about the national ones. The pursuit by DOLAC, the Department of Labour Advisory Council, and the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research of the will-o-the-wisp of the future balance of the market for skilled tradesmen tends to confirm my view that the real objective must be to loosen the trade union stranglehold over the supply of skilled labour, which the unions want to have so that they can dictate the price. If there is a surplus as a result, it will not matter much. Tradesmen are always moving into small businesses, often unrelated to their skills. If the market is in surplus, they will do so at a faster rate. In the meantime, let us try harder to break down trade union opposition to sensible skill training systems; for example, opposition to the training of mature aged people for skills. One way of doing this is to import the skills from overseas in the short term. This breaks up the market. The other action required is to pay skilled tradesmen a better margin. Some of those liquor store proprietors and taxi drivers might return to their original trades. Of course, employers are frightened to do this because of the flow on effects to the less skilled, and we are back on the roundabout of the crazy inflexible system.

To summarise, then, it seems to me that we have quite enough analysis of the problems of future work to tell us what needs to be done. The economists have had their say. It is up to us to see how we can break up the established, entrenched systems of those powerful groups, be they workers, industrialists, public servants or any other groups who currently enjoy the privilege of good work and the promise of future work but who, by their holding on to entrenched and privileged positions, prevent those who are less skilled and less able, the young and possibly the prematurely old, from participating in the economic growth which the Government's policies have now led to. What we want in Australia is not a Nobel Prize winning economist, but a modern Wilberforce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, in expressing the concern of the House at the assassination attempt on President Reagan, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) again condemned terrorism. However, less than a fortnight ago, in answer to the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) the Prime Minister gave unqualified support to the decision of President Reagan to supply arms and advisers to the present ruling junta in El Salvador. That junta regards State sponsored terrorism as a legitimate political weapon, and a weapon that has had genocidal applications against the people of El Salvador. The thrust of the remarks that I want to make is to dissociate myself and I believe thousands of Australian citizens from the present blinkered support of the Prime Minister for a policy which, while he condemns individual acts of terrorism on the one hand, in fact involves support for the concept of State sponsored terrorism on the other hand when that is carried out in a genocidal way, as it has been in El Salvador. President Reagan perceives El Salvador as the first test case for his Administration to demonstrate Western willingness to draw the line against what he perceives as Soviet expansionism. The Assistant Secretary of State, Mr Engleburger, set off to tour Europe and to marshal support for this Presidential perception. Mr Engleburger presented intelligence reports that are said to show that the Soviet Union, Cuba and other communist nations have been providing arms to left wing Salvadoran guerrillas and that proves that the insurgency in El Salvador has been, to use American terms: 'Progressively transformed in a textbook case of indirect armed aggression by communist powers through Cuba'.

SPEECH.PARA: France, West Germany and other European powers have, unlike our own Prime Minister, to date responded very coyly to United States assertions. Mexico, which is far closer than the United States to this problem, has expressed its concern and a former American ambassador to El Salvador, Robert White, faces dismissal by the Reagan Administration for publicly stating that increased United States military aid is simply reinforcing in power a militarist right wing junta. In his testimony in late February before a House committee, Mr White, who was dismissed by General Haig after 11 months as ambassador, contended that the provision of United States arms and advisers was not necessary to deal with the weakened leftist guerrillas. He indicated that such armaments would allow rightist influenced security forces to assasinate and kill in a totally uncontrolled way. Recent history supports Mr White. In the last 12 months, over 10,000 people have been killed in El Salvador-9,000 of these murders are attributed to right wing paramilitary 'hit squads'. Trade union leaders, peasants, student and political leaders, priests and nuns who have supported reform have been targets for assassination and murder.

El Salvador is the smallest and most densely populated nation in Latin America. It has a population of 5.5 million with 60 per cent of the population classed as agricultural workers. Some 64 per cent of rural families are regional workers with no land or with less than a hectare of land. Seven per cent of the population owns 40 per cent of the land; 67 per cent of the people receive no medical attention; and there exists a malnutrition rate among Salvadorean children of 70 per cent. Some 30 per cent of families have no access to water while 50 per cent of the population are illiterate.

Since 1932, the armed forces have ruled El Salvador in the interests of what is known locally as 'the fourteen families'-in reality probably closer to 38-who have dominated the El Salvadorean economy for over a century. These families own most of the land, control the coffee, cotton and sugar cane trade and own most of the industry as well as controlling the banking of El Salvador. In 1973-74, it was estimated that 8 per cent of the population received 50 per cent of the wealth while 30 per cent of the population was subsisting on less than $US2.70 a month. While that economic domination has continued, various factions within the armed forces have from time to time replaced each other. But irrespective of who succeeded in office the basic control has remained the same and the inequity if anything was compounded.

The new Reagan Administration has falsely endeavoured to portray the military based regime of President Duarte as a well-meaning reformist group caught between the escalating violence of the Left and the Right. That portrayal does not stand with the facts of history. In 1972 the more repressive General Molina became President. In 1977 he was replaced by an even more ultra-right wing group headed by General Humberto Romero. He encouraged right wing death squads whose principal targets were local political activists, including peasant leaders, trade unionists and priests. On 15 October 1979, Romero was, with United States encouragement, overthrown by army officers who established a civilian military junta. The new Government was backed by moderate Opposition parties. Most political parties supported the new junta's plan for agrarian and fiscal reforms as well as the pledge that the fascist paramilitary hit group, and other groups that violated human rights, would be opposed. An amnesty was proposed for political prisoners and free elections were to be held in a reasonable time. Three months later, with violence unchecked and right wing death squads being used to repress the popular movement and all attempts at economic reform blocked by the economic elite, the civilians in the junta resigned.

Following the assassination by right wing guerillas on 25 February 1980 of Mario Samora, the Attorney-General and popular Christian Democrat politician, the Government showed signs of breaking up. Napolean Duarte became President, suspended the Constitution, announced proposed land reforms and a state of siege. What has emerged in fact is 'reform with repression', the military occupying expropriated land and using its new powers to repress radical peasant organisations. In El Salvador, human rights organisations, the Opposition and the leadership of the Catholic Church renounced the repression taking place behind the facade of agrarian reform. Jesuit priests created a vast network of Christian communities among the peasantry many of whom have been deeply involved in the struggle for land and social reform for many years. The Church has created Christian camps in which in early February this year some 6,000 peasants had sought sanctuary from the supposed agrarian reforms of the present junta. Archbishop Romero, who had increasingly approved the radicalism of his clergy, added his own very significant voice to the chorus of protest. It was he who stated: 'A land irrigated in blood cannot be productive'.

On 23 March, Archbishop Romero called yet again for the end of repression and said that no soldier was obliged to obey an order to kill if it ran contrary to his conscience. A day later, the Archbishop was murdered by right wing gunmen as he said mass. Since his death, the Church has been under increasing pressure as Church refugee centres have been assaulted and more priests and nuns murdered. The assassination of Romero led to further polarisation and emergence of the Democratic Revolutionary Front. That front has the backing of militias in the countryside, urban street committees in the towns, students, unions, Catholic priests and professional associations. Its leaders were all well known politicians from the centre. It is a movement that owes more to the social encyclicals of the Catholic Church and the teachings of Popes Paul VI and John Paul II than to Karl Marx.

It should not come as a surprise or fill us with shock and horror that the democratic revolutionary front has lost confidence in producing effective social change through free elections. There have been no free elections in El Salvador for the last half century. It is not surprising that they should seek arms as, in the past year alone, right wing death squads protected and encouraged by sections of the present junta have murdered the Archbishop, the rector of the university, the entire leadership of the Opposition, the principal peasant union leader, four American nuns and two American land reform experts as well as instigating a reign of 'white terror' that estimates a minimum of 10,000 to 12,000 Salvadoreans executed. That is the kind of junta which the Prime Minister of Australia, who talks about terrorism-indeed, who blithely mouths statements about terrorism-expects this House to support. Confronted with political repression, why should El Salvadorean patriots not decide that only a national armed insurrection could challenge the army's long monopoly of power and the constant abuse of this power. As further evidence of the reign of terror in El Salvador, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard at the end of my speech evidence given by the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs to the Thirty-seventh session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Successive American administrations, with Australia following loyally behind, have seriously misjudged the nature and complexity of forces for social change in the Third World and have continually supported regimes that even with American financial and military support have had only a limited potential for survival. Until the day the United States ignominiously abandoned its Saigon Embassy, it continued to argue that Vietnamese revolutionaries had no popular support. Our own and the United States people were told the same about Zimbabwean guerrillas until they actually won the election. We had to be told that obviously someone must have voted for them. Despite the formidable United States military, economic and intelligence presence in Iran, the United States and Australia were unable to discover a simple and now well established and indisputable fact of history, that is, that the Shah was passionately loathed by the overwhelming majority of his own people. The list of miscalculations is too long to recapitulate.

SPEECH.PARA: Economic and social inequality enabled a few to live in luxury while the great mass of the Salvadoran people were condemned to live in the poverty that created the socio-economic base for revolution. It was the determination of those who controlled economic power to maintain it with paramilitary murder squads and political repression that did not shrink from large scale state sponsored terrorism, combining murder and torture as a weapon for cowering their own population that led to the counter demand for arms. The same right wing junta is now to receive United States military hardware and advisers as well as financial backing that is designed to secure them in power. We are told that this is necessary because of United States intelligence reports that a flow of arms came from the Soviet Union or Havana. Given the absence of American weaponry, the Revolutionary Front, if it is to succeed, must get its arms where it can.

Governor Reagan made it plain during his presidential campaign, that he regarded the problems in central America as an exercise initiated by Cuba and the Soviet Union aimed at destabilising the region. The rhetoric suggested that only a military solution could solve the crisis in El Salvador. The Carter strategy of backing the forces of reform and being outspoken on human rights abuses, went out the back door as far as the candidate for the presidency was concerned. That rhetoric has now been maintained by President Reagan in office. To view the crisis in El Salvador as simply a Soviet-Cuban plot is to fail to recognise the social and economic processes that have been suppressed in El Salvador for decades by the simple process of corruption and state-sponsored terrorism and torture. It is interesting to note that no European power of significance has responded to United States arguments and that Mexico has publicly queried the logic of United States policy, but our Prime Minister, without any hesitation, has blindly supported the thrust of President Reagan's policy and declared this Government's support for United States policy on El Salvador. It is interesting to note the view of United States citizens in relation to El Salvador. The Age of 26 March 1981, quoting a poll of United States citizens, states:

Only a third of the people interviewed by a 'Los Angeles Times' poll believe that the United States should continue to support the Salvadoran regime, which is under attack from both Left-wing and Right-wing elements.

Many American citizens who experienced the tragedy of Vietnam are saying that they do not want another Vietnam. Anyone who looks at the history of El Salvador from a situation in Australia could not fairly or honestly say that he wants the Australian Government, even the Government of Malcolm Fraser, to be associated with the murderous junta which has made the destruction of its own people an instrument of policy. So long as the Prime Minister of ths government is prepared to do that, he need not talk in this House about terrorism. Individual acts of terrorism are no worse, and probably not as bad, as state sponsored terrorism, and that is what this Government is supporting in El Salvador.

I wonder whether the blinkered vision of the honourable gentlemen opposite who involved Australian youth in the divisive war in Vietnam will ever learn. Is the same blinkered vision of the Prime Minister going to cast Australia permanently into the role of a Sancho Panza, as President Reagan becomes the West's new Don Quixote, tilting forever at the windmill of communist dragons emerging from the tortured areas of human tragedy on the South American continent? The judgment that gave us Vietnam is no better and considerably worse than the judgment being exercised in the White House and in the Prime Minister's office when we determine our attitude towards the Salvadoran people. How does any government in Australia support a regime which has not hesitated to murder its own Archbishop, its own academic scholars and intellectuals, its own writers, its own trade union leaders, the leaders of the peasant party and opposition leadership? Yet that is what we are asked blindly to support. I believe that the judgment of President Reagan is wrong and that once again the West will pay for that error in judgment. I believe that the judgment of the Prime Minister of Australia is far worse. At least the United States President can say of El Salvador that it comes historically within a region which America has regarded as its area of influence. At least President Reagan can fall back on the Monroe Doctrine. But what can we in Australia fall back on? What judgment enables us to hold our heads high in any international community or within the Third World? How do we explain our attitude of blind support on this issue? I suggest that the Prime Minister is making a worse mistake on the question of El Salvador than a previous Liberal Government made on Vietnam. Ultimately that conservative Government came to realise that one cannot hold back forces of social change by supporting in power oppressive juntas which believe that murder is a legitimate exercise, that genocide is a legitimate exercise. That lesson had to be learned the hard way by honourable gentlemen opposite in relation to Vietnam. They will surely learn this lesson again when history writes its judgment of the attitude of the Prime Minister and this Government on the tragic genocide which is now taking place in El Salvador. I condemn the Prime Minister's statement and I condemn this Government's attitude. I believe that the people of Australia, when confronted with the facts, will equally condemn it.
