COMMISSION OF THE CHURCHES ON INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS of The World Council of Churches Moderator: Olle Dahlen Director: Leopoloo J. Nilus
Question of the violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in any part of the world, with particular reference to colonial and other dependant countries and territories.

Text of the oral intervention by the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs, a Non-Governmental Organization in Category II Consultative Status, to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, at its Thirty-Seventh Session, concerning El Salvador, under Agenda Item 13.
Mr Chairman,

Thank you for this opportunity to address the Commission on behalf of the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs of the World Council of Churches a non-governmental organization in consultative status in which are joined over 300 Protestant, Anglican and Orthodox churches in some 100 countries. It also maintains close relations with the Roman Catholic Church.
Mr Chairman,

Our Commission has circulated Document E/CN.4/NGO 314 which contains recent statements by the World Council of Churches on the situation in El Salvador, a country characterized by systematic and gross violations of human rights. This affirmation is based on the daily experience, and copious documentation which has been gathered by the Legal Aid Department (Socorro Juridico) of the Archdiocese of San Salvador, of which I am the Director, and in whose name I speak. We have been uniquely placed to hear from every corner of our country the cruelty and humiliation the common people suffer.

It is a privilege for me to bring their voice here and to be able to share with you the deep concerns of the Salvadorean people. What I shall say is not an invented construction of our situation, it is the living reality of a people.
Mr Chairman,

In its resolution 35/192 (15 December 1980), the General Assembly made reference to the brutal assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero, a man of faith who had come to symbolize the struggle of our people for justice. As the world knows, he was gunned down in cold blood by an assassin as he was celebrating the mass in a hospital in San Salvador.

During his brief three years in the episcopate, Archbishop Romero became a staunch advocate of human rights and of the cause of the people of our country: he consistently denounced the sinful practices he saw about him and with a force comparable only to the prophets of old, and of Bishop Bartholome de las Casas, the defender of the Indians of Central America. He never let up in his outspokenness and, contrary to some others, did not place the security of the Church above the need to denounce injustice. He was the ''voice of the voiceless''. No regime has succeeded in destroying the authenticity of Monsignor Romero's witness. As Christ had done, the Archbishop said, just before his death, that during the three years of his preaching none could accuse him of falsehood. It was necessary to assassinate him in order to silence him.

The cases of the violation of human rights which the Archbishop ennumerated each Sunday, had been subject to a rigorous process of corroboration and legal review by the Legal Aid Department of the Archdiocese. Since his martyrdom we have endeavored to fulfill his mandate to us: 'If they assassinate me', he said to the staff, 'you must continue defending the rights of my oppressed and poor people'. It is precisely because we carry out the martyr's will that those who illegally govern El Salvador raided the offices of the Legal Aid Department on 5 July 1980 with the intention of eliminating the evidence we held which proved that the clandestine death squads and other right-wing extremist groups were linked to the Armed Forces and their military security apparatus.

The authorities have also attempted to eliminate available evidence concerning the assassination of Monsignor Romero, and of the persecution of the Church, which during 1980, claimed the lives of six priests and involved some 150 terrorist acts directly attributable to the Salvadorean military and, in some cases, to foreign military groups.
Mr Chairman,
We are able to affirm and document the present situation of human rights in El Salvador as follows:

1. The violation of human rights in El Salvador has a long history. Between 1977 and 1979 four investigations were carried out by impartial observers-the Department of State of the United States of America; the Parliamentary Commission of Great Britain; the Interamerican Commission on Human Rights of the Organization of American States, and the International Commission of Jurists. Their findings and recommendations are well known. Following the military coup d'etat on 15 October 1979, the procedures by which sanctions would have been applied against the Government of General Romero for the violation of human rights in El Salvador were suspended. From this date on, contrary to the statements made by the new governing military group, and to expectations of the international community, the constant violation of human rights has not diminished, but rather has increased significantly.

2. The substantiated available data indicate that, since 15 October 1979, large sectors of the Salvadorean population have been targeted for systematic extermination, and that to this end instruments have been developed and refined by the regime in power. How does the record of the present regime compare to its predecessor? During the 21-month period from January of 1978 through September 1979 Monsignor Romero and the Legal Aid Department of his Archdiocese denounced 727 political assassinations attributable to government forces. Those responsible for the 15 October 1979 coup de'etat gave as a justification for this act the need to put an end to these atrocities. In the three months following the coup (15 October-31 December 1979), 450 assassinations were committed by the new military regime. It was for this very reason that a majority of the members of the new military junta resigned at the end of the year, charging that the regime was engaged in generalized repression with massive foreign aid assistance, under the guise of a so-called agrarian reform program.

After January 1980 the number of assassinations and disappearances increased. During the first four months of the year more people were killed by groups related to the military than during all of 1979. During these months we heard the indominitable voice of Monsignor Romero demand, in the name of God, that 'the repression cease now', asking that there be no outside collaboration with the illegal military regime, either through provision of military advisors or through further arms shipments, since such collaboration would only contribute to greater injustice and to further bloodshed.

The tragic history of the subsequent eight months of 1980 is an eloquent indication that neither the military regime, nor its supporters abroad had heeded the voice of Monsignor Romero. His warnings continued until those he denounced chose to silence him by the assassin's bullet.

The total number of defenceless victims among the Salvadorean population-not counting those whose lives were lost in direct confrontations with the armed forces-victims who have been assassinated by the government armed and security forces, comes to 8,660 documented cases. To this figure must be added the 4,400 victims of the civilian population-mostly women and children-who died in operations of 'total extermination' carried out during the past three months by the Salvadorean armed forces.
In absolute terms, these figures greatly exceed those for which the previous government of General Carlos Romero was so sharply criticised by the Inter-American community in October 1979.

3. Qualitatively, the violations of human rights have become more serious as the deliberate policy of extermination has been carried out in the countryside by the armed forces, with the help of foreign military advisors, which has resulted in the physical elimination of leaders of significant international renown and who defended the cause of the poor and the oppressed among the Salvadorean people.

Salvadorean military personnel were implicated not only in the assassination of Monsignor Oscar Romero, but also in those of the democratic opposition leadership, numerous priests, and the North American nuns. And this is a government which calls itself Christian!

Members of the present government who opposed the practice of extermination have themselves been assassinated or have been forced to flee the country. In the most recent documented report of the Archdiocese of San Salvador, made available to the Division of Human Rights, on 25 February 1981, it is stated that the Army, and security forces assassinated 257 defenceless persons between 14-20 February. In one month of martial law, 300 defenceless persons were murdered. The majority were abducted from their homes. From June 1980 to January 1981, the Army and the security forces assassinated 202 children, of which 58 were 1 to 10 years of age (the rest from 11 through 15). It can therefore be safely concluded that the illegal and dictatorial government has not heeded the recommendations contained in General Assembly Resolution 35/192.
Mr Chairman,

As Christians seeking to achieve justice, the necessary basis of peace, we regret the nature of international attention which has been paid of late to El Salvador. It is harmful to the whole American continent, to those governments all over the world which respect human rights and in an increasingly serious way to world peace itself.

Central America, and especially now El Salvador, has become an international political laboratory for a set of demonic, violent experiments, the object of which is a people which longs only for justice, for peace, and for its right to determine its own affairs. The people suffers. As has so often happened in the course of the history of our continent, the people has been left to one side, its basic rights trampled or ignored.
Mr Chairman,

It is not through pouring more arms into our country that human rights will become respected. It is not through sending foreign military advisors to improve the capacity of a regime to impose its will by force, that the rule of law will be established. It is not by distorting and hiding the truth that justice will be achieved. It is not through a war against a people that peace will be constructed.

It is with deep regret that we must conclude that the primary responsibility for the violations of human rights in El Salvador lies with the Salvadorean military regime. The testimonies of violations of human rights which we have compiled over the years constitute incontrovertible proof. This documentation is public and available. We hope that this Commission will examine and analyze it. We are convinced that a study of the facts as provided by the people themselves will eliminate the confusion which has been quite deliberately created by those at home and abroad who have their own narrow interests at heart. We sincerely hope that all the governments and peoples of the world will demonstrate their commitment to the lofty principles of human rights which it is the task of this Commission to safeguard, and refuse to become accomplices to the crucifixion of the Salvadorean people.

We call upon those now aligned with the forces of repression in El Salvador to cease their nefarious support for this war against our people, the vast majority of whom are Christian, a people which has been denied its rightful voice in such important international forums as this one. We sincerely hope that this voice will be heard. We pray that it will awaken in this Commission, and in the whole of the international community a commitment to aid us in our efforts to gain respect for the rights of all our people, including our right to democracy and self-determination.
Thank you, Mr Chairman

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to concentrate on the economic aspects of the Governor-General's speech. Because that Speech contained substantial reference to the philosophical basis of the Government's platform and policies, this debate has provided an opportunity for honourable members from both sides of the House to argue the ideological merits of their respective parties. The socialists opposite, particularly the newer members who in their speeches to date have sanctimoniously claimed a monopoly over just about every virtue that exists, have argued that their philosophy is the only one which can bring equity and justice to society. I suggest that they should look at an atlas and discover which nations and which political philosophies around the world provide the better living standards for their people, and where is the great equity and justice in those nations, which, taking the socialist case to its logical extreme, exercise total governmental control over their citizens. I think that honourable members opposite should compare the living standards of countries such as East Germany and West Germany, North Korea and South Korea China and Taiwan, the Soviet bloc and the United States, and the nations of the Association of South East Asian Nations and the socialist countries of South East Asia. I think that the great claims made on behalf of socialism could be seen then in an operational and realistic context.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it that in these great discourses, particularly from those newer members thrown up to this Parliament by the socialist Left in Victoria, they never seem to champion the cause of freedom? That is a word about which I have not heard much moralising to date in their speeches. They seem to assume that there is no equity or justice in freedom. They seem also to suggest that a degree of economic freedom is almost immoral and automatically precludes the attainment of all other virtues. Are honourable members suggesting that the state should determine consumer preferences, that we should surrender consumer sovereignty, and that the state is the best device to make the millions of intricate decisions required every day between investors, producers and consumers? If that is their argument they should ask themselves a few questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody ever said that.

—The honourable member made this kind of assertion in his speech. Honourable members should ask themselves: Which are the countries with the lowest standards of living, the lowest growth rates, the largest black markets and the longest queues for essential goods? I think the answer to that question is simple. It is those countries with government-controlled economies and not private enterprise economies. Given the statements made by a number of honourable members opposite I wish to give to the House the results of a number of studies on economic justice. Studies by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development on income distribution show that Australia is one of three countries which exhibits the lowest degree of income inequality on both a pre-tax and post-tax basis. In a publication called, Surveys of Australian Economics an article entitled, 'Income Distribution, Poverty and Redistributive Policies', shows that on a family income basis Australia consistently displays a more equitable income distribution than other developed countries no matter which assessment process is used. That article refers also to a study involving 56 countries which calculates the proportion of total pre-tax income received by the top 5 per cent of households. In that study Australia was placed among the top 5 per cent of the group which received the smaller share of that income. In all studies Australia is in that group of countries with the lowest degree of inequality in income distribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer also to a World Bank study. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development made a study on this subject a few years ago. On a comparison of countries it showed that Australia had one of the least unequal income distributions of any nation, and that included the communist countries of Eastern Europe. Let us not have any more of this nonsense from the Opposition that economic freedom automatically precludes the attaining of economic justice. Australia not only has a higher growth rate, higher living standards, and a better welfare system, but also we have much fairer sharing of the cake than most countries. This has been achieved within the context of a political philosophy which champions the cause of private enterprise and economic freedom. Given these facts it constantly surprises me that honourable members opposite criticise those of us on this side of the House, who champion private enterprise, as being hard liners because we believe in a reduced public sector with a greater concentration of welfare resources upon the needy. I cannot see what is hard line about advocating, firstly the need to concentrate more welfare resources on the needy; secondly the need to reduce taxes; and thirdly, the need to increase private sector employment by responsible budgetary restraint. This seems to sum up the whole approach of the Opposition, that if we support private enterprise and a more productive economic system we cannot also have any concern for people, particularly the needy. I would have though that these concerns were complimentary rather than mutually exclusive. I believe the record of this Government has shown this to be the case.

Rather than concentrating on the ideological sermanising of the Opposition I will concentrate on the facts and figures which highlight the economic record of this Government, based on its policies and philosophy. The second paragraph of the Governor-General's Speech states that the 1980 general election provided:
. . . a mandate to maintain the basic thrust of the policies which have been followed over the past five years.

Given that economic issues have dominated parliamentary debates over this time and given this statement by the Governor-General, it is necessary to examine the present state of the economy in order to assess the effectiveness of the economic policies which have been pursued over the past five years. The best and most recent summary of the economy is contained in the February and March publications of the Department of the Treasury 'Round-up of Economic Statistics'. I seek leave to have those summaries incorporated in Hansard:
Leave granted.
The summaries read as follows-
Round-up of Economic Statistics The Treasury, February 1981
The Consumer Price Index increased by 2.1 per cent in the December quarter 1980 and by 9.3 per cent over the course of 1980.
Both retail sales and new passenger vehicle registrations showed strong growth in the December quarter.
Private dwellings approvals rose further in the December quarter.
Unemployment continues at about the level of a year earlier although it has declined as a percentage of the labour force.
Employment growth remains strong.
Unfilled vacancies have increased substantially over the past year.
The volume of money, M3, increased by 13 per cent over the twelve months to December. Over the first half of 1980-81, M3 grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 11 per cent.
The combination of a steady current account deficit and stronger private capital inflow resulted in an overall balance of payments surplus of $288m in January.
Round-up of Economic Statistics The Treasury, March 1981
Despite some easing in January, retail sales and few passenger vehicle registrations have recorded strong growth in the three months to January.

New fixed capital expenditure by private enterprises rose by an exceptionally strong 24 per cent in the half year to December 1980 and businesses expect further strong growth for the second half of 1980-81.
Although total employment eased seasonally in January, growth over the year to January remained strong.
The level and rate of unemployment in February was lower than in February 1980, particularly for juniors looking for full-time work.
Unfilled vacancies increased further in January.
Average weekly earnings rose by 13.7 per cent over the course of 1980 which compares with a CPI rise of 9.2 per cent for the same period.
The food group index of the Consumer Price Index increased by 1.1 per cent in January.
Growth in the volume of money, M3, slowed to 11.3 per cent measured over the twelve months to January, although some of this decline reflected special factors which will be unwound in coming months.
The turnaround in the trade account to deficit in February was a major factor contributing to the overall balance of payments deficit of $45m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The economic indicators revealed in these publications give every reason for optimism. They show that consumer spending in the December quarter and in the three months to January 1981 has been strong. Investment expenditure, which is important for future job creation, has been exceptionally strong with new, fixed capital expenditure by private enterprises rising by 24 per cent in the half year to December 1980. The indications are that this trend will continue through 1981. The summaries also show that unemployment in February 1981 was lower than for the year earlier, particularly for juniors looking for full-time work. Employment growth and unfilled vacancies grew strongly over the year to January 1981. Average weekly earnings rose by 13.7 per cent during 1980, while the inflation rate was only 9.2 per cent over the same period. These and other statistics contained in these official economic bulletins provide a comprehensive range of major indicators which suggest that a substantial economic recovery is well under way in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no need to dwell on the state of the economy when this Government took office. The policies of this Government, referred to by the Governor-General, have led to the kind of economic recovery for which the whole nation was voting in the 1975 election. A closer look at the performance of the economy strengthens the picture which has been painted by these indicators. For the third year in a row the rate of growth of the Australian economy will increase in 1980-81, despite a drought and depressed international economic conditions which will restrict the growth of our exports in the current year. Therefore, as we head for a 3 1/2 per cent increase in non-farm production for 1980-81 this growth will be based more on domestic factors than on export growth, as has been the case in recent years. In other words, the policies of this Governmnent have meant that domestic demand or the ability, the willingness and the confidence of people to spend and to invest their money has increased substantially.

After allowing for inflation, private consumption expenditure will increase by some 3 per cent this year. Retail sales have increased strongly, as have motor vehicle sales. In the area of investment expenditure, it is not exaggerating to say that we have an investment boom on our hands. I have quoted already some figures to support that. The present situation is a far cry from the early and mid-1970s when investment fell each year. So to those in the Labor Party who say that our present economic strength-this has been said during this debate-is due to the lucky historical fact that we are rich in natural resources, I would say three things: Firstly, we are facing a strong, broadly-based economic growth, not just in the natural resources sector, which has resulted from strong domestically sourced demand. Secondly, I would say that this is despite the unlucky occurrence of drought and the depressed international market. In that context I would like to quote from a speech given by the Secretary to the Treasury in a recent address to the National Agricultural Outlook Conference. When he was referring to the drought and to the international scene he said:

I might say of these otherwise unwelcome changes that had they not occurred we would currently be facing in Australia what might almost be described as an economic 'boom' of a kind we have nearly forgotten.

In that context it is interesting to note that when in office the Labor Government blamed its poor economic performance on a depressed international economy, whilst this Government, also confronted by a poor international economy, has still succeeded on the domestic economic front. The third point I make to honourable members opposite is that it is not sufficient for a country like Australia to assume that natural endowments automatically make it lucky. We have to have the right policies. After all, these resources were in Australia in the period 1972-75. This Government has achieved the present state of economic recovery because it has applied the kinds of policies which create the incentives and the overall economic environment in which people are prepared to invest their money in all sectors of the Australian economy. It is as simple as that. There has not been any Keynesian growth from the private sector.

Let us consider other economic indicators which have contributed to and resulted from this economic growth. It is important to note that the Government succeeded in attaining a single digit inflation rate for 1980. The rate of 9.3 per cent, although still too high, makes our record better than that of most other countries; the average inflation rate of countries in the industrialised world is about 12.4 per cent. I think we all agree that the level of unemployment in this country is higher than any of us would wish. Nevertheless, the employment situation has continued to improve, according to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force figures.

Although the Opposition likes to cite figures of the Commonwealth Employment Service because they show a higher level of unemployment, the fact remains that the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures are more accurate indicators of employment trends. Successive surveys conducted over a long period have shown that CES figures greatly overstate the unemployment situation because they include those persons who have already found work during the month and some who are no longer in the labour force at the end of the month for which the figures are extracted. The ABS and CES assessments of the employment situation are based on different definitions and different methods of collection and they relate to different periods within the month. The definition used by the ABS coincides with accepted international conventions, whereas that used by the CES does not.

The past two years have seen a significant strengthening of the labour market. In the 12 months to December 1980 the number of people in employment rose by 169,000. The January 1981 labour force figures show that 140,000 more people were employed in this country in January 1981 than were employed a year ago. In the two years to January this year the number of people employed increased by 279,200. The preliminary labour force figures for February of this year show that the number of full time unemployed people fell by 17,900 over the year from February 1980. That figure shows a much improved result when compared with the figures for 1980 and 1979. The position of teenagers seeking their first jobs continued to follow the encouraging trend shown in January of this year.

As I said, the level of unemployment certainly remains too high, despite the substantial increase in the number of people employed. This can be partly explained by the increasing work force participation rate which last year stood at 61.3 per cent, compared with 60.4 per cent in August 1979. That means basically that this increase has resulted in something like 100,000 people becoming employed without in any way reducing unemployment levels. This occurs simply because additional people have entered the labour market as employment and economic prospects have improved. I think this trend will continue because although Australia has one of the highest work force participation rates of all member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development at the present time, there is still scope for this rate to increase further, based on our recent experience. We have every reason to expect this growth in employment opportunities to continue in the foreseeable future as major resource development projects come on stream.

The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner), in his speech to Parliament in December last year, said that a direct employment growth of something like 60,000 jobs would result from such projects over the next five years. Of course, indirect growth in employment opportunities resulting from these projects will be much greater. Those honourable members opposite who always oppose foreign investment and multinational companies would do well to ponder the positive employment effects of the record foreign investment of something like $2.9 billion in Australia last year. That ultimately will filter through the whole economy into all sectors of industry and will help to provide the surpluses necessary for the future expansion of the economy to the benefit of all Australians. To the critics of natural resource development I suggest also that they look at a State by State breakup of the employment figures. They will find that the States of New South Wales, Western Australia and Queensland-those most affected by resource based developments-have experienced the strongest growth in employment figures.

In summary, Australia has now recovered to a point where its economy is once again at the forefront of economies of the industrialised world. I suggest to the Government that it should keep on course. Present economic problems are not due to the overall thrust of the Government's present economic policies but rather to the fact that those policies have not been applied more consistently. I suggest that too heavy a reliance on any particular economic weapon will lead to economic distortions of a kind which will only impede future economic recovery. I believe we should seek a more appropriate mix of monetary, fiscal, tariff and wage policies. In the past the Government, by failing to take sufficient budgetary and tariff action, has allowed the burden of fighting inflation to fall too heavily on monetary policy, which has led to the present interest rate increases.

If anyone has any doubts about the connection between all arms of economic policy, he need look no further than the present situation to dispel those doubts. Successive Budget deficits have increased the public sector borrowing requirement to such an extent that home buyers are now feeling the pinch. Yet honourable members opposite in this debate have said that we adopt a callous approach to government because we want to control government expenditure and reduce Budget deficits. I think all home buyers in Australia who are currently facing increased mortgage repayments as a result of the rise in interest rates will be interested to know that the Opposition in this debate has constantly advocated higher government expenditure and larger Budget deficits-the very things which in the long run lead to higher interest rates simply because the Government has to compete for borrowings to finance the deficits. As the demand for funds increases, so does the price of the borrowings-the interest rates.

The Government has been slowly getting the budgetary situation under control but the cumulative deficits of previous years are imposing an incredible burden on many people through these increased interest rates. That makes it even more imperative for the Government to exercise greater control over the Budget in the future. All in all, although the economy still has troubles, almost all available indicators show that economic recovery in this country is well under way and that the policies of the Government over the past five years are working. For that reason, I am pleased to support the Address-in-Reply to the Speech of the Governor-General, moved by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), and I reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when crucial decisions about the development of Australian mineral and energy resources need to be made, the policy of this Government as outlined in the Governor-General's Speech makes disappointing and depressing reading. This Government simply lacks any concept of what constitutes the long term national interests of Australia. It believes that foreign investment is inherently good, regardless of how, why and where the investment is made. It believes that the majority of Australians have no right to share in their country's mineral wealth. We live in what is potentially the wealthiest country on earth. We have vast mineral and energy resources, a highly skilled population and a surplus of agricultural production. Yet we are well down the world list in terms of living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: The sell-out to foreign investment by post-war Tory governments has already cost us dearly. The distribution of wealth and income in our community is becoming more lopsided every day. Now that we are poised on the brink of a further expansion of mineral and energy industries due to our fortuitous endowment of cheap energy reserves, we have a critical choice to make. We could take the Tory path and leave our resources to foreign corporations. That way we would create a few overnight millionaires, a handful of jobs, a trickle of royalties for 20 or 30 years and a lot of environmental problems. On the other hand, we could be more discerning in our attitude to foreign investment.

We could follow the path of many European nations, Japan, and lately other Asian countries such as Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia and India, and develop our own corporations with minimal dependence of foreign equity. We could use our strength as a major supplier of raw materials to strike a better bargain from foreign investment proposals. We could insist on technology transfer to Australian control as the price for exploitation of our resources. We could insist on further downstream processing, research and development within this country. We could disentangle the corporate web used by transnational corporations to deprive the Government of adequate information and to cheat it of fair tax and royalty payments. All we need is a government with foresight and understanding and we will make decisions.

The deficiencies in Australia's past foreign investment policies are well described in a paper which was delivered last year to the Australian Mining and Petroleum Law Association by Mr Paul Grant of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Grant found that State and Federal governments accepted virtually without question the package deal foreign investment proposals offered by foreign corporations. This package deal involves equity funding, technology transfer, local production and export of selected products to selected markets. No thought is given by the Government to dissecting the foreign proposals to achieve a more equitable deal for this country. Mr Grant also concluded that the three Australian parties involved in negotiation of foreign investment proposals, namely, the Federal and State governments and local companies, do not work together and are, therefore, readily played off one against the other by the foreign corporations concerned. In other words, Australia gains the lowest common multiple in foreign investment.

What makes the situation worse is that the Federal and State governments not only readily acquiesce in foreign investment package deals but also are unconcerned about their long term implications. It is not difficult to find reasons for foreign corporations being anxious to impose package deal proposals on Australia. Under the proposals offered by these corporations, technology is held securely under their control and not disseminated further within this country. The threat of future competition is thus overcome. Local processing and exports are limited to suit the disposition of the foreign corporation's plants in other countries. Further, favourable transfer pricing between plants and nations to minimise local tax and royalty payments is available to the vertically integrated corporation. It has taken us a long time to overhaul section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Technology transfer is a vital but ignored consideration in the evaluation of foreign investment. Norwegian involvement in deep sea oil exploration provides a good example of how foreign investment can be used to nurture a new domestic industry. The Norwegians welcomed multinational oil exploration, but insisted upon the involvement of local companies in the exploitation of any reserves. Once there was an indication of substantial off-shore oil and gas reserves, the Norwegian Government made it a condition of further exploration that a Norwegian partner be taken on in a situation where it could pick up the technology of off-shore oil rig design, construction and operation.

A four-party joint venture was established involving the foreign corporation, an established oil marketing company, a consortium of Norwegian ship builders and the original Norwegian exploration partner. The massive investment required on behalf of the Norwegian companies, particularly in the construction of the off-shore oil rigs, was organised through the national banking system on a totally unprecendented scale. The result was that within a few years the Norwegian partners led the world in off-shore rig design and had developed a major industry building rigs for other nations, particularly those bordering on the North Sea. It is ironic to note that the first Russian discovery of off-shore oil was made by a Norwegian rig manned by a Norwegian crew. If Norway provides a classic study of how foreign investment can be used to advance a host nation, foreign involvement in the Australian aluminium industry provides a perfect case of the cost of mishandled foreign investment in this country.

When proposals to produce aluminium in Australia were first made after World War I, they had to be shelved because of the ease with which the international aluminium cartel could destroy the new local industry. Even when World War II and a world-wide shortage of aluminium forced Commonwealth involvement in aluminium production, the design and construction of a plant was delayed by the refusal of Alcoa to provide the expertise. It was left to the CSIRO, with British help, to develop an Australian designed Bayer-Hall process. An Australian aluminium commission was formed in 1944, and an extensive survey of bauxite reserves was undertaken. A plant was finally commissioned, after five years of construction, at Bell Bay, Tasmania, in 1955. The plant was operated jointly by the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments for several years before being sold to two transnational corporations.

Following this sale a number of aluminium smelters and alumina refineries were constructed in Australia by foreign corporations. The refinery constructed at Kwinana by Alcoa was a typical case. Originally the Australian-owned Western Mining Corporation Ltd began negotiations with Alcoa for the construction of this Bayer-Hall process refinery. Western Mining fought hard to retain control in Australian hands by bringing in two other Australian partners to make up the local equity, but had to concede control because of Alcoa's dominant position in the technology. Much the same situation had occurred earlier with the Gladstone refinery. It was repeated in the Bayer process alumina refinery at Gove where the major shareholding went to Swiss Aluminium Aust. Ltd. because of its position in controlling the technology of production. The efforts of Australian scientists and technologists and the foresight of the wartime Labor Government went down the drain. This shameful episode was summarised by Grant in the following manner:

We have the same technology-the Bayer process- being the subject of three separate international transfers in three different direct foreign investment packages (that is, being paid for three times), when the same technology had been worked-up and operated at full scale by the government before any of the transfers were made. Not only that, but it is clear that the technological base in each case now lies outside Australia so that significant process development no longer occurs in Australia and none of the three companies operating alumina refineries in Australia is either capable of or empowered to transfer that technology to another country. It is possible, therefore, to argue that the massive international transfer of technology which has occurred has effectively deprived Australia of that very technology.

This is a shocking indictment of Australian foreign investment policies and a repudiation of the political philosophy of this Government and past Liberal governments. The same sorry story could be told about the mineral sands industry where wartime development could have provided the basis of an industry producing titanium dioxide pigment. The nature of other recent foreign investment proposals should also set the alarm bells ringing for any concerned government. Almost every day the large international oil companies are swallowing up our mineral and energy resources, particularly coal and oil shale. Oil shale technology and oil-from-coal technology are obviously areas where Australia could develop a key industry if the Government were to lead the way. The sell-out of the Rundle shale oil reserves to Exxon already has probably put paid to any such viable industry led by Australia. We ought to remember by studying the history of the matter that the same oil companies which rejected research and development into these technologies after the War are now quietly but insidiously closing off the option of an Australian-based industry by tying up key reserves of oil shale and suitable coal.

We no longer keep statistics on the level of foreign investment and control in Australia. We cannot even establish the extent of the problem. We also have the situation in which foreign investors are obtaining an increasing share of the few major Australian mining companies such as Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd, Western Mining Corporation Ltd, Peko-Wallsend Ltd and CSR Ltd, via bank nominee companies. Honourable members opposite should take into account that there is no provision in the current companies and securities legislation to cover that predicament. The provision has been taken out. Up to a quarter of each of these Australian companies is now owned by bank nominee companies which are in turn dominated by off-shore interests. The proportion of shares in major Australian mining companies which are held by nominee companies has increased steadily over the past two or three years yet we do not know which foreign interests are behind these moves, and there is no legislation to block them.

For example, in the case of Pancontinental Mining Ltd we do not even know the true ownership of the company because eight of the 10 largest shareholders are nominee companies holding 41 per cent of the shares. How can any minimum ownership requirement have any value when true ownership cannot be assessed or disclosed? Although the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has powers under the Companies (Foreign Take-overs) Act-if my memory serves me correctly the powers are contained in section 26-to require disclosure of the persons or corporations on whose behalf an interest is held by nominee companies, he has not found it necessary to exercise this power. I predict that he will never use it. In effect, the Government is turning a blind eye to major overseas investors acquiring substantial interests in major Australian companies through nominee companies. Whilst no government would dare to allow these Australian companies to fall to foreign investors in an open market takeover, this Government is allowing the same process to occur through the back door method.

In conclusion let me say that there is no shortage of solutions or overseas examples to follow to ensure that development of Australian resources provides the optimum advantage to this country. Frankly, what is needed is a government that will rekindle the faith in Australia's know-how which led to early pre-eminence in technology such as we had in a number of areas before, during and after the last war. We need a government which will take the initiative to promote Australian pro- jects with the same zeal that led to the Snowy Mountains scheme and other great projects of the past. I remind honourable gentlemen opposite that, when we talk about statutory bodies and government agencies, the Snowy Mountains scheme was allocated the sum of $800m. At completion of the project, that is precisely how much was spent.

We need a government which will set up government supported marketing agencies in the mineral products area to assist Australian companies to secure long term contracts without having to rely on foreign corporations, particularly those that are vertically integrated. We need a government which will back schemes to finance major industrial development projects to minimise dependence on foreign equity. We ought to do this. Other advanced countries of the world can do it; why cannot we do this? We need a government which will gear the substantial government supported scientific and technical resources in Australia to assist the generation of suitable locally owned investment vehicles, that is, enterprises equipped with the financial, technical, marketing and entrepreneurial skills to undertake direct investments. We need a government which will extract a much better deal from foreign investors using our considerable resources as a lever. This ought to be our source of strength, not our source of weakness.

Finally, and most importantly, we need a government which will redistribute the great wealth that can be generated from our natural resources much more equitably. The Government has an obligation to do so; it ought not hesitate to do so. Regrettably, the Speech of the Governor-General reveals that this Government will continue its short-sighted and dogmatic faith in foreign investment at any cost. Such a thrust ultimately will lead to disaster. The speech reveals that this Government stands as the main impediment to a more prosperous Australia. The Government cannot be trusted to protect the interests of all Australians. I thank the honourable member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham) for allowing me the opportunity to speak in this debate earlier than I was originally to participate.

SPEECH.PARA: It was my privilege to occupy the portfolio of Minister for the Northern Territory in a very historic era. Firstly, following the devastation of Darwin by Cyclone Tracy, my role was to work for the reconstruction and rebuilding of that great city, working closely with the Darwin Reconstruction Commission. I pay particular tribute to those who have probably received too scant a recognition in that tragedy and in the tremendous task of reconstruction. Firstly, I pay tribute to the members of the Cyclone Tracy Relief Trust Fund, a body of citizens of Darwin of all political complexions. I believe that this nation owes a very hearty vote of thanks to them. Theirs was an unenviable task. They had suffered tragedy and loss. They often were the victims of unfair and unwarranted criticism. Yet the manner in which they handled the funds of the Trust to relieve distress, worry and hardship was magnificent. If ever any part of Australia again suffers such a national disaster, that Trust has provided a blueprint of administration and action which could well provide splendid guidance for any such committee of the future.

In the massive task of reconstruction, many people played a magnificant role. I pay particular tribute to two men and record my deepest appreciation in the records of this Parliament and in the history of this nation. It may surprise honourable members to know that the first person is the Chairman of the Darwin Reconstruction Commission, Mr Clem Jones. He was appointed by my predecessor, the Honourable Rex Patterson, and although our political ideologies do not coincide, in retrospect I feel that it was an excellent appointment. Indeed, the way he harnessed and co-operated with private enterprise to do the job was an eye-opener. The speed and the standards of the greatest task of rebuilding Australia has ever faced owes much to the leadership of Clem Jones. I place on record my appreciation of the absolute loyalty and support which he gave me while I was Minister. With him was the Deputy Secretary of the Department of the Northern Territory, Frank Dwyer-a legend in the Territory. He too was involved in that great task. It was very sad indeed to learn of his death a few days ago. The Northern Territory owes very much to Frank Dwyer. I interpose here also that in both of my ministries I count myself most fortunate in the secretaries of the respective departments, namely, Mr Ray Livingston and Sir Richard Kingsland.

Also, in that role as Minister for the Northern Territory, it was my good fortune to activate and complete the commitment of the Government to take the Northern Territory to self-government. The Government foresaw a timespan of five years to achieve this; in fact, it was accomplished in less than three years. In this House we have heard of some of the architects and champions of Territorian self-government. I will not go through that noble list again. However, the tremendous contribution and co-operation of Goff Letts and his deputy, Grant Tambling, who now very ably represents the Northern Territory in this House, must be recorded. Add to this the grand contribution of Sam Calder, a friend of all of us, and we see the quality of the Territorians who have been in the vanguard. The present Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, assumed the reins of office and saw the goal finally achieved. He has very capably led the Territory into an exciting new era, already bearing the hallmarks of success and achievement.

The role of Administrator of the Northern Territory was both central and crucial to the attainment and consolidation of self-government. Territorians, irrespective of their politics, join with me in paying a tribute to John England, who has just retired from that position, for his magnificent and completely dedicated service as Administrator. Side by side with his wonderful wife, Polly, he attracted the respect, admiration and love of all Territorians-and I say that advisedly. I wonder whether history will ever adequately record the sterling and splendid service that that couple rendered to the Territory. I am confident that the Territory has a great future. That is why I felt it appropriate to pay these brief tributes to men and women who have played these important roles in the building of the Territory and have made that future success a certainty.

I turn to an aspect of government legislation and planning which is of considerable importance. That is the adoption of the new two-airline agreement. I do not propose to canvass much of the debate which has already occurred in this House and elsewhere. I simply recognise that by the very geography of our nation, the vast distances and the decentralisation we face somewhat unique particular conditions. Recognising too that we rightly demand the most rigid safety standards, efficient and convenient services, and high quality aircraft to provide both speed and comfort, I believe that the two-airline policy has been necessary and has achieved these desires. I further recognise that, with the very great expenditure on new aircraft and the proper insistence of the Government that remote areas and distant States must be properly served, we can only sustain our insistence on service beyond the most commercially profitable short haul journeys by some fair agreement. Thus, I do not seek to contend that a two-airline agreement should be abandoned.

The point which must be carefully pondered is the role of regional airlines and their fair treatment. The trunk routes are preserved for two airlines and other operators, such as East-West Airlines Ltd, Bush Pilots Airways Ltd and others cannot intrude. However, much of our nation away from those trunk routes is serviced by such operators. They have pioneered services and routes and have developed them. If they desire to go into jet aircraft, they do not receive the guarantees of government that others receive. Of course, they are subject to government export controls. If they are precluded from the trunk routes, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines must play the game on other routes.

For instance, I would deplore a repetition of the Sydney-Maroochydore saga, which is not the only occasion when such a situation has occurred. I believe that many years ago Ansett operated a Sydney-Maroochydore service but abandoned it for economic reasons. So East-West instituted a regular Fokker service between those centres, and popularised and developed it. With the growth of the Sunshine Coast, a daily service was provided, and additional services were provided in holiday periods. Serious consideration was even given by East-West, in view of the use of the run, to proceeding to use jet aircraft to service the route. With Norfolk Island and other routes, that degree of viability seemed promising. However, Ansett then came in with Fokkers and provided a daily service and extra aircraft. This capitalised on East-West's development and reduced its revenue. Certainly, it is great to have so many aircraft flying from Sydney to Maroochydore and the beautiful Sunshine Coast but, of course, the jets did not materialise and, whether justified or not, the suspicion has been voiced that the action was at least influenced by the possibility of East-West acquiring jet aircraft. So, without wanting to be a protagonist in that controversy, as a Queenslander I emphasise that our regional airlines which serve, and have served, much of our State off the trunk routes faithfully and well-often not with great profitability-must not be sacrificed or betrayed on the altar of expediency in the attainment of a new two-airline agreement.

Might I now turn to our commitment to recognise 1981 as the International Year of Disabled Persons. This must not take the form of a barrage of slogans, pious platitudes and propaganda. We will be judged by our actions rather than our words. There is always much publicity when we send athletes to the Olympic Games or international games, or to participate in Commonwealth Games. Quite rightly, Federal and State governments and other sponsors contribute handsomely to assist the athletes to participate. I applaud that. However, many such athletes then become professionals and do not always devote their time and endeavours to promoting amateur sport and assisting others to develop their athletic potential. This is not a blanket condemnation, but on occasions the rich rewards of professionalism dim the memory of the contributions by taxpayers and citizens which helped them along the path to that goal. My plea is for the disabled. These people also love sport and international and interstate competition. They will not become professionals but participation enriches their enjoyment of life. Because of their disabilities, most of them are not in very favourable economic circumstances. Often they are on low salaries or social security benefits, yet if there are paraplegic games, blind games, deaf games and so on, how ready are we, as governments, sponsors or citizens, to be generous enough to provide sufficient funds to help them to participate?

Sadly, as I have spoken to blind, deaf or disabled friends about particular international sports meetings in which they would dearly love to participate, I have repeatedly heard them say that they could not possibly afford to go. If an athlete cannot afford to go to the Olympic Games, the media and the community make quite a stir and start a fund to get him there. That is fair enough, but contrast that athlete's position with that of the disabled person who, more often than not, just has to stay to home. Perhaps I have said enough to pose to parliaments, governments and the community, in this year of the disabled, the question: Have we got our priorities right? That, too, is why I have on the Notice Paper a question, as yet unanswered, asking whether, in our provision of national and State sporting and other centres, we are providing facilities to accommodate the disabled. They too like sport and participation in athletics.

I turn now to a particular and large group of disabled people, the deaf. As they live in a lonely world of silence, they are largely ignored. Because communication is difficult, most people become impatient and unsympathetic with them and finally push them out. The tragedy of deafness is often sadly increased by our own unthinking, cruel sense of humour. If we relate Irish jokes, Jewish jokes or jokes that are offensive to any ethnic group, we are rightly and properly condemned. Such jokes are hurtful, insulting and wrong. Yet how often is deafness, with the ridiculous ear trumpet illustrated, the butt of jokes. Just think about how spiteful and hurtful that sort of humour appears to those who suffer from this terrible disability.

I want to put forcibly and earnestly to the Government two propositions. I could put many more, and probably will, but two in particular stand out. Let me give an illustration. Recently there was on the Sunshine Coast the threat of a cyclone. Warnings were issued of flooding and possible disastrous wind gusts, precautions were frequently advised and so on. But how were they issued? They were issued by radio, which the deaf cannot hear, and by television. I was in close contact with a profoundly deaf young couple. Every little while the well-known cyclone warning symbol came onto their television screen. They saw the well-dressed announcer and assumed that he was giving up-to-date warnings and information. All they could do was admire the cut of his suit and his tie. They could not understand a word that he said. Our television companies do not flash captions or sign language on the screen to help such persons. That is a travesty. Picture the concern and fear of that young couple. I made countless trips to their home to tell them of the precautions being advised. But if it had rained much more the road would have been cut and I would not have been able to get through. Yet there is an attachment which can be added to, or built into, a television set. In Queensland, it is called Seventel. By the flick of a switch, the viewer can get on his screen a print-out of such things as police warnings, cyclone warnings, news, sports results and many other messages which we with full hearing take for granted. Most deaf people cannot afford Seventel, which is very dear, but we add to its cost by levying on such attachments and sets a hefty sales tax. There is no morality or justification for doing that. The Government should remove sales tax on those attachments immediately for cases in which the purchaser produces a medical certificate of profound deafness. If the Government does not do so let us not trumpet platitudes about our concern for the disabled.

The other matter concerns the teleprinter telephone, about which I have also placed a question on notice. This phone has a print-out, so that a deaf person can use the receiver to converse with others who have a similar receiver in their home. They can receive a printed conversation record back from them. Such a receiver should be provided in every police station, ambulance centre, medical centre and office of a State and Federal government department set up to serve the community. Indeed, I hope that it will be provided in many commercial establishments, stores and public telephone booths also. The telephone is a lifeline, a means of calling for help, a method of communication which we take for granted and sometimes curse because it never stops ringing, but why can we not open up these lines of communication to the deaf. Such receivers are very dear. The answer of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) quotes their cost as $800 to $1000. They are not of much use to the deaf unless similar receivers are provided in the places to which I have referred by way of illustration. Surely we must get off our seats and do something to help many disabled Australians who have been pushed into a corner and forgotten. If that $800 to $1,000 includes sales tax payable by the deaf the tax should be immediately waived on production of a medical certificate of profound deafness.

All around us are disabled people with all sorts of disabilities. We are making a great noise about this year showing our concern for them. It is great to sing 'Break down the barriers' but let us do it, not just sing it. Governments have their part to play, their credibility to prove, and I urge them to face that responsibility, as should every Australian citizen. Very much has been achieved over the years for those with disabilities but very much more has yet to be done. The Bible, a book that I love, says that it is by our deeds and not by our words that we will be judged. I wonder how we will be judged by the disabled on 31 December 1981 in relation to our sincerity about bringing into the community the disabled who for so long have been shut out. However, our concern, compassion and action must not cease at this year's end or we will be rightly identifiable by bandwagon hypocrites going through an exercise to salve our consciences with the least possible inconvenience. Our responsibilities are not discharged by buying a raffle ticket or two, or by giving a dollar or two for tax deduction purposes to a collector because there, but for the grace of God, go we.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to touch on a number of matters that have been raised in the Governor-General's Speech and which have a bearing on the general philosophies of the Government. Indeed, that speech was a fairly good summary of the philosophies of the Australian Government. Some of the speakers in this debate from the Government side have warned against increasing the deficit because, they say, that is irresponsible. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is on record as having said several times that to increase the deficit would be irresponsible; it is like a housewife spending more than her housekeeping money. Of course, he is concealing from the Australian people and from the Parliament-possibly from himself-the fact that Federal Budgets include an item which does not occur in the well balanced State Budgets; namely, capital expenditure. It is completely misleading to represent a deficit, on account of expanded capital investment in the interests of the Australian people, as being irresponsible budgeting if it is funded by responsible borrowing and responsibly repaid by the posterity that will get the benefits of that capital investment. In just the same way it is not irresponsible for a family, or household, to go into debt to pay off a home which is something that will be an increasing asset to them and to future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the economic theories that seem to be espoused particularly by the National Country Party, which has seized on this marvellous concept of a 20 per cent flat rate tax as an ultimate objective, is that of the Laffer curve. This gentleman, Laffer, has come up with the remarkable discovery that if we do not tax incomes at all, revenue from income tax is nil and if we put a 100 per cent tax on incomes revenue is nil because nobody will work to gain income which is 100 per cent taxed. Therefore, the rate of tax has to be somewhere between nought and 100 per cent. He has capitalised on that remarkable discovery. Of course he and the National Country Party followers are using this to prove, in their view, that our rates of tax are too high. Nowhere does the shape of the Laffer curve indicate that. It does not even indicate that we will get maximum revenue if the level of income tax is set at 50 per cent. The curve does not have to be of Sabrina-like symmetry; it may be that the highest revenue comes from an income tax level of below 50 per cent, as the National Country Party suggests, but it may well be that revenue will be higher if it is pitched at 80 per cent. Other countries have demonstrated efficiency and achievement in economic management far in advance of anything this country has achieved under conservative governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones?

—Sweden is an excellent example. That high rate of tax was introduced over a period of about a quarter of a century, about the same period that we had conservative governments in this country achieving none of those economic goals. In fact, they presided over records of just about every economic indicator-records of bad achievement. There was a level of inflation of 22 per cent under the Menzies Government and under the Fraser Government we have the worst post-Depression unemployment rate. The Government has also espoused another Messiah in the economic catalogue of saints, Milton Friedman, who assures us that the way to prosperity and salvation in times of stagflation and the like is to cut government expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the arch disciple of the Friedman philosophy would be Mrs Margaret Thatcher. This week a statement, released by over 70 per cent of the leading economists in Britain, told her that she was going the wrong way and that she should go back. They told her that she has to start increasing government expenditure in certain directions, with certain discrimination, if she is to stop the stagnation that is the major affliction of the British economy, despite its high achievement in resources development with North Sea oil. Not only is that the case with North Sea oil, but also Britain has a record output in agricultural produce. It exports agricultural products that a few years ago had to be imported. It hardly relies at all on the food imports on which it relied when Australia was one of its main suppliers. Another dogma of conservative governments is that they are low tax governments and that Labor Party governments are high tax governments. The Government frequently propounds this by referring to the rate of increase of revenues under the Labor Government, completely ignoring the increase in the gross domestic product-particularly in the social dividend that Australian's received from the Labor Government compared with conservative governments-and ignoring entirely the fact that the increased revenues that a future Labor government would propose to take would not be out of the pockets of the ordinary citizens of Australia, as we are continually being told in this place. Our proposals are not to increase the load on the low and middle income earners but to take it from those who have the capacity to pay and who ought to be paying.

The theme of the speech of the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) could be summed up by saying that Australian Labor Party policy is not against the marriage of foreign capital with local capital, and we are not against the marriage of public and private enterprise. We pioneered it. We brought in the General Motors company in partnership with the Australian Holden team. Under the Fraser and Menzies governments the attitude has been to let the foreign people take over. The Labor Party introduced a marriage between State and Federal enterprise in Australia's first aluminium refinery. Our successors sold it out to their great and powerful friends in the private sector. We are not even against polygamy of capital. Whether one happens to be a Moslem, a Mormon or an Aboriginal who believes in polygamy, we do not mind if one wants to marry foreign and local private capital with public capital. Australian Labor Party governments are not against private enterprise absolutely, as has been alleged in debate tonight, particularly by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume). What we are against is indiscriminate prostitution of capital. That is what the Government is hellbent on achieving. We do not mind being pastors to preside over any kinds of company marriages. We do object to this Government assuming the role of a pimp to prostitute Australia's resources to the plunderers, the multinational companies.

An example of the Government's obsession with blindly opposing at all costs anything that comes from the working class or the people who at the moment are receiving, and since 1975 have been receiving, a decreasing share of the increasing wealth of this country, is the millions of dollars that it is going to spend on a promotion to convince the Australian people that if everybody worked 35 hours a week, we would be worse off. The Australian people do not have to be convinced of that. The Australian Council of Trade Unions does not have to be convinced of that because it has been saying that for years and it has never said anything different. The Australian Labor Party does not have to be convinced of that. We have said that an immediate move to a 35-hour working week across the board in all industries would be silly, suicidal and harmful. We have agreed. Apparently in promoting this propaganda the Government is not trying to persuade people of that self-evident fact, but is trying to persuade them that what it is opposing is something that has been promoted by the alternative government and by the trade unions-in other words, to create hatred and division in the Australian community, to paint unions as devils and to paint the Australian Labor Party as the dupe of those devils. In fact, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) said in his speech this evening: 'If only we could get the devil out of the labour market, we would solve unemployment'. Here was his great formula: The honourable member said that we should stop overtime payments for weekend work in the leisure industry, give people premium payments for night work but not on weekends. We should import skilled tradesmen and persuade the unions to let more mature age people become skilled so that we would not have to pay bigger margins to skilled people, because if we did, there would be a flow-on to the unskilled. That is a cirular argument. On the one hand, we must keep down the margins for the skilled people so that other people will not want to reduce those margins, but on the other hand we must not train young Australians to help the unemployment situation. We must train mature age people and bring in migrants. I do not think that he has thought out his figuring too well there.

Of course, the 35-hour working week stance of the Government, its blindness and its one-eyed approach to this argument, tie up with its usual approach to the umpire. We have explained this on many occasions in other situations. The Government uses the term 'industrial blackmail' when the unions strive to use the open labour market, the very labour market that the honourable member for MacKellar wants to get the devil out of. The Government says: 'But you should go to the umpire. You should go to conciliation or to arbitration'. Of course, in many cases the unions are not allowed to do that as the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will not hear their cases unless there is already a dispute; so they do not have much choice. Sometimes they cannot even consult the umpire. But when they do, such as in the case involving Altona Petrochemical Co. Ltd, and have argued a reasonable deal and package-the same sort of thing that would occur in collective bargaining in the open market, or in the free labour market-the arbitrators agreed that the deal was a fair one and that the industry would benefit not only by shorter hours of work but also by the increased productivity arrangements that the employees entered into in return for those shorter hours. But the Government does not want to abide by the decision of the umpire. It wants to brainwash people into believing that the umpire was biased, that the unions were using industrial blackmail and that the Austalian Labor Party is irresponsible. In other words, there is no virtue in any decision which disproves the Government's own bigoted, ideological preconceptions.

The Government has broken not only its promises of abiding by what the umpire says but also has used industrial blackmail in the case of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. In effect, by its amendments to the Act it has shot the umpire. The Government has taken away from Commonwealth employees only their right of appeal on redeployment and retrenchment. It has deprived them of any right of appeal. Not only has the Government broken promises in that regard but also, as I think Senator Chipp totted up, it has broken over 70 other promises. I will not go through the broken promises again in detail, but the common ones that have been raised in this debate include employment, interests rates, inflation, Medibank, tax, small government, Aboriginal welfare, general social welfare and ministerial jobs. Even today another broken promise has been raised. There is an article in the Canberra Times entitled 'Doubts over future of institute. ''Broken Promises'' anger director'. Mr Don Talbot, the executive director of the Australian Institute of Sports says:
If I was a gambler . . . I wouldn't bet on the institute surviving.

I am not saying that the Australian Institute of Sport is vital for those in need in Australia. I agree with the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Adermann) who made a very able speech this evening on the need to help the disabled to take part in sport. I do not think that leading the world in winning gold medals, competitiveness and professional sport is a major priority. But participation of the disabled in sport and other fields surely should have some assistance. This was a promise. The then Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Ellicott, a Christian gentleman who is active in the parliamentary Christian assemblage, a man of honour who has been appointed to a court by this Government, promised that this Institute would go ahead. Have the promises been fulfilled? The director of the Institute has no confidence in its survival. Yet the Government helps Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd. Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, Ansett Airlines of Australia, the Utah company, Comalco Ltd, Alcan Australia Ltd and the Pechiney company. To any of these big companies, the Government says: 'We need you'. The old pimp is at it again.

It is just like when Prime Minister Gorton said in less extreme terms: 'We are like a puppy with its four legs in the air saying ''please, please, tickle my tummy''. Give us foreign capital under any conditions'. That is exactly what the honourable member for Hawker told us. It is not only Liberal Party of Australia leaders who have told us that. A former Country Party Prime Minister, Sir John McEwen said: 'We are like a farmer who sells a little of the farm each year to try to stay out of debt'. What a way to pay off a mortgage. This is the Government that talks about balancing the Budget. There are many other issues that I could raise and would like to raise, particularly relating to foreign affairs. But I think I will content myself, in the one minute left to me, with drawing attention to a very significant article by Ivan Illich in the Co-Evaluation Quarterly. It starts with a letter dated 12 April 1980, in which he talks about vernacular values.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters on the adjournment debate tonight, both of which I find of extreme concern. I hope that the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) will investigate the second matter at a later stage. The first matter concerns the Geelong Aboriginal Co-operative Society. Twelve months ago it obtained funding to conduct a drop-in centre for the Aboriginal community in the Geelong area.
