No further funds will be made available to the Co-operative.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the group has been treated very badly. It has been given little or no opportunity to prove the success of the venture which a small number of Aboriginal people, banding together in a self-help honorary manner, have tried very hard to make work. After only one year of funding the organistaion is now to be chopped off as a cost saving measure by the Commonwealth and State Aboriginal affairs administrations. The reasons for non-funding are vague, to say the least. There seems to be some suggestion of prejudice against individuals at the levels at which recommendations are made. I believe that this matter should be investigated by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in another place. When decisions are made to support projects which will obviously require continuing funding, that support should be forthcoming for a reasonable period so that the organisation can establish whether it is able to operate a viable and worthwhile community service. To drop the funding at the end of the first year is unreasonable. It would have been better not to have commenced the scheme in the first place. Governments have asked for and accepted from people work in good faith. Expectations which have been created have not been met.

The other matter I raise arises out of certain changes in the types of insulin available to diabetics in Australia. This House has seen a number of petitions over recent weeks relating to changeovers in syringes and other equipment that are necessary because of the change from insulins of varying strengths of 40, 80 or 120 to a standard 100 strength insulin. Costs are involved. The old types of syringes are less than satisfactory. I think as a general principle that people whose incomes are not adequate should be assisted. All people on low incomes are the most disadvantaged in this situation. They may require certain life support systems. Insulin is a life support system for those who require it. Similar difficulties exist in relation to other surgical aids such as colostomy bags. The free medical service scheme will pay to take out part of a person's bowel but it will not provide the wherewithal to allow a person to continue to function. That is a cost of living which people have to bear.

There are now medical reports that the 100 strength insulin has effects which are less than satisfactory, so the change to a standard strength which has taken place may not be useful. I ask that the matter be drawn to the attention of the Minister for Health because it is reported that the stronger insulin will not pass through the small vessels through which it must pass in order to react.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read with interest in the latest bulletin of the Australian Industries Development Association the article entitled 'The Burgeoning Cost of Welfare'. This Association with a powerful voice is calling on the Federal Government to reduce welfare expenditure. The article accepts that such a reduction would be politically sensitive and advises its being done in a cushioning and gradual way. But the whole emphasis of the article is on cutting the amount of money spent on welfare so that the tax burden is alleviated. The paper calls on Government Ministers to be bold and to support Sir Phillip Lynch's razor gang in reducing expenditure. It advises the reintroduction of the means test for pensioners aged 70 or over. It advises an income test for family allowances based on the joint income of husband and wife. It further advises that the age at which women become eligible for a pension should be raised to 65 to bring it into line with that of men. Its argument is that women are seeking equality and tend to live longer than men so there should be no basis in principle for granting the pension to women five years earlier than it is available to men.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper supposes that the savings over a four year period would be in the vicinity of $400m. This sounds perfectly absurd to me. In a climate of such high unemployment as we have today, just how many women aged 60 to 65 would find employment? The authors of the paper do not seem to have taken reality into consideration. If in fact a woman of 60 cannot get an age pension and she is designated to be of employable age, then she would be entitled to unemployment benefit if the Commonwealth Employment Service could not find her a job-and it cannot find jobs for some of the 450,000 unemployed now. Just what sort of saving is this to the community? She is whipped off the old age pension and she is put straight on to unemployment benefit. How many widows of 60 who draw a pension now have never officially worked in the employment market at all? How do they suddenly develop the skills at 60 to enter a highly competitive work force such as we have today? They have made a home, they have reared their families, they have been a partner in family life, and they have lived on the widow's pension if their husband has pre-deceased them. Are we then to say, in the cause of reducing the tax burden: 'You can't have a pension until you're 65. We'll save that money and we'll put you on unemployment benefit instead'? The idea is ill-conceived and ill thought out and should be dismissed by the Government for the absurdity it is.

Instead of thinking of raising the age at which women will be eligible to receive a pension, we should be looking at lowering to 60 the age at which men can get a pension. I agree with the equality of that. Early retirement would be most beneficial to the community at large and very beneficial for many men who work those last few years to 65 to qualify for superannuation when they are just too tired to carry on. It would also open the doors for promotions of men in the middle age group and for a larger intake of younger people at the other end of the scale and would take some of the enormous army of unemployed off the dole and on to a weekly wage.

The article implies congratulations to the Government for failing to index payments to all but 20 per cent of those on unemployment benefit, the ones indexed being those for adults with dependants. Those who are struggling to exist on the unemployment benefit will not thank the Association for being more interested in saving on the welfare bill than in provision for them to live with some semblance of dignity. The article accepts that the genuine and needy recipients of welfare benefits should have a rate of pay that keeps pace with the consumer price index. But who is going to judge who are the genuine and the needy? If one is homeless, hungry and struggling to keep one's kids, who is going to be one's judge as to whether one is genuine or not? How would such a judgment be made and who would be qualified to make it? I guess it could be said that welfare payments could be kept to the absolute minimum if it could be proved that the recipients could be described as lazy, spendthrift, dishonest and, in fact, not genuine. What absolute hypocrisy! If the Australian Industries Development Association wants to save government money and reduce the tax burden, it would be better employed getting out after the big tax avoiders who milk the general revenue of hundreds of millions of dollars annually while the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer pays his full tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pays more than his full tax.

—The honourable member is quite right. Family allowances must be increased and this should be done as a matter of urgency. I hope that the Government will totally reject the recommendations contained in this article.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

Those remarks were in response to a letter sent by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) on behalf of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party to the Soviet Ambassador on the contemporary situation in Poland. As reported in the Australian the Foreign Minister suggested that the Opposition had 'finally agreed to join the Government' in protesting Soviet interference. The letter sent by the Leader expresses in very strong terms our opposition to the possibility of Soviet interference. I seek leave to have the text of the letter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Leader of the Opposition
25 March 1981 His Excellency
Dr N. G. Soudarikov,
Ambassador for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics,
78 Canberra Avenue,
Griffith, ACT 2603
Your Excellency,

The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party would like you to convey to your government its strongest opposition to any intervention by Soviet armed forces or other Warsaw Pact countries in the internal affairs of Poland.

We believe that such a course of action will do irreparable damage to the process of detente seriously endangering world peace. Such action would be in breach of the principles of non-intervention in the internal affairs of sovereign states.

We note with concern the extension of Warsaw Pact manoeuvres in Poland and strongly urge that such pressure on the Polish Government and people should cease. The Polish people are entitled to solve their own problems without external interference.
Relations between the Soviet Union and Australia, which have already been damaged by the invasion of Afghanistan, would further deteriorate should armed intervention take place.

The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party would like you to make clear to your Government that it would share in the sense of outrage that would accompany any such intervention, and would regard it as placing in serious jeopardy the prospect of any useful relations between a future Labor Government and the Soviet Union.

It is in this regard that I have sought an appointment with you so that the concern of my Party can be conveyed to you. I thank you for agreeing to see me at 4 p.m. on Tuesday 31 March 1981 along with my Deputy, Lionel Bowen, and the President and Secretary of the FPLP Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, Mr R. Jacobi, and Mr K. Beazley. Given the uncertainties of a Parliamentary sitting day, I would much appreciate it if our meeting could take place in my office at Parliament House.

BILL HAYDEN M.P. Leader of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The letter is by no means the first comment of the Labor Party on this matter. On 27 November last year, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) sent to the Polish Embassy a petition signed by a substantial majority of members of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party which strongly supported the creation of independent trade unions in Poland, argued that they strengthen democracy and indicated the following to the Polish Government:

SPEECH.PARA: We attach great importance to the continuing ability of the Polish Government to negotiate a peaceful settlement of the complex issues without intervention by external forces.

Further back to last September after the spontaneous and dispersed strike committees co- alesced to form Solidarity in Poland, a variety of Labor Party and trade union bodies passed resolutions supporting the creation of Solidarity, the claims of Solidarity and its right to pursue those claims without external interference. Clearly, this included external interference from the Soviet Union. I moved and had adopted by the West Australian State conference of the Australian Labor Party in that month a resolution to that effect.

At every key point of this crisis, the Labor Party has strongly and publicly supported Solidarity and opposed Soviet intervention-first, last August when Solidarity first challenged the authority of the Polish state over all facets of economic planning in a move unprecedented in the eastern bloc, then in November-December when many in the United States State Department feared Soviet intervention, and finally this last week when the extension of Warsaw Pact manoeuvres raised tensions and the possiblity of Soviet intervention. We have opposed forcefully, solidly and unequivocally intervention by the Soviet Union. We have done so because as a democratic socialist party with a trade union base the economic and political reforms sought by Solidarity are four square with what we see to be the requirements of the creation of any democratic state and that includes a democratic state in Poland. Of course, we see these policies as fundamental to the existence of democracy in this country as well. We have no wish to argue with the Government on this matter. We are on the public record and we would expect a Minister with half a regard for a bipartisan approach on this matter to acknowledge that fact gracefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to add to the one minute contribution I made to the adjournment debate on Wednesday of last week when I discussed a table--
—What, more shonky figures?

—I notice that the honourable member for Cunningham is once again incapable of containing himself when presented with the facts. He is so unaccustomed to dealing with facts in his own party and on his side of the House that the presentation of statistics which are unassailable is too much for his psyche which apparently is clearly dented if one is to judge by his last observation. I was referring to official statistics relating to the grants for community health facilities from 1975-76, which those of us with any kind of memory can recall was during the term of the Labor Government, and 1980-81. Those statistics revealed that in the recurrent spending on community health facilities there had been a dramatic difference in the trends between the various States. I particularly refer to this matter because the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) had quite falsely claimed in this House that the Federal Government had cut funding to New South Wales. The statistics show of course that that is not true, particularly in the context of the funds being on a matching grant basis. If the State wishes to put up a request the Federal Government is obliged to match that request.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at the differences between the performances of the various States in the area of recurrent spending-that is, running costs of the community health service. We are all aware that there is a difference between the running costs and the capital costs. For example, in the Wollongong area which services part of my electorate and which has the ill fortune to have the honourable member for Cunningham as its representative in this House there has been a clear distinction between capital and recurrent spending because the State Government, in fact, has reduced recurrent spending in that area and instead stated that it plans to spend something like $50,000 purchasing a house while at the same time threatening to put off community health service workers who are involved in the recurrent spending side of the program; in other words, who are actually providing a service to the people.

Let us look at the differences between the performances in New South Wales and Victoria. From 1975-76 to 1980-81 in Victoria there was a rise from $7.7m to $15.9m; after accounting for inflation that was a sizable rise. There was a similar sort of rise in Queensland from $3.6m to about $6.1m. In South Australia there was a rise from $1.97m to $3.5m. These are all pretty substantial rises. I concede that these levels of funding still do not reach the levels of funding that exist in the New South Wales service; that is quite true. In New South Wales the total is still higher than it is in the other States as, of course, it should be; New South Wales is a bigger State. There is no doubt that in Victoria there seems to be a greater concentration on home help service. Certainly, on a per capita basis it is far higher in Victoria than in New South Wales. That is an offset which I recognise.

It is interesting to see that in New South Wales the increase in recurrent spending has been only from $19.3m to $24.2m. That is a much lower rate of rise than the rate in any other State of Australia. We must remember that they are matching grants by the Federal Government in response to requests from the States. That is almost an open-ended situation because if the States put up the money the Federal Government is obliged to meet it. The State of New South Wales has taken a different view to that of the other States in the matter of recurrent spending. I think it is worth mentioning that the honourable member for Cunningham misled the House when making totally incorrect assertions about the running costs of community health facilities in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, once again we have had to listen to a diatribe of shonky figures from the little grafter from Macarthur.

—Order! The honourable member for Cunningham has a habit of using a word which the dictionary has not taken notice of. I think we should regard it as unparliamentary. I ask the honourable member to desist from its use.

SPEECH.PARA: The terrible thing about all this is that most of these cases are affecting services in the field; that is, the services of community nurses who go out and look after people such as the poor old lady featured in the Illawarra Daily Mercury who has terminal cancer and who is frightened that, because of the cuts that the honourable member for Macarthur and his Government have foisted upon the service in New South Wales, she will not get nursing services any more. TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to address this House tonight on a subject that is very dear to the hearts of many country producers. I refer to the problem of meat inspection services and the manner in which they apply to export abattoirs. Recently an abattoir within my electorate-the Tip Top abattoir which is located in the Northam Shire-sought an export licence. The abattoir previously serviced a major retail chain in Western Australia and, under the laws of that State, operated in a situation in which the local authority, namely, the Northam shire, was able to supply the meat inspection services. It did this according to the health requirements of Western Australia for the cost in the case of a bullock of $1.25. Nevertheless, when the company decided that it needed additional throughput and sought an export licence, it found that the Commonwealth had to enter the scene. In doing this, the work force situation was reconsidered. It is a fact that importing countries require a higher degree of meat inspection and consequently additional meat inspectors and the services of a veterinary officer. However, the Northam shire originally operated with 10 meat inspectors, eight of whom worked at any one time. When our employees turned up on the scene it was discovered that approximately 16 operatives would be needed. The original suggestion was that all of these people should be supplied by the Department of Primary Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that because of the concern that has been felt by governments certain investigations and inquiries have been held, the last of which was carried out by Mr Bert Kelly, who is well known to many people in this Parliament. Included in his discoveries was that after the Commonwealth supplied its meat inspection service the Australian taxpayer is up for about $26m a year. That is over and above the $1.80 which is charged by the Commonwealth for its meat inspection service. So the producer is loaded with, firstly, a local inspection fee, which in this case is $1.25, the Commonwealth fee, and if he happens to be a taxpayer he has to contribute to the $26m loss.

Interestingly, the Northam shire has managed to make ends meet on the revenue of some $200,000 a year that is attracted. It did this in various ways, one of which was to pool its vehicle resources when it was necessary to get men to work. In fact it managed to get the work force to work for a fee of about $7,000 a year. It drew to my attention that if the same eight inspectors were taken to work by the Commonwealth the cost would jump to $43,000 a year; and we wonder where the money is going.

In this case the shire did not want to dismiss any of its workers. It was quite willing to supply men whose qualifications exceeded the minimum requirement of the Department of Primary Industry, at no charge to the Commonwealth, to carry on the services. In the interest of the abattoir when our people came on the scene-apparently they are a very elitist lot-they demanded separate ablution facilities. The union has convinced our Bureau of Animal Health that such facilities are necessary. A letter dated 1 September 1980 stated that it was the Department's firm policy not to share amenities with other inspector personnel. When that was queried we discovered that in fact it was the policy of the Meat Inspectors Association. On 30 December the Association wrote stating:
It is the policy of the Association not to share amenities with any other than DPI inspectors on any registered export works.

That is about as un-Australian as bowling underarm. To be quite honest, it astounds me that workers in the Australian community cannot even share, with similar qualified people, their ablution facilities. That is the circumstance that we have.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer by the Minister's predecessor to part (5) of question No. 5332 (Hansard, 15 May 1980, page 2876), how many claims for compensation from Vietnam veterans, based on possible exposure to herbicides, pesticides and other chemicals, had been received by the Department of Veterans' Affairs by 25 November 1980.
(2) How many of those claims had been accepted by 25 November 1980 and how many of those accepted were attributed to (a) specific chemical exposure and (b) non-specific war-related disease or injury.

(3) What are the details of the progress made by the Commonwealth Institute of Health in the conduct of the epidemiological study into the effects of chemicals used in Vietnam on Vietnam veterans and their wives and families as at 25 November 1980.

(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statement made by the United States Federal Department of Health and Human Services, dated 1 August 1980, that (a) there are inherent statistical limitations in the US Air Force proposal epidemiological study, (b) that study would need a significant period of follow-up beyond 5 years and (c) that scientific research other than epidemiological studies is also required.

(5) Has the Minister caused (a) the Department of Veterans' Affairs, (b) the Commonwealth Institute of Health, (c) any other Federal agency or (d) any other individual or organisation to conduct any scientific and/or medical research into the effects of chemicals used in Vietnam, in addition to the Commonwealth Institute of Health's epidemiological study; if so, what are the details; if not, will the Minister give urgent consideration to any other research that may be required.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Up to and including 30 November 1980, 749 claims had been received (825 as at 28 February 1981).

(2) Up to the date in question there had been 73 cases where disabilities had been accepted as being service-related but none of these was accepted as causally related to chemical exposure (99 and zero as at 28 February 1981).

(3) A detailed progress report on the conduct of the epidemiological study is contained in a news release, dealing with the offering of free hospital treatment for Vietnam veterans and with the study, issued by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs on 14 January 1981. With respect to the study the news release stated, in part, that:

The Institute has received essential data from the Central Army Records Office in Melbourne on Army personnel who served in Vietnam, and on other Army personnel who are being considered as a control group for the study. Information has also been provided by the Department of Defence on troop locations and movements, and the United States Department of Defence has supplied computer tapes detailing American fixed-wing aircraft herbicide-spraying operations.

The Institute has pre-tested data collection questionnaires, and will conduct a pilot study involving some 600 veterans and their families. The purpose of this pilot study is to establish the relative merits of three different types of data collection and various administrative systems which could be used in the major study.

The results of this pilot study will be submitted to the Scientific Advisory Committee which will assess how appropritate the study's methodology is. The major study of all contactable Vietnam veterans, a control group, and families of both groups, is planned to begin during the third quarter of 1981.

(4) The Minister is aware of a report by the Department of Health and Human Services which concerns the epidemiological study of 'Ranch Hand' personnel, designed by the US Air Force. The Report gives the conclusions of the US Inter-agency Work Group on the Possible Long-Term Health Effects of Phenoxy Herbicides and Contaminants. The Work Group, while recognising that there are several limitations inherent in the study design, strongly recommended that the study, with appropriate protocol modifications and with outside peer review and monitoring, be commenced by the Air Force as soon as possible. The Scientific Panel which advises the Inter-agency Work Group pointed out in a report on the 'Ranch Hand' Study that this study is but one segment of a larger effort and that there are other studies that are critical to the overall effort, some of which are: the US Dioxin Registry; the proposed International Dioxin Registry; the Case Control Study of Human Birth Defects; the Health Evaluation of the Nitro, West Virginia worker population; the proposed US Department of Veterans' Administration Epidemiology Study; the 'Agent Orange' male mouse study; and ongoing laboratory studies such as those which are assessing the potential of Herbicide Orange components to cause genetic damage (mutation). It is understood that a decision has been made to proceed with the 'Ranch Hand' Study.

(5) The Department of Veterans' Affairs is establishing a data base from information contained in the claims of veterans who cite exposure to chemicals as a possible cause of their disabilities. Results are not yet available and are unlikely to be available until a greater number of claims have been determined. No other bodies have been asked to undertake any scientific and/or medical research into the effects of the chemicals used in Vietnam and no additional Australian studies are currently planned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say whether the British-based company, Rio Tinto Zinc Corporation (RTZ) has taken up its full entitlement of shares in the latest 1-for-15 rights issue by Conzinc Riotinto Australia Ltd (CRA), as reported in the Financial Australian on 3 September 1980; if so, does this constitute a rejection of an opportunity to increase Australian ownership of CRA.
(2) What benefits does CRA gain from the Government from the promise by RTZ to lower its stake in CRA to 49 per cent.
(3) Is he also able to say whether RTZ has persistently undertaken to Australianise CRA.
(4) If RTZ has not undertaken to Australianise CRA, what steps will he take to ensure that RTZ complies with Government policy guidelines on this matter.
(5) When does the Government expect Australian ownership in CRA to reach the level required by Government policy.
(6) Has the government given urgent consideration to a time scale for the Australianisation of CRA; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation Ltd (RTZ) subscribed to its entitlement to a 1-for-15 rights issue announced by CRA Ltd on 2 September 1980. The reasons for its decision to do so, involving matters of commercial judgment, were advised in confidence to the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Government. The Government accepted that judgement, noting that Australian equity in CRA had increased from 27.4 per cent to 38.9 per cent since early 1979.

(2) Having complied with the necessary policy pre-conditions to be granted the status of a naturalising company, CRA is given prior credit for 51 per cent Australian ownership and is regarded as meeting the Australian equity and control guidelines in relation to any new natural resource development projects (other than uranium projects) in which it may wish to participate. It may proceed to develop such new natural resource projects without notification to the Government where it intends to carry out the development on its own or in conjunction with other naturalising or naturalised companies or with an Australian-owned company.
(3) and (4) RTZ has given undertakings to the Government that it will pursue the naturalisation of CRA in terms of the policy, and it has also made a public commitment to do so.

(5) and (6) A firm time scale for achieving naturalised status was not set because the Government recognises the rate of progress must depend largely on commercial judgments of what is achievable. As one of the undertakings required by the Government prior to the granting of naturalising status to CRA, RTZ and CRA are committed to hold regular discussions with the Foreign Investment Review Board to report on the progress being made towards naturalisation. One such meeting was held in September 1980. I am confident that adequate opportunities will arise in the future for maintaining an acceptable rate of increase in the level of Australian ownership of CRA, particularly through the financing of new projects to be developed by that company. I am equally confident that the naturalisation provisions of the Government's foreign investment policy will encourage increasing participation by Australians in the development of Australia's resources and industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In its assessment of social security beneficiaries' extra income, is the attitude of the Department of Social Security as to what constitutes income the same as that of the Australian Taxation Office.

(2) If not, (a) in what respects do the attitudes differ, (b) why are there two separate attitudes and (c) will the Minister institute changes to bring the assessment of income by the Department of Social Security into line with the procedure used by the Australian Taxation Office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) The Social Services Act defines income for pension and benefit purposes to mean:

''any personal earnings, moneys, valuable consideration or profits earned, derived or received by that person for his own use or benefit by any means from any source whatsoever, within or outside Australia and includes any periodical payment or benefit by way of gift or allowance . . .''
The Income Tax Assessment Act does not contain any definition of income. Consequently, the term is understood in its general meaning determined according to ordinary concepts and usages.

Liability for income tax is based primarily on taxable income, which is calculated by deducting from the assessable income all allowable deductions. Under the Act, assessable income includes some items which are not income within the ordinary meaning of the term, and does not include some receipts which are income within the ordinary meaning, such as those which are specifically declared to be exempt from tax.

(b) Variations in what is regarded as income validly may exist when the general rationale underlying the respective systems differ. The social security system is based on presumed need for income support while the income tax system is based on the principle of ability to pay tax.

(c) In view of (a) and (b) the fact that the laws relating to social security and taxation have different provisions governing the determination of a person's income does not of itself indicate that changes to either law are necessary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the growing levels of complaint from Defence Service families with respect to the neglect of basic maintenance of Service housing.

(2) Will he provide details of (a) maintenance programs for Service housing for 1980-81 and (b) the (i) availability and (ii) response time, of urgent repair and maintenance work with respect to each area where Service housing is established.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that Defence Service families complain from time to time about the maintenance of married quarters they occupy. However, there has been no increase in the number of complaints made to me personally; and I am informed that there is no evidence that the general level of complaints is growing.

(2) (a) There are approximately 23,500 Service houses in Australia. About one third of these are owned by the Commonwealth Government and maintained by the Department of Housing and Construction. The balance are owned and maintained by State Governments, under Commonwealth/State Housing Agreements.
The Commonwealth Government allocated $5.2m in 1980-81 for the maintenance of those Service houses it owns. It also allocated $1.8m for capital improvements to Service houses owned by the States.
According to State Housing Authorities, about $6.9m will be spent in 1980-81 on the maintenance of houses provided for Servicemen under Commonwealth/State Housing Agreements.

(b) Requests for urgent repairs to Commonwealth-owned Service houses are normally responded to immediately (i.e. the same day) by the Department of Housing and Construction. If such repairs cannot be completed then, holding maintenance is carried out.

State housing authorities have advised that urgent repairs and maintenance to Service houses for which they are responsible are carried out promptly. Two State Housing Authorities advised that such work is normally carried out the same day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he give consideration to either (a) increasing the allowance paid to multiple sclerosis sufferers for intensive care or (b) taking steps to have the subsidy paid to nursing homes for treatment of sufferers increased.

(2) Would the proposals outlined in part (1) meet, to some extent, the additional expenses incurred by multiple sclerosis patients for intensive physiotherapy on the one or two occasions per year when such treatment is required.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) There are two types of subsidy payable in respect of patients accommodated in nursing homes approved under the National Health Act-the basic benefit which varies from State to State and is reviewed annually, and the extensive care benefit. These benefits are paid by the Commonwealth on behalf of patients without hospital insurance, and by registered health insurance funds on behalf of their contributors.

There are also homes approved under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act for deficit financing. Under the deficit financing arrangements, the Commonwealth meets the approved operating deficit of the nursing home each year.

In reviewing basic benefits each year the principle adopted by the Commonwealth is that benefits should be set at a level in each State which, together with the minimum statutory patient contribution, would cover fees charged for 70 per cent of beds in the State in non-Government nursing homes approved under the National Health Act.

The extensive care benefit is an additional benefit payable in respect of patients who are in need of and receiving extensive care. The current rate of extensive care benefit is $42 per week and only one rate is payable throughout Australia.

It is not Government policy to pay a further additional benefit in respect of particular categories of patients. The fees that homes charge may include, where appropriate, the services of paramedical staff e.g. physiotherapists. It is known, for example, that in the honourable member's home State, Queensland, multiple sclerosis sufferers are mainly accommodated in Granston Lodge Nursing Home, Dutton Park, Brisbane. This home makes provision for paramedical services, such as intensive physiotherapy, at no additional expense to patients.
In 1979-80 the Commonwealth paid $312m in respect of patients in nursing homes.
